DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR HENRY BASIL TURNER

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on Monday, 19 September 1988, of Henry Basil Turner, a former member of the House of Representatives.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution: Proposed Changes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. that the constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. our deep concern that the recommendations of the constitutional commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the states and weakens the role of the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that . . .

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.
2. This would make it possible for U.S killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack.
This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `Joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia army barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out that aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

We, the petitioners, request the Government to ensure that provision of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in this State.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgment that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non-aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves,
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Vessels in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, strongly urge that the Australian Government prohibit the entry of nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered vessels into Australian ports or waters during our bicentennial celebrations and at any other time in the future.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-My remarks follow on from those made by my colleague the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The release read as follows-
Statement by Senator John Stone,
Leader of the National Party in the Senate

Naturally I regret yesterday's decision by the Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. John Howard, to request the Leader of my own National Party, the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair to terminate my membership of the Shadow Cabinet-a decision subsequently concurred in with regret, as he has said, by Mr Sinclair.
Because of some confusion in media reporting of yesterday's events leading up to that outcome, the salient facts are set out for the record in the Attachment to this media release.

As will be clear from that Attachment, I totally support the new, and much improved, immigration policy recently agreed by the Coalition Parties. Any balanced reading of the transcript of last Sunday's ``Face to Face'' program would have clearly shown that.
Indeed, having had no small hand in having the new immigration policy arrived at, it would be extraordinary if I were not now to support it.

As some journalists have quite correctly pointed out this morning, the problem between me and some other members of the Shadow Cabinet-as well as certain backbench members of the Liberal Party-lies not in the wording of our new immigration policy but in its interpretation.

I would have wished to avoid raking over old coals in that respect, but in the light of Mr Howard's comments at his media conference yesterday about my alleged failure to be a ``team player'' in this matter, I am forced to say that in that regard my only fault has been to support too faithfully the position originally taken up-and never recanted-by the leader of the team.

As to the question of what Mr Howard, in his news release yesterday, called ``Shadow Cabinet discipline and teamwork'' more generally, I shall take a more appropriate opportunity to comment in detail on that aspect-including suggestions being purveyed by way of background briefing of the media.

Suffice it perhaps only to recall that there was no criticism of my ``discipline and teamwork'' when, last year, I was the means of presenting the Leader of the Opposition with his greatest triumph in this Parliament-the killing off of the Australia Card-as he said, ``Stone dead''.
But enough of all that. I want only to add two things.

First, I remain a loyal member, in good standing, of my own parliamentary National Party Room. In that capacity I shall continue to work as hard in the future as I have done during the past year or so to bring about the defeat of the Labor Party-whether federally, in the State election now proceeding in Victoria, or in the impending by-election in the federal seat of Oxley. So far as I can see, my capacity to do so will not be materially affected-and indeed may even be enhanced-by yesterday's decision.
Secondly, and particularly after having talked to my family and some good friends about all this, I am inclined to think that, on balance, Mr Howard yesterday may have done me a favour.
At any rate, that is the attitude of mind which I bring to it all today.
Canberra, A.C.T.
14 September, 1988
Attachment

Yesterday morning in Sydney, by arrangement, I discussed with the Leader of the National Party, the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, the demands which had been made of him by the Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. John Howard, following my appearance on the Channel 10 programme ``Face to Face'' last Sunday.

As a result of that discussion I initially acceded to Mr Sinclair's personal request to me, in his capacity as Leader of my Party, to signify to Mr Howard my willingness to issue a statement relating to immigration policy.
For the record, the text of that statement was as follows:
``In my `Face to Face' interview broadcast on Sunday last, some questioning related to immigration.
There have been subsequent suggestions in the media that in my responses to that questioning I was in some way seeking to re-open the debate on the Coalition policy or differ from it.
That is not so.
As with all members of Shadow Cabinet I of course accept and am bound by that policy.
The remarks I made earlier about this issue were of course before Coalition policy was adopted.
The policy itself makes no decision on migrant mix nor does it identify or exclude any source country.
The policy however does provide Coalition Government with the capacity to control the flow of migrants from any part of the world if it were felt desirable to do so.''

At this point Mr Howard made the new demand that I should add to the statement above a further and final paragraph saying that in my future statements as a Shadow Minister I would confine myself to those relating to my own Shadow portfolio of Finance or otherwise only in support of settled Coalition policy.
Particularly having in mind my position as Leader of the National Party in the Senate, and for other obvious reasons, I was not prepared to do so; nor did Mr Sinclair suggest that I should.
Again for the record I should say that, apart from a fleeting chance encounter in the corridor, at no time yesterday did Mr Howard and I converse personally on these matters.

—Is the Minister for Justice aware that the Hawke-Keating Government of which he is a part is proposing to save $40m a year by removing pharmaceutical benefits for vital drugs required by people with chronic illnesses such as asthma and epilepsy? As the Minister was responsible for bringing forward in this place proposals for constitutional amendment at a total cost of almost $50m can he explain how or why higher priority was given to this discredited, deceptive and wasteful exercise which has been so decisively rejected by the Australian people, rather than helping people with life-threatening illnesses?

—I believe that the expenditure by the Government in relation to the constitutional referendum campaign was totally justified in the sense that the Australian people-as ought to be the case in a democracy-were presented with proposals for change which had been given assent to not only by the House of Representatives but also by this chamber where the Government does not have a majority. The people were presented with an opportunity to make a judgment on the proposals and gave their verdict. This Government, being proud of the fact that it has had a term of government in this great democracy, accepted that verdict quite readily. I believe that the money was well spent. Indeed, as one moves around the country one finds that the interesting constitutional matters which arose during that campaign are a very important part of the democratic process and the expenditure is justified in that sense alone. The other matter which has to do with recurrent savings in relation to another portfolio program is a matter on which I have no comment to make.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister saying that he supports giving higher priority to these referendums than to the maintenance of drugs that are required by people with chronic illnesses such as asthma and epilepsy?

—I make no such statement, nor should that be inferred from my comment. I am saying that the expenditure on the constitutional referendum campaign was justified and proper. The Government's decision on recurrent savings in relation to certain benefits in the pharmaceutical area is a matter which I believe can be justified.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a letter published in the Australian Financial Review on Wednesday, 21 September, from Mr Max Burr, MHR? Among other things that letter asserts:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government has now acquired almost half of our national economy; it was 28 per cent in 1972 under the McMahon Government.
Can the Minister provide the Senate with information on the accuracy of these figures regarding the current size of government in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the letter from Max Burr, who I think is a member of the Liberal Party from Tasmania or somewhere. I am surprised that the Australian Financial Review has published this sort of thing, because its readership is much too sophisticated to take this sort of rubbish seriously. It is like a visit back to the 1940s, when I started taking an interest in politics. It is hard to know what he means by saying that the Government has acquired almost half of the economy. It is probably his clumsy way of purporting to describe the fraction of gross domestic product (GDP) which the Commonwealth Government, in this case, spends via Budget outlays. So in addition to the previously known innumeracy of members of the Opposition we can now produce evidence of semi-literacy.

ANSWER.PARA: On the basis of Commonwealth outlays as a proportion of GDP, the correct figure for 1988-89 is 25.6 per cent, not almost half as Mr Burr asserted. It is true that that figure is higher than the 1971-72 figure, which was 23 per cent. It is, however, lower than for all the years of the Fraser Government. In the seven years of the Fraser Government Commonwealth Budget outlays as a proportion of GDP, starting from 1976-77, were: 27.7 per cent; 28.2 per cent; 27.1 per cent; 26 per cent; 26.2 per cent; 26.7 per cent; and, in the last year, with John Howard's supernova Budget it blew out to 29 per cent of gross domestic product, and, as Senator Stone was good enough to put in writing shortly after that, it left this Government facing a prospective Budget deficit of almost $10 billion.

So if socialism, which is purported to be the subject of Mr Burr's letter, is defined as a higher proportion of Government expenditure, Mr Burr should be vilifying the Fraser Government for all of its Budgets and not vilifying the present Government for its last Budget. But if he wants to know more about public finance, I suggest he ask Senator Stone for some help because, firstly, Senator Stone understands these things and, secondly, he will have a bit more spare time than he used to have-unless he is providing research assistance for the new shadow Finance Minister, Dr Hewson, whom Senator Stone once described as a mere meretricious player flitting across the stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government, who would be aware that in the May economic statement the Hawke-Keating Government cut more than $30m off road funding for State and local government. As the Government has just spent considerably more than that sum on its futile and dishonest proposals for constitutional change, can the Minister explain how priority was given to those discredited, deceptive and wasteful proposals which have been so decisively rejected by the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that Senator Calvert has not been in touch with local government in Tasmania.
—You ought to be ashamed of that vote. You ought to resign.

—The reality is that local government throughout Australia is extremely disappointed in the outcome of the referendum. It is even more disappointed and disgusted with the attitudes of the Opposition in regard to the way in which it conducted its campaign. I believe that Senator Calvert will find that he and all Opposition members have a great deal of bridge-building to do with local government.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Calvert asks me about road funding, but in reality it is the Opposition that will have to be involved in bridge-building with local government. Local government rejects the Opposition's stance in relation to the referendum and, of course, it was very disappointed. However, I believe it is important now to focus on the outcomes of the referendum in relation to constitutional recognition of local government. One of the most important outcomes that many Australians are interested in, even though obviously members of the Opposition are not particularly interested in local government, is that the campaign enabled people throughout Australia to find out more about local government and to find out about its contribution to local communities. This has been a very worthwhile exercise. Furthermore, it has prompted both the Tasmanian Premier and the Queensland Premier to look at recognising local government in State constitutions, something which, I am sure, all honourable senators on this side of the chamber will agree is a major step forward. Finally, of course, I understand that in New South Wales the Premier, Mr Greiner, is looking at enshrining local government in the constitution and is considering calling a referendum to ensure that that recognition cannot be taken out by government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not seem to understand that in the terms of the New South Wales constitution you cannot take it out except by way of referendum.

—Precisely. That was the basis of the approach that the Government took in putting this question to the people. I believe that later this year, in November, I will be conducting consultations with the Australian Local Government Association to try to get greater progress in regard to inter-governmental relations. I think this is very important. The question that was asked at the referendum was about greater recognition of and greater consultation with local government. Just because the Opposition was not prepared to adopt a bipartisan approach on this issue, I am not deterred and Australian local government is not deterred. We will continue to work for the recognition of local government. One of these days members of the Opposition will agree to support a proposal that does in fact recognise the very important role that local government plays for local communities.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for her long answer on local government but she really has not answered why priority was given to constitutional change. Does she deny that $30m was cut from State and local government road funding?
—I am not sure where Senator Calvert gets his figures.
—Look at the Estimates.

—If one looks very closely at road funding one will find that there are a number of categories of funding in so far as it affects local government. In actual fact, when it comes to local roads funding, we have been able to maintain funding to local government in real terms. That means that there has been a $13m increase this year for local roads funding. It is true I believe that the figures which Senator Calvert is referring to relate to arterial road funding and the amount of funding that goes through State governments. Of course, State governments contract to local governments. Therefore, I do not dispute Senator Calvert's $30m in that sense. However, I think it is important to recognise that the Government and Senator Walsh-I pay tribute to him as Finance Minister for being keen to support local government-have ensured that local road funding has been maintained in real terms. When Senator Stone was on the Opposition front bench he was always talking about greater cuts in government spending. It is important in the current economic climate that local government take the necessary restraints that have been applied to both Commonwealth and State governments. I believe that the outcome of that real terms increase in local roads funding was a very fair and equitable decision for local government, given the overall period of restraint.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to my question of 10 May concerning human rights abuses in Colombia in South America. Has the Minister's attention now been drawn to a special report by Amnesty International, documenting horrific human rights abuses in Colombia? Does the Minister have anything further to add to his answer to me on 10 May?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not a lot that I can add to the answer that I gave to Senator Maguire on this matter, but the situation does remain one that gives the Government very serious concern. The tragic human rights situation in that country was the subject of a report by Amnesty in April of this year, documenting abuses, including political killings and disappearances which have apparently continued at high levels, against a background of violence involving the Government, guerilla groups and criminal groups associated with drug trafficking. In a reply to Amnesty International's report, the Government of Colombia pointed out that efforts were being made to improve the general human rights situation. That may or may not be the case.

ANSWER.PARA: As in the past, the Australian Government has expressed its concern about the situation in Colombia. In the first half of this year 11 representations were made to the Colombian Government on specific instances of human rights abuse involving groups and individuals. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Has the Government called upon all State governments to advise them of contingency plans in the event of a nuclear accident in an Australian port? In particular, and in view of the massive concentration of warships in Sydney Harbour over the next few days, many of which are probably carrying nuclear weapons, has the Government checked contingency plans for a nuclear accident in Sydney Harbour? Has the Government drawn up contingency plans for a nuclear accident within Australian waters? If not, why not? If so, is the Minister satisfied of the adequacy of all such plans? When will the Government make all these plans public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some background material that may assist Senator McLean. A preliminary draft of the procedural document for responding to nuclear weapons accidents has been prepared. This document has no status, having not been approved within the Department of Defence, by the relevant interdepartmental committee, or by Mr Beazley himself. The Government has no reason to alter its long-established assessments concerning the safety of nuclear weapons that could be deployed on allied warships visiting Australian ports. An accidental nuclear detonation is essentially impossible. Secondly, the chance of any kind of accident involving a nuclear weapon is virtually nil.

ANSWER.PARA: These assessments are based on the fact that all nuclear weapons that might be carried on visiting allied warships would be safely stowed under armed guard in their magazines, protected from fire and electrically disconnected. They would not be handled or used for training. They would not be in an armed condition.

The Government does not require visiting allied warships to declare whether they deploy nuclear weapons. The general emergency plan of Australian ports would be adequate to respond to any conceivable accident. The purpose of the current document would be to formalise arrangements for Commonwealth assistance to State governments. It has always been envisaged that the Commonwealth would provide assistance to States, analagous to arrangements outlined in existing plans for visits by nuclear-powered warships. When a sound draft set of procedures has been finalised the Government will consider the desirability of their adoption. In the meantime there is no reason to alter the Government's position of allowing visits to Australian ports by nuclear-capable ships.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to understand that the Minister is saying there is a plan but it has no status? Therefore, my question is: Is not such a plan no plan at all?

—All plans have their embryonic beginnings. I cannot add much to the brief, other than to say that that particular plan is in the developmental stage. It has not yet officially been approved, as I indicated to the honourable senator, by the Department of Defence, the interdepartmental committee or Minister Beazley himself.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. By way of preface I note that in the recent Commonwealth Budget the Treasurer forecast that, because of an improvement in our international terms of trade this year, our external balance of payments deficit would decline to `only' $9.5 billion and that that decline, together with the large surplus estimated in the Budget, would produce downward pressure on our domestic interest rates. I ask the Minister: First, in the light of recent trends in commodity prices, together with the extraordinary balance of payments deficit of $1.67 billion for July alone, does the Minister still forecast a $9.5 billion deficit for the year as a whole? Secondly, does the Minister agree that since the Budget commercial interest rates have risen, not fallen, and that there is now every likelihood that, as soon as the Victorian election and the Oxley by-election are out of the way, commercial interest rates, including housing loan rates, will rise further? Finally, given these developments, will the Minister now make it clear that without major spending cuts the Government cannot possibly provide the Treasurer's promised tax cuts next July without blowing out the balance of payments even further and producing an even faster rise in our foreign debt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that Senator Stone's first question in his new capacity was directed to me. I thought it would have been directed to Senator Ray as the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, since immigration is Senator Stone's favourite topic and his primary interest. Now that he is no longer the shadow spokesman on finance apparently he is interested in Treasury matters and public finance. I have been asked whether the Government believes that the $9.5 billion current account deficit forecast in the Budget is an accurate one. I think it is much too early to give a considered response to that question. Certainly the current account deficit for July was higher than anybody I know of anticipated, but we have had only one month while figures perform and I think it is much too early to speculate about whether the $9.5 billion forecast was correct.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to interest rates, Senator Stone seems to be caught in a time warp. He suggested that interest rates were being held down in some way because of an election in some State next Saturday. He seems to be back in the 1980 period, when of course, as Secretary to the Treasury, he would have been absolutely disgusted by the actions of the Fraser Government and John Howard, when everybody knew that monetary policy should be tightened, in artificially holding down interest rates until an election in Queensland was out of the way. This ultimately did the Fraser Government a great deal of damage and destroyed what little bit of credibility it may have had left at that time. But Senator Stone is caught in that time warp. Apparently, he still believes that interest rates are regulated, whereas, of course, for the past 1 1/2 years-or is it 2 1/2 years; I am not quite sure-apart from pre-existing housing loan rates, interest rates have not been regulated. The level of interest rates is something which, essentially, the financial institutions determine, and not the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. First, I understand from the Minister's response that he refuses to confirm the balance of payments forecast. Secondly, will the Minister now respond to the second of my questions, which was-and leaving aside the question of whether it follows the Victorian election or the Oxley by-election: does the Minister agree that interest rates are likely to rise further in the near future, including housing loan interest rates? Thirdly, I refer to the question to which the Minister did not respond at all, namely: will he now make it clear that, without major spending cuts, the Government cannot possibly provide the Treasurer's promised tax cuts next July without blowing out the balance of payments even further and producing an even faster rise in our foreign debt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did neglect to comment on Senator Stone's reference to commodity prices in the original question that he asked. Ever since October last year, Senator Stone has been preaching doom and gloom and saying, essentially, that obviously the world is heading for a massive depression; that, because of the stock market collapse, 1929-30 is going to repeat itself; and so on. The honourable senator asked several questions along those lines last October and November. I told him then that I thought it was too early to make those sorts of predictions. I said that there were two ways in which the stock market crash conceivably could have damaged the Australian economy, namely, if it had induced a flight of capital from Australia or a drastic fall in commodity prices. There was no evidence in November that either of those things was going to happen, and there is still no evidence of that.

ANSWER.PARA: As to what the market generally may do to interest rates in Australia, I intend to follow the practice that I have followed as long as I have had this job: I will not speculate about the direction in which I think interest rates are likely to go. I will not repeat the mistakes that Senator Stone's National Party colleagues made when they were in government. I remember Mr Anthony saying in 1977 that if interest rates had not fallen by 2 per cent before the end of the year he would eat his hat. By the end of the year interest rates had increased by about 2 per cent. I will not speculate on interest rates, any more than I will speculate on what I think the value of the Australian dollar should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Resources would be aware, the soil conservation conference in Cairns in August endorsed the Federal Government's support for a community based approach to the issue of land degradation. What is Victoria's commitment to this issue and has Victoria put any initiatives in place, in conjunction with the Commonwealth Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Victoria has put in place a number of initiatives in conjunction with the Commonwealth Government, I am pleased to say. In many respects, Victoria is a model State when it comes to effort to combat land degradation. Before I go into details, I think it is important that the Senate be reminded that the most overwhelmingly important conservation issue in Australia is that of land degradation. Annually we lose over $600m in production from agricultural lands in this country because we allow lands to decline, to salinate and to erode, and the river systems and water catchments that serve them to become polluted and eutrophied.

ANSWER.PARA: After I took over this portfolio, very early on I appointed a ministerial task force, consisting of Rick Farley, the executive director of the National Farmers Federation, and Philip Toyne, the executive director of the Australian Conservation Foundation. The reason for my taking that action was, in part, based on an action taken by Joan Kirner, the Victorian Minister for Conservation, Forests and Lands, who has worked very closely with the Victorian Farmers Federation in developing a land care model, a community based model for land protection in Victoria. The Victorian land care model focuses very much on the actions of community groups and it aims at solving the problem of land degradation not simply by trying to find a chequebook answer by throwing money at the problem, but rather by motivating farmers, local government councillors and other people in local communities through a catchment based approach to resolving the problems of land degradation in their own areas. I think the Victorian land care program stands as a shining example to the rest of Australia. It is a major initiative by the Victorian Government.

For example, under land care the budget for tree planting to control erosion and salinity stands at some $27m over the last several years. Expenditure in Victoria for 1987-88 under the national soil conservation program totalled $677,536, the State component of which was almost $624,000 and the national component $53,000. Under the national soil conservation program we are currently funding 22 projects in Victoria. The value of this expenditure is $583,600, of which the State has a component of $475,000 and we, the Commonwealth, a national component of $107,781.

As well as those positive steps, the Victorian Government is a co-sponsor of the first land care community conference, which is to be held in Bendigo on 29 and 30 September this year. This important conference stands to energise further the work of local community groups, the bipartisan political nature of the attack upon this major problem, and better information and understanding of what can be done to remedy the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I ask that the Minister table the document from which he was reading.
—There is no point of order. However, will the Minister table the document?
—I was not reading from a document, Mr President. I can table my notes, if that is what the honourable senator would wish to see.
—That is a document.
—I have a few pencilled notes. Fine, I will table them.

—Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware of the existence of nine legal opinions and an Ombudsman report relating to the conduct of a household expenditure survey currently being undertaken by the Australian Bureau of Statistics? Is the Minister also aware that eight of these opinions, including that of the Senate Clerk Assistant (Procedure) and eminent lawyers as Professor Whalan of the Australian National University, are that the survey is a new one and should have been tabled in Parliament prior to its commencement and that, as a result, the survey is illegal? Is the Minister also aware that the only opinion supporting the household expenditure survey is the one given by the Attorney-General's Department, while the Ombudsman's report suggests that the matter should be tested for legality in the courts? In light of this overwhelming opinion against the legality of the household expenditure survey, will the Minister confirm media speculation that the Attorney-General's Department has been instructed to re-examine the matter and, if so, when will the results of this re-examination be made available to the Senate?

—I am aware in a general way of the conflict of legal opinions that have been circulated. But, of course, the Government relies, as it properly should, on the opinion that has been provided by the Attorney-General's Department in relation to this matter. It is quite supportive of that opinion. The fact is that I am not aware of any re-examination of the matter within the Attorney-General's portfolio. —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I refer to an amnesty provided by the Federal Government to Australian grape growers who might be guilty of importing illegal table, dried fruit and wine grape cuttings. I ask: What has been the response to the amnesty, which expired earlier this month? How many properties whose owners have not responded are under continued Federal Government suspicion, and of these how many are now under quarantine? What are the dangers posed to the Australian rural community through the illegal importation of vines? What are the penalties available to the courts against growers found to be guilty of this practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September an amnesty that I had extended to those who had illegally imported grape vines expired. At the expiration of that amnesty, 27 growers had taken advantage of it and offered vines for destruction by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, and 32 properties are currently quarantined for the suspected presence of illegally imported vines. We are continuing, through the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, to investigate and determine whether such vines are present on other properties as well. It is a matter of considerable importance to the Commonwealth, not to mention to anyone in Australia who likes to sample our wines or, indeed, enjoys a table grape or dried fruits, that foreign vines that may contain exotic diseases which are communicable to properly registered vineyards or grape growers in this country, therefore bringing into jeopardy the health of their crop, be not imported.

ANSWER.PARA: Thus the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service maintains an extremely close check to see that nothing is illegally imported. However, we came across some illegally imported vines in the Mildura area of Victoria and we were aware through the grower organisations that there may have been some widespread practice of illegal importation. We took advice from the grower organisations that the best way of dealing with this was, rather than to investigate, to offer an amnesty to allow those who had illegally imported to come forward. As I have said, some 27 growers have turned themselves in-six from the Sunraysia district in Victoria and 21 from the Swan Valley in Western Australia. That at least has enabled us to get control of this issue. However, now that the amnesty has expired, we will continue the policing of illegally imported vines with a great deal more enthusiasm.

The dangers about which the honourable senator has asked I have spelt out. They are basically dangers to the Australian grape crop, in whatever form that crop appears-as table grapes, wine grapes or dried fruits-and the danger of communicable diseases of exotic pests for which there is no defence mechanism in Australia. The honourable senator also asked what the penalties are. Under the Quarantine Act there is a maximum penalty of $50,000 and/or 10 years gaol and the ultimate forfeiture to the Crown of illegally imported materials.

I might say as a response to those growers who have turned in vines that we are in the process of having those vines removed and subsequent possible breaches that do not relate to the growers but may relate to other people, such as falsifying brands at the point of importation, breaches of the Export Control Act, or breaches of the Quarantine Act, will be referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions.

—Order! There is no point of order. It is not up to me to determine whether a Minister's answer is correct.

—Senator Messner mentioned $56 in his question. If Senator Chaney wants to argue about that, he had better take it up with Senator Messner, not with me. He is repeating the innumerate rubbish that has been pouring out of the mouth of the Liberal Party shadow Treasurer. If average earners had lost $56 a week and if that sort of adjustment were spread proportionately among taxpayers with above and below average weekly earnings, as Mr Peacock has undertaken to do implicitly, what do honourable senators think that would cost-$5 billion or $10 billion? —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer to media reports of Victorian Liberal promises of cuts to payroll tax and land tax and other measures. Can the Minister assure the Senate that, in the unlikely event of the Liberals winning next Saturday's poll, the Commonwealth will not underwrite, by grant moneys, any financial irresponsibility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give the assurance sought, and that is that the Commonwealth will not underwrite fiscal irresponsibility by a highly unlikely State Liberal government in Victoria, or indeed by any other State government. As the question suggests, the Victorian Opposition Leader has been making a lot of very expensive promises on both the outlays and the revenue sides of the State Budget. ANSWER.PARA: On the spending side, he has made commitments in health, which would cost $130m; education, which would cost $83m; housing, which would cost $75m; and police, which would cost $70m. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. The Minister should be aware that for the second time in just over three months Australia, and especially Western Australia, has been subject to blockade by heavy road transport. Firstly, has the Minister ascertained the reason for the latest blockade in Western Australia? Secondly, does he yet accept that the new registration fees implemented on 1 July were too severe and were applied too quickly? Thirdly, what does the Minister intend to do to keep the free flow of goods into and out of Perth in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any specific information on the situation in Western Australia or the current claims, extravagant or otherwise, being made by some in the trucking industry who continue to be unwilling to make their fair contribution to road damage on a national basis in the same way as is done by their counterparts elsewhere. Disputation does still continue, of course, but most people are prepared to knuckle down and accept the responsibilities that go with being major road users. The situation generally in relation to the matters that have been the subject of dispute is as follows: the Federal Government did negotiate-as will be recalled-a quick end to the truck blockade in July that was started by interstate operators to highlight pressures facing some sectors of the industry. The main problem was not Federal charges, which compare favourably in every jurisdiction with State charges. Rather, it has been the decline in real freight rates caused by overcapacity in the industry. The Government will not regulate freight rates or entry into the industry but we have moved to improve operating conditions through more simple and uniform regulations.

ANSWER.PARA: Federal and State Ministers for transport met on 16 September, as was previously foreshadowed, to consider issues raised during this blockade. They agreed on the following measures: first, that road vehicle technical regulations, including 42.5 tonne mass limits, will be nationally uniform for the first time in Australia's history. Secondly, a uniform points demerit system for all categories of drivers in all States will be finalised and implemented in March 1989, with uniform driver licensing arrangements being considered by Ministers in March 1989. Thirdly, vehicle permits will be eliminated where possible and States and Territories will provide one stop shopping where possible for the range of services required by truck operators. Finally, Federal registration charges, which are the nub of Senator Panizza's question, will be frozen at their present levels until January 1990.

The Government regards these reforms as really quite historic in improving the operating environment for industry. We have done more than any other government to increase stability and professionalism in the industry. Further blockades of the kind we are seeing desultory examples of around the country at the moment will simply set the industry's image back decades and make further reform much more difficult to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to recent reports alleging Iraqi use of chemical weapons against Kurdish rebels in that country. TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources to recent media statements concerning the joint exploration agreement between Australia and Indonesia in the Timor Sea. Can the Minister indicate the current status of this agreement and its implications for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question could have easily been directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.
—It is all yours.

—I thank the Minister. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is the senior Minister in respect of the Timor Gap issue. In any case, it is appropriate to pay tribute to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Minister for Finance because they were formerly Ministers for resources and energy and this issue was their concern. The present state of the understanding between Australia and Indonesia is that officers of both the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the resources section of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy have met their opposite numbers in Jakarta and have reached an understanding as to how the area in dispute between Australia and Indonesia can best be developed. The area in dispute relates to the difference between Australia and Indonesia as to where the seabed boundary should be drawn between our two countries. From the Australian point of view we regard the seabed boundary as properly to be drawn along the continental shelf. The Indonesian Government takes the view that it is 200 miles from Timor. There is an overlap between both positions. The issue is how to resolve this disputed territory.

ANSWER.PARA: We have reached a tentative agreement at officer level which reflects an understanding that we divide that disputed territory into three zones. Zone A would be the area for which both Indonesia and Australia would work out a common set of provisions to govern how prospecting would be carried out and, if prospecting is rewarded by finds, how production would be carried out; what the taxation regime would be; what the legal obligations and impediments would be; and what rule of law would prevail.

In Zone B, which is the Australian end of the disputed area, the Australian provisions would apply and 16 per cent of our resource rent tax would be payable to Indonesia. In Zone C, the Indonesian end of the disputed territory, Indonesian provisions would apply. We would obtain a 10 per cent return from the Indonesian taxing system, which is based on profits.

The question from Senator Beahan was: where is all that up to? It is up to a position in which, I understand, very shortly the Indonesian and Australian departments are to meet to address the question of how the Zone A terms are to be worked out. At the present time my Department is carrying out an investigation of what the existing titles or claims were by Australian-based companies to blocks or acreage in Zone A.

There is a considerable amount of interest in Zone A because at the edge of the continental shelf there is a formation known as the kelp structure, which is thought to be highly prospective. I have seen estimates printed, ranging from one billion barrels of oil to seven billion barrels of oil. I think the accurate way of describing it is to say that the kelp structure may contain a huge quantity of oil, it may contain gas, or it may simply contain seawater, but it is regarded as a highly prospective area of acreage. If it were to be successfully prospected and found to contain oil, it would boost our offshore reserves quite considerably.
