TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The partnership for development program is a major element of the information industries strategy. My intent in making this statement is threefold. First, I wish honourable senators to clearly understand the broad economic context within which the information industries strategy was developed; secondly, to relate the partnership for development program to that strategy; and, thirdly, to inform honourable senators of the way in which the program works and of the successful results that are flowing from it. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

It has been a central theme of this Government since coming to office that far reaching changes to our economic structure are necessary if we as a nation are to retain, let alone increase, our living standards into the twenty-first century.

The Australian economy needs to be restructured and positioned so that we diversify our export base and participate more effectively in the fastest growing areas of world trade. It is in the high value-added goods and services area, based on the use of newer generic technologies such as advanced materials, biotechnologies, advanced manufacturing systems, and the information technologies, that the fastest growth is taking place.

Australia's future prosperity depends upon improving our international competitiveness and moving to an outward orientation for our industries. As a small, high income country we need to be highly flexible and adaptable, and to use the new technologies both to improve the competitiveness of our existing industries and to create new opportunities.

We have, accordingly, taken a number of far-reaching steps to internationalise the Australian economy and better integrate our industries with the world economy, to revitalise and restructure our manufacturing and traded services industries, and to create an environment which is favourable to innovation and entrepreneurship.
Over the last five years we have, for example:
floated the exchange rate, deregulated the financial sector and freed up foreign investment controls;
reduced barrier protection and reformed and reduced corporate taxation;

tackled the fundamentals of creating sustained competitive advantage by increasing the private sector contribution to research and development, and by improving management, labour skills, work practices, quality, marketing and strategic business planning;
sought to improve our education and training systems and link our research infrastructure in the Universities, and publicly funded laboratories such as the CSIRO, more closely with industry;
identified and removed impediments to competitiveness such as unnecessary areas of business regulation.
Information Industries Strategy Background
It was against this background that the Information Industries Strategy was formulated.
The information technologies are of pivotal importance for the future development of not only the Australian, but also the world economy.
They are fuelling new products and services making the information industries the fastest growing area of many advanced economies.
These technologies are also providing the means by which other industries are improving their competitiveness and developing new services and products for sale in markets around the world.
The market for information products and services is growing rapidly:
it presently accounts for 19 per cent of world trade;
and the OECD estimates it is growing at 14 per cent per annum, compared to overall world trade growth of 6 per cent per annum in recent years, and will reach some $US1,300 billion by 1995.
It is a global industry characterised by rapid technological progress, high levels of international trade and technology flows and dominated by firms that are internationally oriented.

This combination of rapid growth and wide application of information technology is providing major opportunities for the development of `state of the art' specialised products. Australia, with its strong information technology research base, technical skills and traditional innovative flair, should be well placed to exploit the opportunities. It has already established its credentials by developing world standard products in a number of fields, particularly communications and software applications. The task ahead is to duplicate and build upon these competitive advantages and to position ourselves to take a global approach to exploiting markets for goods and services during the short product cycle times which characterise these industries.

For Australia to take full advantage of the global opportunities-and to do it on an on-going, self-sustaining basis-will require a fundamental shift in the orientation of our indigenous industry. Instead of the preoccupation with limited domestic opportunities, Australian firms need to:
work to achieve the stringent quality, design, delivery and price requirements demanded by the global marketplace;
form strategic alliances with overseas organisations which give cost effective access to complementary skills in areas of product development and marketing;
become part of the international supply network whereby they focus upon a specialised set of products and services directed at particular markets;
experience the dynamic benefits from vigorous competition on international markets.
In short, our industries will be most successful if they become truly international in outlook. The timeframe available for this transformation is strictly limited.

The need for change in the orientation of our information industries is demonstrated by our trading performance in this sector. Despite the rapid growth of world information technology markets, Australia has not made the most of the considerable opportunities available. OECD statistics for 1985, covering all information, computer and communications products, show Australia having an export-import performance ahead of only Turkey and Iceland.

While there has been some growth in our exports since then, Australia currently has a trade deficit in this sector of just under $4,000m, and on present trends this trade gap could approach $10,000m by the early 1990s.
Clearly there is a major challenge before us to achieve a healthier trade balance in the information industries sector.
The Information Industries Strategy
The Information Industries Strategy, which I announced last September, was a product of 18 months extensive consultation with interested parties.
The Strategy seeks to address the challenges I have described through joint action by the industries and Government.

The Government sees its role as providing a positive operating environment which encourages these industries to maximise their potential. The Strategy also seeks to stimulate greater awareness by decision makers about the valuable market opportunities to be found abroad-that is, an expansion of their focus from the domestic to the international market.

The industries themselves are confident of their own capabilities and recognise the opportunities to be gained from a more global focus to their activities. During the consultation process from which the Strategy developed, industry reached a conservative estimate that it had the potential to treble in size by 1996, and to become one of Australia's largest employment and export sectors. They forecast exports of hardware equipment, for example, increasing tenfold to $1,500m per annum by 1995.

The Government does not intend to direct industry resources to any particular activities within the information industries sector. Rather, it considers that resource allocation questions are generally best left for determination by market forces. The industry also believes that, for it to realise its competitive potential, Government action to build the necessary basic infrastructure is critical for success.

The Strategy is a long term integrated development package with specific goals. It formulates a range of initiatives designed to encourage our information industries to raise their competitiveness and develop their full potential by linking into world markets and expanding capacity to develop new products and services.

The Government's role is to ensure that, where possible, impediments to industry growth are removed or reduced, thus allowing the potential of these industries to be fully realised. To this end the Strategy combines initiatives which concentrate on developing the potential of the information industries through action in three key areas:
product research and development;
enhanced international integration and increased exports;
a supportive industry infrastructure, including education and skills formation and a more liberal operational environment.

A strategic planning function to ensure the effectiveness of the Strategy has been provided for through the establishment of the Information Industries Board which is made up predominantly of people from the private sector actively involved in the industries.
The Partnership for Development Program
The role of the Partnership for Development program in this Strategy is a central one.
It is a fact that transnational corporations dominate both the world and Australian markets in most of the information industries.

The Partnership program harnesses the resources of these corporations to make a substantial contribution to achieving the goals of the Information Industries Strategy. It aims to provide a solid basis for the future growth of these industries and contribute substantially to their internationalisation.

The thrust of the Partnership program is to encourage transnationals to deepen their roots in Australia; that is, for their Australian activities to become an integral and important part of corporate global operations and growth strategy. Through the Partnership program, we encourage the transnational to develop, on sound commercial grounds, Australian activities that play a significant role in its global R&D program and contribute new and innovative products suitable for global marketing. These activities may be owned by the Partner, or be a joint venture with Australian owned companies or organisations.

Under the program, transnational corporations are encouraged to explore the opportunities available in this country and to actively seek out and work with Australian firms in the information industries. The demand of Partners for local R&D and for a wide range of exportable products, from components to finished goods and services, will stimulate industry infrastructure development and open new opportunities for Australian firms.
These objectives are inherent also in the Australian Civil Offsets Program, from which the Partnership program evolved.

The desire by Government to encourage the establishment and development of commercially viable activities in this country is reflected in the evolution of the Offsets Program over recent years from a simple contract by contract approach to the Pre- qualified Offsets Supplier arrangements that were introduced in March 1986. These latter arrangements allow the overseas supplier the flexibility to adopt a medium to long term approach to discharging offsets obligations without the need to enter into individual offsets arrangements against each sale to Commonwealth or State purchasing authorities.

It became clear, however, that a more strategic approach would be more effective in seeking to achieve the specific objectives of the Information Industries Strategy and this rationale has given rise to the Partnerships for Development program.

The development of the information industries in Australia was seen to be dependent on both building up healthy indigenous firms and on working with transnationals to form product development and marketing links into world markets. While the Offsets Program was consistent with the thrust of the Information Industries Strategy, and industry policy generally, it did not enable Australia to establish broader relationships with transnationals in the information industries regarding their overall investment plans.

Transnationals typically see offsets as obligations imposed upon them in order for them to participate in the Government market. The Partnership program, on the other hand, establishes an environment which encourages the transnationals to realise that there are worthwhile opportunities to be found in Australia of commercial benefit both to themselves and to this country.
Thus we sought to provide a framework within which the transnationals, and their Australian suppliers, could more sensibly and strategically plan to achieve the targets set by the industry itself.
The Partnership for Development program achieves this.
If the transnationals, by entering into a Partnership agreement, commit themselves to achieve the R &D and export targets then they are exempted from the requirements of the Civil Offsets Program.
As long as they remain on track in performance achievement during the life of the agreements then they will continue to be exempted.

When they attain the targets at the end of the agreement, and continue to operate in a manner consistent with the broad principles of the Partnership program, then they will gain permanent exemption from the Offsets Program.

The R & D and export commitments require a serious level of activity to be undertaken by the transnationals. With the achievement of these Partnership undertakings, I am confident that Australia's capabilities in the information technology field will have been more than adequately demonstrated. After that, normal commercial forces should be sufficient to continue the ongoing growth and development of these industries.

Given the often limited appreciation abroad of Australia's capabilities in the information industries sector, these investigations would have been unlikely to occur, or would have occurred over a much longer timeframe, without the existence of the Offsets Program and a willingness to adjust our approach to obtain a healthier relationship with some of the world's best companies.

A real strength of the program is that the work undertaken by the Partner in Australia is based on long term viable activities which make commercial sense for the transnational to undertake in this country as part of its overall global R & D, production and marketing strategies. To ensure the effective integration of Australian activities into the transnationals global operations, the Partnership agreement is signed, not with the Australian subsidiary, but with the overseas corporate head office.

An important point to realise is that, in committing to the Partnership program, each transnational will be undertaking activities in excess of the obligations it would normally have incurred under the civil Offsets Program.

For all these reasons, therefore, it is misleading to regard the Partnership program as simply a `higher order' alternative to meeting offsets obligations. It is, as I have said, much more than this. It is a cornerstone of the Government's Information Industries Strategy, utilising for a period the leverage offered through the Civil Offsets Program to cause serious investigation by such corporations into the establishment and development in Australia of dynamic and internationally competitive activities in these technology intensive industries.
Australia has a host of attributes which make it attractive for transnationals to establish activities here. These include:
its convenient location to Asia-Pacific regional markets;
a stable political and economic environment;
a leading edge and competitive market for information industries products and services;
a well educated work force with an English language base;
world class industries and infrastructure;
world leadership in specialised technologies.

These and other competitive advantages mean that an attractive package can be harnessed to encourage transnationals to establish worthwhile and ongoing activities in Australia, rather than elsewhere in this region.
The Asia-Pacific region is the fastest growing region in the world today and is increasingly attracting the interest of the transnationals.

My discussions over the past year with leading corporate decision makers suggest to me that this success is due in large part to an appreciation by the transnationals of what this Government is endeavouring to achieve through the Strategy and the clear understanding that it involves mutual benefits and mutual obligations.
The transnationals welcome this as a more rational approach than that of some other countries which tend to adopt a more one-sided approach to the development of their high technology industries.

I recognise also that the need by those transnationals to be seen as a `good corporate citizen' is not an irrelevant factor in a sector where the Government is a major customer. But more importantly, the dynamic growth of the Asia-Pacific region has caused transnationals to rethink their long term strategies for the region. Australia, with the inherent strengths and capabilities of its information industries, can compare favourably with other countries of the region as a source of specialised information technology products and services.

This regional approach in itself is indicative of the process of globalisation that is increasingly occurring within the transnationals. This demise of the `not invented here' syndrome, as transnationals compete to maintain market advantages, offers Australian high technology industries opportunities that would not have been conceivable 10 and possibly even five years ago. Accordingly, we all need to re-program our mind-set from the restrictions of the past to the opportunities of the present.
Details of Partnership Agreements
Let me turn now to the details of the Partnership agreements.
The agreements are embodied in formal Memoranda of Understanding, with each party committing to certain undertakings.

These commitments are not lightly undertaken either by myself, as the signatory for the Australian Government or by the senior corporate office holders signing for the transnationals. The status of these agreements and the goodwill generated by becoming a Partner make me confident that the undertakings by the Partners are firmly based. I am fully committed to seeing that the undertakings given by the Government are also achieved.

The transnationals commit to support the aims and objectives of the Information Industries Strategy and to meet the specified R&D and export undertakings through an agreed seven year project schedule.

The Commonwealth Government, in conjunction with the States, undertakes to exempt Partners from the requirements of the Australian Civil Offsets Program and to develop and maintain a supportive economic environment and industry infrastructure.

The agreements are signed, as I mentioned earlier, with the transnational's corporate headquarters, not the Australian subsidiary, to ensure that the agreement has head office support and commitment and is integrated by the corporation into its overall product development and marketing strategy.
Partnership Commitments

Consistent with the thrust of the Information Industries Strategy itself, the commitments entered into by a transnational under a Partnership agreement focus on the three key areas of product development, internationalisation and export, and industry infrastructure development.
A transnational corporation signing a Partnership agreement commits to achieve, within seven years:
expenditure on R&D activities in Australia equivalent to 5% of its local turnover annually;
annual exports of goods or services equivalent to 50% of the Partner's imports into Australia;
an average across all exports by the seventh year of 70% local value-added content.

For software companies, and in other situations where appropriate, the 50% export-import ratio is replaced by a commitment to achieve exports equivalent to 20 per cent of the corporation's Australian turnover. Again the 70% local value added criterion applies.

The level of the product research and development commitment is derived from the fact that, on a global basis, these corporations tend to commit about 10% of turnover to R&D. In Australia, however, often very little is spent in this area. The 5% of turnover R&D requirement therefore represents a substantial improvement. This level of R&D also amounts to significant expenditure by the transnational, requiring serious consideration in terms of the transnational's overall R&D strategy.

The commitment is also pitched at a level which will show whether Australia has the capability to undertake significant R&D activities. But it is not pitched so high as to be considered unrealistic, nor place excessive demands on scarce local R&D resources. In other words the commitment presents a challenge to both the Partners and to Australia, but one that is not insurmountable given goodwill and effort all round.

The export commitments were chosen after reviewing the performance of the information industries in similar OECD countries. The target ratios were selected to provide a significant and progressive increase in the level of exports from these industries-but again pitched at levels which are both realistic and achievable.

The Australian value-added requirement acts, not only to ensure that simple re-export activities are not sufficient to meet the export-import ratio, but also to develop progressively the component supply and other core aspects of industry infrastructure development.

By allowing Partners to meet export commitments through facilitating the export of the products of Australian owned firms the internationalisation of our indigenous industry will be markedly assisted.
Developing the Project Schedule

A detailed project schedule aimed at achieving these R&D and export commitments is developed by the potential Partners and discussed with officers of my Department to ensure that it is consistent with the principles and requirements of the Partnership program. This process is assisted by relevant State Government agencies helping to identify local firms and institutions that could benefit by being involved with the Partners.

While the Government is non-directive about the type of activities to be undertaken by the Partner, it always seeks to ensure that the project schedule is consistent with, and contributes meaningfully to, the global marketing and R&D strategies of the trans- national. In this way the Australian activities are effectively linked into the transnational's global operations.
The Government also looks to the project schedule to include collaborative activities with local firms and institutions where this makes commercial sense.

In committing to Partnership there needs to be confidence on both sides that the R&D and export commitments will be achieved. It is unrealistic to expect them to be achieved overnight. Many Partners are starting from a low base and need time to develop their activities in this country.

The program allows each Partner seven years to meet the R&D and export commitments and the Government wants to see steady progress each year towards the year seven targets. However, some flexibility is necessary as each Partner is commencing from a different start point in terms of resources and levels of activity in this country. It would not be reasonable for the project schedule to nominate inflexible annual R&D and export targets applicable to all Partners.

The progressive annual targets are established by the transnational and reflect what it believes it can realistically achieve to that point as it moves towards the fixed year seven R&D and export commitments. My Department, in reviewing the proposed project schedule, seeks to ensure that the rate of progress is commensurate with that of other Partners with similar levels of resources and activity in this country.

The question of possible corruption or abuse of discretion by officials is irrelevant in the Partnership context. It needs to be understood that the Partnership program is a framework for the Government and the private sector (involving both indigenous and foreign-owned firms) to work co-operatively to achieve the goals of the Information Industries Strategy. The Administration of Partnerships is on a broad focus and as such is quite different from the specific processes of the Government Purchasing arrangements which are administered quite separately by the traditional Purchasing Authorities.
Review and Audit of Performance

To ensure that satisfactory progress is being made towards achieving the R&D and export commitments, a review is undertaken with each of the Partners each year. The review audits their performance in meeting the current year R&D and export targets and examines and sets in more detail the anticipated future project schedule activities.

The agreements require that Partners maintain sufficient records of R&D, export and import activities to permit the annual auditing of such activities by representatives of the Commonwealth nominated for this purpose. Sales to Government also need to be recorded by the Partner to enable the offsets position of the transnational to be established should the agreement be terminated.
The intention is that the nominated representatives of the Commonwealth be the usual independent company auditors of each of the Partners.

The auditors would be required to verify the Partner's annual Australian turnover and imports for the period under review. In addition the claimed achievements in respect of R&D and exports would be subject to the audit process. Verification will be sought for each R&D and export activity claimed, whether in-house or undertaken in collaboration with third parties. Claimed sales to Government will also be checked.

Part of the review and audit process will be the assessment of progress towards achieving the 50% export/import commitment and the 70% value-added local content requirement. Local value-added is considered to represent the value which has been added to imported materials, components and services by the processes of production undertaken in Australia.

I am confident that potential for abuse in this area will be minimised by the operation of the annual review and audit provisions. Also the relationship of turnover to R&D, and imports to exports will also act to minimise creative accounting and other activities which are contrary to the spirit of the program.

For example, if in the early years of the operation of the agreement a Partner increased imports substantially above levels forecast in the project schedule (resulting in significantly increased turnover), then the Government would wish to discuss what plans the Partner had to expand R&D and export activities to ensure a continued steady progression to the achievement of the year seven R&D and export commitments.

The Commonwealth also proposes to undertake on a random basis, and where circumstances indicate it would be desirable to do so, its own independent verification of activities particularly in the area of collaborative arrangements with third parties.

If the annual review reveals that the Partner has not met its foreshadowed annual target, and the shortfall cannot be adequately justified, provision exists for the Commonwealth to allow the Partner a specified period to rectify the situation prior to any move to terminate the agreement.
Termination of Agreements
If a Partner fails to perform adequately, the agreement can be terminated by the Government.
With such termination:
the transnational loses its Partnership status and the benefits arising therefrom;
and returns to standard offsets arrangements.

The offsets balance applying at the time of signing the Partnership agreement is adjusted to take into account, on the one hand, subsequent sales to State and Commonwealth Governments up until the date of termination and, on the other, export and R&D achievements under the Partnership work program.

A further sanction arising from such termination would be the adverse impact on the corporate image of a transnational that had not lived up to its side of the balance of obligations which form the basis for the Partnership agreements.

Entering a Partnership agreement is a serious long term commitment by a transnational corporation. I would not expect that the Commonwealth would need to exercise its right of termination, but that right does exist, and would be applied if necessary against a defaulting corporation.
There is also provision in the agreements for Partners to withdraw from the program if the Government has not lived up to its side of the agreement.
Government Undertakings

The principal concession of the Partnership program is that Partners are exempted from the requirements of the Australian Civil Offsets Program introduced on 1 March 1988. This exemption applies to all civil procurement by the Commonwealth, and procurement of information technology goods and services by State and Territory Governments participating in the Civil Offsets Program.
However, the Government also undertakes to address issues which are particularly important to individual transnationals. The undertakings tend to cover:
publicising the Partnership program and its participants;
encouraging an adequate supply of skilled labour and professionals;
establishing uniform offsets arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States through the Australian Civil Offsets Agreement;
taking steps to improve the performance and capabilities of local industry supplying components and products to international standards;
continuing the 150% R&D taxation concession scheme until 1991 and the GIR & D scheme to at least 1990.
Just as the Partners' performance is reviewed annually, so too is that of the Commonwealth in meeting its obligations.
The Commonwealth has made a good start in meeting its undertakings. For example:
an Information Industries Education and Training Foundation has been established to encourage an adequate supply of skilled people to meet current and future needs;
950 extra tertiary places were established for 1988 in computer science and more than 100 in electronic engineering;

my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (the Hon. J. S. Dawkins, MP), in his recent policy statement on higher education, stated that the Government will continue to give a high priority in the 1989-91 triennium to fields of study relevant to the development of these industries;
a `fast track' immigration scheme for needed skilled personnel was implemented for Partners in June;
on 1 March 1988 uniform civil offsets arrangements were introduced by Commonwealth, State and Territory governments under the Australian Civil Offsets Agreement;
a Vendor Qualification Scheme was announced in July, designed to accelerate the development of a vendor base of local companies capable of supplying world class components and products;
information/communication technologies have been established as generic technologies qualifying for support under the Grants for Industry Research and Development (GIRD) Scheme;
the establishment of the Information Industries Board provides an industry based mechanism to investigate relevant emerging issues and to suggest to Government further initiatives where necessary.
Benefits of the Partnership Program
The benefits to accrue to Australia from the Partnership program are considerable and will be broadly based.

The 12 Partners signed in the program's first year expect to increase R&D in Australia from over $55m in 1988 to close to $250m per annum by 1994. This means that between 1988 and 1994 total R&D expenditure by these 12 transnationals will exceed $1,020m.
I remind honourable senators that total R&D expenditure by all Australian businesses in 1986-87 was less than $1,100m.

In the case of exports, the Partners will increase their overseas sales from Australia from about $185m in 1988 to close to $1,100m per annum by 1994. By then about one half of exports will be hardware, a third software and the balance services, such as training, and technical support. Overall, between 1988 and 1994, exports by the 12 will total over $4,000m. Importantly, also, by 1994 these exports will on average have a minimum Australian value-added content of 70%.

The strong emphasis in the Partnership agreements on export, together with the 70% local value-added requirement, will mean that the Partners' activities in Australia will be integral to their global strategies, and that developing their Australian capabilities will be of vital importance to them. Furthermore, the R&D requirement is an investment in the long term future of the industries locally, especially in the export field. Overall, therefore, the Partners will generate considerable demand for high local content products and services, but on the only basis that matters-that it makes commercial sense to do so.

These R&D and export activities will be undertaken both in-house and in collaboration with third parties, principally locally owned firms and research organisations. The involvement of transnationals in the program will act as a critical stimulus to the growth and development of infrastructure, capabilities and capacity in these firms and organisations over the period of the program.

R&D activities will be undertaken in both hardware and software sectors including the development of communications and computer equipment and components, and the development of systems and application software. While much of the R&D will be done in-house for commercial security reasons, Partners are involving Australian firms and institutions in collaborative arrangements, where there is mutual benefit.
Indications of success in these areas are already to hand with emerging areas of specialisation, particularly in the software field, becoming apparent. For example:

Hewlett-Packard expanding its R&D facility, Australian Software Operation, to develop and export fourth generation computer languages. Some 300 professional jobs, mostly in R&D activities, are expected to be created by the company;
Apollo Domain funding third party software R&D, in areas such as image processing and advanced graphic systems with the CSIRO's Division of Information Technology; and
Nixdorf undertaking a joint venture with another transnational and an Australian software house to develop OSI software for worldwide application.

Exports under the program will span hardware, software and services. Partners will be placing a heavy reliance on products sourced under collaborative arrangements with Australian suppliers. By 1994 about 40% of all exports under Partnership agreements will be sourced from local firms. Hardware exports will cover a variety of communications and computer equipment and components including EFTPOS equipment, modems, workstations, personal computers, memory boards, power conditioners and cables. A wide range of software with application in areas such as marketing, finance, tourism, communications and manufacturing will also be exported giving recognition to the considerable Australian expertise that exists in this field.
Two examples of such activities that have already been announced include contracts worth:
$12m to NetComm Australia Pty Ltd from Apple Computer for communications equipment design and development work during 1988-89 destined for the American market;
$5m for software exports and another $5m for manufacturing expansion to Datacraft from its joint venture with the recently signed ICL group.
Challenges and Opportunities
The success of the Partnership program will depend upon how well Australia responds to the challenges and opportunities emerging in a number of key areas.

Some of the challenges are already becoming apparent, such as the need to secure an adequate supply of skilled resources for the requirements of both the Partners and local industry. As I noted earlier, the Government has already taken action to address this issue and has mechanisms in place providing for on-going attention to be given to this matter.

Related to the skills issue is the critical need for the development and improvement of the managerial resources of these industries. Management of local firms will need to be commercially astute in their dealings with the transnationals.

They will need to appreciate and actively seek out the opportunities offered by the expanding horizons beyond Australia and into the global marketplace. For many, the Partnership program will offer a mechanism by which this can be achieved without the same cost burden and risks associated with individual export ventures. Even with marketing assistance and support from the Partners in production, the management of local companies will need to tailor product development, pricing, quality and production strategies to the requirements of these new markets.

With the growing realisation of the importance of the Asian Pacific region as a major market, there is a particular need for Australian firms to build further on the regional acceptance of Australia and the opportunities arising from our location in the region.

There is the very real challenge for indigenous firms wishing to benefit from the program that they be able to demonstrate that they can be world class producers meeting the exacting quality, delivery, price and quantity requirements of the transnationals. This will place heavy demands on the financial and technical, as well as the managerial, resources of the firms concerned, but the rewards for those seeking the opportunities will be well worth it.

These opportunities cover not only the provision of finished products but also the supply of core componentry to assist the Partners in their quest to achieve 70% local value-added in their exports. The demand generated by Partners means that the current Australian components infrastructure will need to expand considerably. However, in developing new capabilities in such areas the driving principles must be that such expansion is commercially viable.

The Government has a clear role here to encourage appropriate infrastructure development, and will be utilising the Partnership and Investment Promotion programs to help achieve this. State governments also have an important role in this regard. My Department is discussing with the partners their critical areas of need, and identifying component supply activities that could be established in Australia on a long term basis. Such developments will benefit not only the Partners but the information industries generally.

The demands on our industry and industry sub-structure through the Partnership program will provide a significant challenge for the financial sector to mobilise the necessary resources necessary to meet the substantial opportunities becoming apparent.
The Partnership program should provide substantial reassurance to investors and lower the image of risk that is often associated with investing in these high technology industries.
The successful coming together of all these factors is critical to ensuring a sound basis for future growth of the information industries.

For such issues to be resolved effectively and in a timely manner will require collaboration and a concerted effort between State and Commonwealth Governments, transnationals, local industries and the finance sector.
This is what the Partnership program is all about-cooperation for mutual advantage.

I am confident that all parties will realise the considerable benefits emanating from this Program and will rise to the challenge of ensuring we make the most of this opportunity to establish Australia as a major force in the Asia-Pacific region in the information industries.

joint development work is to be undertaken with Techway Group, Webster Computer Corporation, Austek Microsystems, CSIRO, Australian Defence Force Academy, Melbourne University, Monash University and Sydney University-

undertake R&D activities both in-house and with third parties;

technology transfer from ICL to Datacraft to facilitate the development by Datacraft of ICL's Network Management software;
international marketing by ICL of Datacraft developed Matrix Switch, modems and graphic based network management software;
the production of PS2 compatible personal computers for the Asia/Pacific Market, and the production of interface boards for ICL terminals worldwide.

Are `partnerships' a snow job?

THE Federal government-dictated formula for announcing its corporate partnerships with multinational computer companies is `snowing' the Australian people with talk of millions of dollars and Australian industry involvement that means almost nothing.

The announcements appear to indicate that Australia's import/export ratio in high-tech products is to be dramatically changed for the better by 1994, that foreign-exchange improvements will be achieved through increased expenditure on research and development in Australia by multinationals and that the indigenous Australian computer industry is going to be much better off through the multinationals being virtually forced to buy from them.
The figures are `rubbery' in the extreme.

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, said at the IBM signing in Sydney (CW, Apr 1, pl) that the total commitment by seven multinationals so far was $A720 million a year in exports by 1994 and $A145 million a year in R&D. IBM's signing had contributed about half of the figures.

The government, which expects to have about 25 corporate partners by the end of this year, many of them software companies, bases those figures on the companies' own individual forecasts of their activities in Australia.

In other words, there are seven different bases for the seven sets of figures issued so far (and about 18 more different ones to come)-not a strong foundation for building genuine expectations on computer industry development, especially as the companies will revise their forecasts according to economic developments.

The announcements have been orchestrated to draw most attention to a handful of agreements between the multinationals and mostly-Australian companies (financial details withheld for `commercial in confidence' reasons) and designed to make it look as if the multinationals are bowing to government pressure to involve the indigenous industry. The IBM announcement mentioned Teknis (Adelaide), Siemens (Melbourne), Aspect (Melbourne) and the University of NSW.

The multinationals have been doing deals with Australian companies for their own corporate reasons for years-IBM said it created much of its $A100 million in 1987 exports from Australia through agreements with `local suppliers'. So what's new?

And what does `local' mean, by the way? Is multi-national Siemens' Australian operation `local'? And what does `much of $A100 million' mean, when IBM admits that more than 40 per cent of it was derived from services.

Further, how rubbery is the $A100 million total, when IBM admits that it imports products, groups them into shipment lots and distributes them to other countries, claiming the grouping of shipment lots as `added value' for export figures.
Canberra editor Colin Brammall examines IBM's entry into the `corporate partnership' scheme.

All of the above should not be taken as suggesting that IBM is doing nothing for Australia. With 4000 people working here, it is contributing healthily to our economy. The point is that the government, not IBM or the other multinationals, is dazzling us with virtually meaningless figures.
The IBM announcement followed a similar pattern as for the other five hardware companies-Apollo-Domain, Honeywell Bull, Hewlett-Packard, Wang, DEC and Cincom.
Button gave figures for exports and R&D-and admitted their rubberiness with the words `commitments based on the anticipated growth rate projected by IBM'-and the head of IBM Brian Finn, agreed.
Neither gave any detail of what the company would be doing to achieve the figures, although Button said that, `IBM's R&D program will mainly focus on software development'.

He referred to the Australian companies doing deals but there were no details of the business benefit to them. Teknis said its printed-circuit board deal with IBM was potentially worth $A13m over five years.

Button said: `Current manufacturing activity at the Wangaratta plant will be extended', allegedly resulting in a tripling of exports from it. Finn said later that the plant's capacity would not be extended-and it could handle the new export products it is currently developing. So what did Button mean?

Button referred to unspecified education, distribution and technical services being exported and to the creation of a special engineering group `to support the development of locally designed products for overseas marketing', by which he means bringing products up to international standards.

However, Finn said that the group would `design specialised products for Australian customers and export markets', a quite different activity. Then he said the group would `transfer technology into Australia and assist in the development of local manufacturing industries'.
The plans are all a trifle confusing and not very informative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask honourable senators to understand that the Government of Australia is entering into partnership agreements with multinational companies around the world. The Government hopes to enter into 25 partnership agreements within the next 12 months or so. But we are not to be provided with details of those partnership agreements. There is to be no legislative base for those partnership agreements. The Government, on behalf of the people of Australia, is to enter into some sort of secret agreements which are not made public. I say to the Minister: that is not right, it should not be, it should not happen. Unfortunately, this scheme does not, in the general press or, indeed, in the Parliament, have the profile of the steel plan, the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) plan or the passenger motor vehicle plan. But let there be no mistake: this scheme is very important, not just because it is being used by the Government for subtle public relations purposes but also because of the large sums of money and government support involved in the scheme. These amounts include access to hundreds of millions of dollars of government contracts and, allegedly, billions of dollars in export earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: A major difference is that the financial aspects of the steel plan, TCF plan and the passenger motor vehicle plan are covered by legislation and the administering monitoring authorities are established by statute and are required to report to Parliament on their activities: not so with the partnership program, which is to have no legislative backing or parliamentary scrutiny but with enormous potential to direct activity and with apparently a high degree of administrative discretion.

I note that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has said in the statement he has incorporated today that the question of abuse of discretion is irrelevant in the partnership context. What an incredible statement for the Minister to be making. I remind honourable senators that in early 1986 the Government announced substantial changes to the offsets program and that in March 1987 the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, in report No. 270, highlighted the potential for abuse in the offsets program. The high degree of administrative discretion in the administration of the program was a cause for concern. This Government has still not responded to the Committee's report No. 270, issued in March 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not game.

—As Senator Watson says, that is because it is not game. There are too many hidden problems. The partnership program appears to derive from continued problems with the administration by Senator Button's Department of the offsets program, and the push for these new arrangements seems to have been well under way only a few months after Senator Button said that the revised offsets scheme of early 1986 was working well. That is what he told us; yet within a very short time we have this new partnership proposal. So, despite the question marks, the Government came up with a modified scheme with apparently even greater administrative discretion and ground rules that are not revealed to the people of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that what the Minister has said today means that there will be no regular Commonwealth scrutiny of these partnership arrangements. In April 1988 Mr W. J. Henderson of the Australian Chamber of Commerce spoke on the realities of the offsets program. This is what he had to say: `But a steady flow of ministerial press releases is all that we have seen about this program'-the snow job I mentioned before.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your word, not his.

—That is right; they are my words. There has been a snow job. Until today all we have seen from this Minister about this program is a series of press releases. I do not know whether he has written them. I guess that they have been written by members of his staff, who seem to know something about the matter. But they keep contradicting one another. Senator Button, when we ask him questions in this chamber, frankly does not know what it is all about. He contradicts his own Press releases. At various times has has tried to distance his partnership scheme, which he calls a child of the offsets program, from the offsets program itself. He wants to distance them, but of course they are related.

SPEECH.PARA: Where are the answers to the questions I put on notice on 2 June 1988 about the offsets program? They were fairly straightforward questions that should have been easily answered if the program was being properly administered and the Government was truly in a position to determine whether the partners had satisfactorily discharged their offsets obligations. What is the situation with regard to Australian manufacturers of this sort of equipment? Australian manufacturers trying to get themselves established and looking for markets in Australia have to compete with multinationals who are being promoted by the Federal Government. The Federal Government is promoting the multinationals, whereas the poor old Australian manufacturer who is trying to compete with the multinationals has to promote himself. How does an Australian manufacturer get out and sell his product when he discovers that the multinationals--

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the list.

—Look at the list that has been printed. It includes Honeywell Bull, Hewlett-Packard, Apollo Computer Equipment, Digital Equipment, Apple Computer, IBM, Wang Laboratories, Cincom Systems, Sun Microsystems, Unisys, Nixdorf Computers and ICL-and there are many more to come, according to Senator Button. How is the Australian manufacturer to compete with those companies when they are able to say, `But we are being promoted by the Australian Government; Mr Hawke and Senator Button think we are great'? What assistance is this Government giving to the poor Australian manufacturer? It is giving him his interest rates, high inflation and a wage accord that he cannot cope with.
—Less money for research.

—And less money for research. Where is this Government assisting Australian manufacturers? Notwithstanding the rhetoric contained in this report, what is this Government doing for Australian manufacturers? It is promoting the multinational manufacturers. I repeat the calls I made in July and August for an independent audit of the offsets program, the administration of which has led to this partnership program. If the Minister fails to carry out such an audit he will fuel the growing suspicion that the truth is being hidden from the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has put before us today a very lengthy statement but very many significant questions remain unanswered. I can give the Senate three such questions unanswered in this statement. What is the exact nature and detail of the Government's commitment to the so-called transnationals? That is what the Minister is calling them. He is not game to call them multinationals; he calls them transnationals. He thinks that somehow or another the people of Australia will be confused by that euphemism. What are the limits to the types of products and services that can count for export credits? Finally, are the partners exempt from the requirements of the Government's preferential purchasing arrangements? These are three significant questions that I have arrived at following my quick perusal of the document before us today. I say to the Minister: this proposal needs some legislative base. Bring the legislation into the Parliament. Let the people of Australia know what the legislation is all about. Then we will be able to debate its merits or its demerits and the people will be able to understand the sorts of deals that the Minister and his Departments are getting up to with multinational companies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleague concerning the statement brought down today by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), which I have literally received in the last 20 minutes. I, too, was most disappointed that the Minister did not choose to read this statement, which takes the debate in the area of partnership for development, and the offsets discussion generally, much further along the track. It is not without surprise to members of this House that the whole contentious nature of this developed practice has come in for much discussion and much criticism within the business world. Part of the problem is due to the fact that the terms of the so-called program are vague, ill-defined and, worse still, almost unenforceable.

SPEECH.PARA: The growth of offsets programs and counter-trade generally in international trade has begun to be looked at seriously by economies more developed than our own in the sense that they are larger and more extensive. In the United States, for instance, there is now a move to curtail many of the offsets programs demanded by Third World countries. The concern I have with regard to this statement relates to much of the language that is used in it. Although I have had the opportunity to look at this document in only a cursory way, I would bring out one or two points. First, the Government says, at the head of page 13, in dealing with the question of Government undertakings:
. . . the Government . . . undertakes to address issues which are particularly important to individual transnationals. The undertakings tend to cover . . .

What on earth does `tend to cover' mean? Either they do cover the dot points that are then listed or they do not. The second of the dot points says that the Government will be `encouraging an adequate supply of skilled labour and professionals'. Yet in the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report dealing with offsets, the Government gives a commitment at page 67 that it is to provide-not `might tend to provide'-a `supportive infrastructure environment', whatever on earth that might be, including ensuring adequate availability of skilled labour.
The report sets out further things that the Government will do in relation to obligations that it undertakes pursuant to partnership for development agreements. It states:
The companies' contributions are acknowledged through a public relations program.

I ask the Minister: By whom is that public relations program to be undertaken; what is the cost of that program; and what is the nature of that program? The statement, which comprises in excess of 20 pages, is, I can only presume-having not had the opportunity of reading it more thoroughly at this stage-reasonably detailed. But, again, page 67 of the IAC report states, in relation to partnership for development agreements:
Objectives and achievements are to be reviewed annually.
What are the criteria and the enforcement provisions for the annual review?

The other particulars that are laid out in the IAC report as to what shall constitute an agreement do at least define when such an agreement will come into operation. It is described as `a mechanism by which companies can choose to become exempt from obligations under the offsets program. To date, partnership agreements have been limited to firms in the information industries'. From the Minister's statement today, it seems that the whole intent behind these agreements is to reinforce the statement that they will be exempted from the requirements of the Australian civil offsets program.
Page 12 of the Minister's statement informs us:
If a Partner fails to perform adequately-
that is, not the Government, but the contracting transnational-
the agreement can be terminated . . .

It does not say that the agreement must be terminated or will be terminated: it uses the word `can'; so it is optional from the Government's point of view. The statement goes on to say that, if such a termination takes place, the transnational loses its partnership status and the benefits arising therefrom, all of which are still in that airy-fairy category of being unsure as to precisely what they are. The statement then says that there will be a return to standard offsets arrangements.

There has been an attempt, as from 1 March 1988, to have more standard tests and criteria relating to offsets programs, but it seems unsatisfactory to say glibly that if a contract or agreement is terminated-again, it is non-specific about who may do the terminating-there will be a return, at the very least, to the standard offset arrangements, because it would not be a great enough penalty for the benefit that would, seemingly, be disposed.
The statement continues:
A further sanction arising from such termination would be-
not `will be' or `must be'; but `would be'-
the adverse impact on the corporate image of a transnational that had not lived up to its side of the balance of obligations which form the basis for the Partnership agreements.

How is that to become known? What mechanisms will the Minister use to make sure that a company attracts the odium which his statement purports to say it will, and how will he avert finding himself in hot water by in some way defaming individuals or causing loss of business to that party? Where are the provisions that cover such things?
Page 12 also states glibly:
There is also provision in the agreements for Partners to withdraw from the program if the Government has not lived up to its side of the agreement.

With the vague and waffly things that the Government is undertaking, as largely set out on page 67 of the IAC report, it would seem that the transnational partner to an agreement will have a very wide field from which, presumably, it can unilaterally break an undertaking into which it has entered with the Government.

As I said earlier, I am disappointed that the Minister did not read his statement because, when statements are read, one can often come to understand whether the Minister was the author of his own statement or whether it was written for him; indeed, whether that was his first reading of it. However, perhaps when we have the opportunity of examining the Senate Estimates we will have a better chance to expand upon the Minister's knowledge of the program and to find some satisfactory answers which certainly are not available from the statement today.

TALK.START.PARA: — I see a general inconsistency between the statement put down by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Government's perceived strategy, particularly its Budget strategy. Nowadays we see very little by way of initiative for business from this Minister. Therefore, it is not surprising that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has seen fit to take away the Industries Assistance Commission from his portfolio. SPEECH.PARA: It is true that Australia's future prosperity depends on improving our international competitiveness and moving to an outward orientation for our industries. That is a central theme which the Minister pushes time and time again. Given that this is the thrust and the focus of his attention and lectures to business and the outside world, I was surprised to learn in Question Time today that he does not seem to be aware that there is a relationship between the exchange rate and the way it is moving and what is happening to the terms of trade, as those factors affect competitiveness. Business journals regularly comment on such movements but, unfortunately, the Minister prefers to ignore the problems Australia is facing. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —About two years ago I realised that the offsets program was running off the rails. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The degree of interest in the offsets program and in the success of the partnership for development program is probably of some surprise to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). It is certainly a pleasure to see that there are so many senators who are concerned about these issues. As has been foreshadowed on my behalf by the Democrat senator from South Australia, I intend to see that this debate is adjourned. I understand that Senator Button wishes to speak to the motion and to deal with a few factual matters. I gather that Senator Button will be seeking to adjourn the debate so that the matter will not go off the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the matter before us by echoing the concern expressed by Senator Austin Lewis on behalf of the Opposition about the fact that we have waited until 27 September 1988 to get a detailed statement-to the extent that this is a detailed statement-on the partnership for development program. The Minister issued a media release on 8 September 1987, more than a year ago. Very substantial arrangements appear to have been made on a quite informal basis from a parliamentary point of view. I congratulate Senator Lewis for raising this matter and for vigorously pursuing the Minister on it for some time and her having obviously shaken this statement from the Minister.

In terms of our examination of the partnership for development program, I do not wish to repeat the many comments made by Opposition senators with whom I am in general agreement but I do want to make a couple of points. The first is that the whole offsets program and this successor program are based on the fact that without some artificial stimulus, without some formal requirement or obligations being placed on the people who are the subject of this program, they simply would not invest in Australia. Therefore, we are trying to use an artificial means to overcome the disadvantages which appear to those potential investors to stand in the way of investment in this country. I think it is very important to keep that basic point in mind. Essentially offsets programs of this sort are aimed, in part at least, to overcome the fact that Australia is simply not providing an adequate investment climate to attract the investment that is being sought without some artificial stimulus or requirement being imposed. I do not think that is the whole story, and I do not base my remarks on it being so, because we are dealing at the moment principally with an area of international trade which is dominated by a number of large international firms-transnationals, multinationals, call them what one will-and it may well be that left alone--

TALK.START.PARA: —`Transnational' is the cult word.

—According to Senator Walsh, Senator Button is using the cult word, and we can leave it at that and I will get on with my comments. We have a situation where, I suppose, it could be argued that without artificial interference from governments in different countries we might get the centralisation of these industries in one or two nations and the whole thing being dealt with on the basis of trade, so the issue is not a simple one.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I think it is important to note the problems which arise with respect to these mechanisms and which have been identified by many people, and I, like Senator Stone, was going to cite the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) as a body which has regularly drawn to the attention of the Government, the Parliament and the people of Australia the fact that there are problems and difficulties involved in using these mechanisms. I shall quote from a number of IAC documents, and firstly from page 83 of the 1986-87 annual report where, in a section which deals with offsets, corporate citizenship or partnership agreements and so on, the IAC makes the following point:
The proposed targets for exports and R and D-research and development-have been based on the achievement of TNCs-
transnational companies; it calls them `TNCs', which I guess is even more cultish-

in other countries. The draft discussion paper suggests that the targets are . . . only difficult to achieve when compared with the history of the relevant Australian industries'. This ignores the possibility that the targets may bear no relation to what is appropriate in the light of Australia's resource endowments.
In the 1987-88 annual report-I think this is the passage that was quoted in debate a few minutes ago by Senator Stone-the IAC said:

While recent changes to the offsets program have narrowed its focus towards exports and technology-intensive activities, the introduction of Partnership for Development Agreements in the information industries has broadened the options for discharging offsets obligation.

I interpolate here that it seems to me that that is a statement of a positive nature which is saying that it has given a wider range of options for dealing with this question of offsets, which I think have been fairly vexed and difficult to administer in an effective way-that is, to ensure that the people entering into obligations carry them out. The IAC then states:
Partnership agreements may reduce the cost to foreign contractors of meeting existing offsets obligations, but have further reduced the transparency of the budgetary and economic costs involved.

It is important to understand that one of the problems-I think this is central to the points that have been made by Senator Lewis-is that we have not got an effective way of scrutinising the costs, as against the apparent benefits, of these agreements. Do they really mean a diversion of resources from more productive investment, for example? That is one element. Then there is the simple element of supervision. The Minister has said that in the past we have been unable adequately to supervise and guarantee the performance obligation. We are dealing here with imperfection. I ask the Minister to focus on the reality that whilst in his statement he refers to the Government having moved to meet its obligations-which, on page 8 of the statement, are described in these terms:

The Commonwealth Government, in conjunction with the States, undertakes to exempt Partners from the requirements of the Australian Civil Offsets Program and to develop and maintain a supportive economic environment and industry infrastructure . . .

Right at the beginning of his statement he talks about things that have been done in the last five years. Some of those things have received the enthusiastic support of the Opposition. I have always been waiting, and I am sure I will wait for the rest of my political life, and certainly for the rest of the Minister's political life, for him to acknowledge that the active cooperation and support of the Opposition in some of these things have indeed made it much easier for the Government to achieve them.
