He talks about reduced barrier protection and reformed and reduced corporate taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He does not mention the increase in corporate taxation when it went from 46c to 49c, or the fringe benefits tax.

—I am greatly assisted by my Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Senator Lewis, because he raises the points that I think are pertinent to this: that one of the things which the Government should acknowledge is that it has yet to produce an internationally competitive tax system which will, all other things being equal, give rise to the possibility of voluntary investment in Australia rather than forced investment. The Minister talks about `tackling the fundamentals of creating sustained competitive advantage by increasing the private sector contribution to research and development, improved management, labour skills, work practices, quality marketing and strategic business planning'. Again, we would say that here is an obvious area of shortfall, that whilst the Government has encouraged some moves in the right direction, which again, in all cases, we have supported, it has, as with the debate on the industrial relations legislation which we are currently undertaking in the Senate, drawn back from making changes which could accelerate that very essential process and indeed could actively impede the process with some of the legislative provisions which it is putting through this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister talks about removing impediments to competitiveness, such as unnecessary areas of business regulation. I think the Minister himself would concede that there remains a vast amount to be done there. I would seriously question whether the totality of new regulation which is proposed in the mass of Bills that we have before us with respect to the corporate sector-the new companies legislation-has seriously been examined with respect to the difficulties that that may cause for the business sector as against the purported advantages that it is delivering.

My concern is that we are dealing here with an artificial stimulus to investment in Australia. We all want investment in Australia, but the reality is that under this Government's administration, when we compare our position with that of our key trading competitors, it remains true that our inflation rate is very high and in many cases is two or more times as high as that of some of those countries that are active in the field of computers, among other things that we are interested in. Our interest rates remain very much higher. The Minister at the table brushed off a question about real interest rates that came from Senator Watson during Question Time. The fact is that our prime rates are 50 per cent higher than those of the United States of America and almost four times those of Japan.

I think there are even more significant discrepancies when we look at some of the differences in real interest rates. Our nominal wage increases are about double. Whilst the Government points, with justifiable pride, at the fact that there have been some reductions of unit labour costs, the sad fact is that those reductions have been achieved substantially because of devaluation. Over recent years one of the problems that have faced people who might invest in Australia is that in a nominal sense, in terms of the dollars that have to be paid out, our wages continue to go up about twice as fast as those in comparable countries. I think that the Government itself must be deeply concerned at the speed with which wage increases are flowing through under the current wages round. It certainly seems to be, both in the view of some leaders in the trade union movement as well as some Government Ministers, much faster than was anticipated at the time of the last Budget.

The final point I would make is that, in terms of our basic capacity to attract investment of the sort which is so vital in our various industries, we have a pretty depressing set of figures on productivity growth. Again, that is probably a pretty multifaceted matter, in the sense that the changing composition of the work force has something to do with the rate at which productivity increases. There would no doubt be some sectors of Australian industry which could point to very substantial productivity improvement over recent years. When we look at the average-we are looking at the average in Australia, as we are looking at the average in the countries with which we are comparing ourselves-we see that our productivity growth is much lower: about half the estimated Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average over the current period. I think that is the period 1988 through to 1990.

The concern which I would like to express, which is in a sense additional to those expressed in the earlier part of the debate-perhaps it was raised in the debate by Senator Stone when he spoke just before me-is that there still remains a really dramatic need to deal with those fundamentals if we are successfully to attract investment outside areas where it is actually required by government as a condition for bringing goods into Australia, which is broadly what we are dealing with here. The Government knows that it will get the cooperation of the Opposition in dealing with those fundamentals. We remain of the view that there is a great deal that could be done more quickly. I indicated earlier that I would seek leave to continue my remarks. However, in light of the fact that Senator Button wishes to speak, I will not do that. I think that the Minister should be chastised for his failure to give the Parliament more detail earlier. This is a very late repentance on his part in response to Senator Lewis's complaints. However, I welcome the fact that we have had an opportunity today, and will have an opportunity later, to look at this important area, which has been a vexed area of policy and in which I think some parliamentary debate is likely to be of great advantage to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel it appropriate that before I adjourn the debate I reply briefly to some of the comments which have been made today. Let me say first of all that this statement on the information industries and, in particular, the partnership for development agreements was distributed at 10.30 this morning to the Opposition. In light of the comments which have been made in the debate today, I will certainly willingly accede to an adjournment-in fact, I will move it-because clearly more time is needed to study the statement which has been brought down. That has certainly been revealed by the contents of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I want to say is that the partnership for development program is an evolving program. Senator Lewis took great pains to cite a report in some journal called the International Trade Reporter of something which I was supposed to have said in September or October last year. There was no partnership for development program at that stage. There were no signatories to the partnership for development program. The Government had not entered into any arrangements finally with any company. What my trip overseas in October was about was to confer with the chief executives of multinational or transnational corporations-whichever one likes to call them-about the possibility of reaching agreement with their particular corporations on their activities in Australia. By and large that has been done.

First of all, let me say that it is not just a matter, as Senator Lewis describes it, of government by press release. Certainly, we have announced each of the partnership agreements. In April this year we published what I would have thought was a fairly clear document about the nature of the partnership for development agreements. It is a public document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you table it in the Senate so that we could have access to it?
—Everybody else has access to it. It is freely available.
—It is not in the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshop.
—Yes, it is.
—It is not. I tried to get it today.

—It was probably sold out. Senator Lewis is perhaps the last person to look for it. In the last Estimates Committee discussion we had something like two hours discussion about these matters. Question Time is available to the Opposition, and it has been since September last year, to ask questions in relation to the partnership for development program. The only time I interjected when Senator Lewis was speaking was-I want him to remember this-to give him an undertaking that I would bring down a statement as soon as possible. I gave him that undertaking 3 1/2 weeks ago. I intended to respect that undertaking. However, Senator Lewis came into the chamber on the last day of the last sittings--
—You also gave that undertaking in November last year.

—I did not give that undertaking in November last year. I said, `at an appropriate time'. I want to make the point, as I said earlier, that this is an evolving development. It is not a clear-cut matter which can be entirely determined in one statement or anything like that.
—You will get it right eventually.

—Yes, we will, which is more than Senator Lewis will do. It is an evolving matter. That is the important point. I gave Senator Lewis an undertaking. On the last day of the last sittings he came in here and moved the suspension of Standing Orders, without telling me beforehand, in order that I could make that statement. However, I wanted to have the statement prepared properly and carefully so that it might be debated intelligently in this chamber. That is why I will be moving the adjournment of the debate in a little while.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to clear up one or two basic confusions. There is an offsets program which has been in existence for many years. It was a creature of a Liberal government of the past. It was in the hands of various Liberal governments. When we came into office there was an enormous backlog in the offsets program. There was an enormous backlog running to billions of dollars because it had not been administered properly. The second thing to be said about it is that in the context of Australian industry in the 1980s, it was no longer relevant because what it was seeking to attract here was employment in manufacturing-employment of whatever level. It used to be called metal bashing. Various companies which used the offsets arrangements sought to attract low technology activity in Australia essentially for the purposes of employment.

The offsets program was changed by the Government in 1986 in order to facilitate technology transfer and higher technology activity in Australia and to be relevant to the contemporary needs of Australian industry. But, the offsets program is different from the partnership for development program. I want to make that quite clear. Senator Lewis, in the course of his remarks, quoted from an article by Colin Brammall in April of this year. Colin Brammall is reported as saying in that article that the figures were rubbery in the extreme. I must say to Senator Lewis that that allegation, although now somewhat old, probably is correct. The figures are fairly rubbery. This program is not about financial commitments of a strict order. It is about the level of exports which various companies will obtain by the year 1994. They have given targets which, I believe, they will endeavour to meet. In the context of many of the agreements, I think some companies will exceed them. The fact that the honourable senator describes them as rubbery is not a matter of any great concern to me. Senator Watson laughs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the point of having them? You cannot even tell us whether you have reached the first lot yet.
—The point of having them is--
—They are just a guide.
—Yes.
—Why have them at all?
—The point of having them is--
—It sounds good.

—If Senator Watson thinks that is all it amounts to, he can go on parroting that expression, but he has to face up to the fact that in this country we could have something like a $10 billion trade deficit in computers and associated equipment by the early 1990s. The problem which has to be addressed is what we as a government and you as an opposition think ought to be done about that. That is what I would like Senator Watson or any person on the Opposition benches to address his mind to.
—What are you doing about the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation?
—Senator Watson interjects about the CSIRO--
—What are you doing about basic research?

—Senator Watson interjects about the CSIRO. Let me make this point to see what his colleagues think about it: for many years the level of public sector funding of research and development in Australia has been 80 per cent of total funding. In Japan 20 per cent of research and development is funded from the public sector and 80 per cent is funded in the private sector. In Europe it is some figure in between. In the United States the figure tends more towards the Japanese figure than the Australian figure. Now, I would have thought that Senator Watson, belonging to the party that he does--
—What a disingenuous example, when it is so much defence based in the United States.

—Senator Puplick can criticise that example if he likes, but I remind him that private sector research and development in Australia was at an abysmal level for many years under Liberal governments, with nothing done about it. It reached the lowest level of any member of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and Senator Puplick was sitting here in government all the time while it happened. I am very pleased and proud to be able to say that there has been a significant increase in private sector investment in research and development in Australia under the present Government, and I trust that Senator Puplick would acknowledge that very significant increase. The point is, Senator Watson, that I would have thought it was desirable in the context of Australian industry to shift some of the public sector research into the private sector, and that is what is happening in respect of the CSIRO. The CSIRO has been given incentives to seek work from the private sector.
—Encourage the private sector.

—The encouragement is there in terms of the tax incentive. I do not want to go on arguing with Senator Watson about the CSIRO. He can ask me questions about that at Question Time if he wants to, but I think he ought to be aware of the facts in relation to research funding in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two other points I wanted to deal with. There was a lot of talk about massive sums of money being involved in all of this. Let me make it clear that the offsets program is one thing. The offsets are in respect of government purchases, which are based on the open tender system. If Senator Lewis wants to attack the tender system, that is something else, but that is the way government purchasing contracts are let. The partnership for development program is not in the strict offsets category, because partners are relieved from offset obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. Of course they are. What is it all about? You enter into a secret agreement with them and it takes away their offsets obligation.
—Not at all. They make public commitments.
—Tell us about your public commitments. Tell us what you are going to do about publishing them.
—Senator Lewis was bleating in here about playing the man earlier. If he wants a hand at that, he should try it and see how he gets on.
—I am not talking about playing the man. I am talking about your public commitments on your policy.
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—Senator Watson said that it is no wonder the Prime Minister took the Industries Assistance Commission away from me. It is no wonder the Opposition took Senator Lewis's job away from him last week.
—They wanted to give him some real competition.

—That is right. But when one talks about large sums of money being involved, they are large sums of money, as the senator said, in terms of export commitments and research and development commitments, and those are the matters with are the subject of the agreements themselves. So the first question relates to the matter of money.

SPEECH.PARA: The second question which emerged in some Opposition senators' speeches related to how Australian manufacturers compete with the multinationals that this Government is favouring. In the real world in which we live, in many areas of activity Australian companies will not compete and cannot compete with the transnational corporations involved in the information industries. But under the partnership for development programs some 40 per cent of export commitments will be exports by local Australian companies working in association with transnational corporations. Some $400m in the life of the partnership program will be exports by local companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they could be minerals.
—No.
—Yes, they could be. They could be anything. That is all set out in that document that you suddenly produced today that we have not seen before.

—They could not be minerals. Each partnership program is negotiated and some 20-odd local companies have been involved already. I am surprised that Senator Lewis comes in here alleging bad faith on the part of transnational companies, which is what he did.
—I am not alleging bad faith on the part of transnationals. I am alleging bad faith on your part.

—Yes, he did. The honourable senator alleged bad faith on the part of transnational companies. He alleged that their activities would be detrimental to local companies. In fact, exactly the obverse is happening. That is why I want the honourable senator to go away and read the statement carefully. I suggest that, rather than pick one piece out of the massive computer press, he should cull it a little bit further on behalf of Australian companies in the computer and information industries to see what they say about the partnership for development program. It was a very selective quotation, if I might say so, in the course of the remarks of Senator Lewis. Of course there is no industry assistance provided for the computer industry in Australia, other than generally available assistance measures and bounty in certain circumstances provided to Australian companies. They do have to compete, but they can only compete in particular areas of activity.
—Meanwhile, you are publicising their opposition.

—Yes, that is a very good thing, I think. To double the size of their opposition in Australia is a very good thing. If Senator Lewis thinks it is a bad thing, he ought to say so publicly, because what it involves is companies of international sophistication doing research and development and exporting from Australia and helping to create the critical mass base in technology which we need in this country.
—At their own cost-their own associated companies-with no safeguards at all.
—Senator Watson was doing this in respect of the textile industry last time. It is exactly the same level of interjection.
—What is to prevent them exporting technology and putting any value they like on it-creative accounting opportunities with no safeguards at all?
—I do not propose to answer every one of Senator Watson's interjections in this place. Let me say that the point about partnerships not being beneficial to local companies is absolute rubbish.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, let me say a little more about the Government's obligations under this proposal. They are, first of all, to improve infrastructure for this industry. Infrastructure in this industry, apart from anything else, means trained people-skilled people. Government commitments and government actions in relation to that matter are spelt out in the statement which has been tabled today. That is the nature of partnership: commitments by overseas corporations-transnationals or multinationals, whatever you like to call them-commitments by Australian companies, and commitments by government in respect of infrastructure. Put together, those commitments help build critical mass in terms of a very important industry for this country. I, on behalf of the Government, very warmly welcome the attitude and participation of a variety of international companies towards the partnership for development program. I believe it to be good for this country. I believe it to be good for Australian industry. I believe it to be good for our current account and for our position in this particular region of the world in terms of a very fast growing industry.

Senator Chaney made one or two remarks which were of a very general nature. I do not criticise him for that because he probably had not read the statement. He made a very good point about an offsets program essentially being based on a degree of artificial stimulus. The offsets program has been used over a number of years to encourage industries in which Australia has perhaps never had any particular competitive advantage. It is now being used for a different purpose in a very important industry. What Senator Chaney said about the investment incentive effect of offset programs was undoubtedly half right. He asked about the costs, what exemptions there will be, and so on.

He then went on to raise a number of questions about wage rates, productivity growth and matters of that kind. Those issues are all relevant at the margin. Research and development costs in Australia are low by sophisticated international standards. The cost of employing research personnel and personnel in the information industries is, compared with countries which have much more sophisticated industries, relatively low. Particular circumstances apply to those industries which make the activities of multinationals under the partnership for development program competitive in the Australian context, and the Government is committed to working to improve that competitive advantage over time.

I sum up by saying that, as Senator Lewis said, I described the partnership for development program as a child of the offsets program. That is true. It is an offshoot of the offsets program. But it is quite different from the offsets program. If one reads the statement one will see that parties are relieved of offset obligations in undertaking certain commitments to put down roots in this country for the general benefit of the community, the business concerned, and the establishment of some critical mass in terms of technology infrastructure. The obligations are pretty clearly spelt out. These agreements are not detrimental to Australian industry, as was alleged by Senator Lewis. On the Government's side, one does not suspect that multinational companies will act with bad faith in these matters. In fact, there is every sign of them acting in very good faith in the matters in question. The Government will, in turn, honour its obligations under the agreement. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEDICAL EDUCATION AND WORKFORCE INTO THE 21ST CENTURY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is the report of the Doherty Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and Medical Workforce, established in January 1987, which has reported to both the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). The committee was chaired by Professor Ralph Doherty, Pro-Vice Chancellor, Health Sciences, University of Queensland. It is a monumental report running to some 700-odd pages and includes 105 or so recommendations. The Committee considered some 400 submissions. I wish to make a couple of very brief points arising from a preliminary look at the report in detail.

The first point is that there is some considerable degree of uncertainty as to who is now to be responsible for implementing what parts of the report. Indeed, in the fairly feeble eight-paragraph statement put down by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training in conjunction with this report we are told that the Government is currently assessing the report and its recommendations and will be moving quickly to establish its priorities in regard to the recommendations. One has no idea what the Government means by `moving quickly' in that regard. It makes it clear that many of the recommendations are in fact made to bodies other than the Government. There is no indication of any real coordination which is to be put in place to ensure that these recommendations are actually acted upon, if they should be.

In many respects, I suspect, the report is a little too large. It fails to provide a comprehensive and readable document for those who are interested in the public policy aspects of this subject. Unlike the report of the FitzGerald Commission to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, which came down in several volumes, one of which was a distillation-the essence of the report-while the others dealt with more substantive matters, this report is extremely difficult to come to grips with from a public policy point of view.

A couple of things immediately struck me when looking through the report. The first was the confusion and difficulty in dealing with the question of supply and demand. By and large, manpower studies of one sort or another have generally got wrong the great issues of supply and demand in terms of manpower planning and policy. If one looks at the table on page 501 under the heading `Recommended Doctor: Population Ratios by Specialty and Sub-Specialty', one suspects that this will in fact bring about some attempt to plan in an area in which governments have been notoriously bad. On page 512 there are some remarks about the current concern shown in many submissions at the possibility of over-supply of medical practitioners. In many respects, one is reminded of some of the arguments back in the 1960s about the production of geologists and how courses ought to be manipulated to bring about desired results.

There are some quite interesting comments made, two of which I shall highlight particularly. One is the continuing disparity between male and female doctors in levels of income. On page 508 it is indicated that male doctors earn nearly twice the gross annual reported by female doctors. It will be interesting to see what the Government does by way of response to that comment. The second comment, which I find very disturbing, is about the extent to which the Committee deals with what it described as the relative unattractiveness of specialities with limited private practice opportunities-for example, geriatrics. Given all the information which has been forthcoming about the ageing of the Australian population, that is somewhat alarming.

I make the point that this report is fairly thin on dealing with the question of the recognition of overseas professional qualifications, which is a major problem. If one looks at paper 13 on our Notice Paper today, that is, the report of the Council on Overseas Professional Qualifications, one will see that on page 88 considerable disquiet is expressed about the expectations of people who are highly qualified in medical disciplines coming to Australia and being unable to find proper recognition of their qualifications and satisfactory employment in this country. It does not appear that there has been a great deal of stimulated public debate as a result of the Doherty report. It is nevertheless an important contribution to the debate. I look forward with some degree of interest to seeing the way in which the Government responds to its voluminous recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Medical Education and Workforce into the 21st Century report confines itself, properly but very narrowly I think, only to doctoring. When one looks at the composition of the very distinguished committee that compiled this report one sees that, apart from Ms Delys Sargeant, the rest of the committee is made up entirely of professors, teachers and administrators, all from within the practice of medicine. Those of us who are medically trained can see in this report much that relates to our life experiences. The report is quite massive-it is a 700-page report, as my colleague Senator Puplick has said. It is quite difficult to read and quite difficult to analyse. Indeed, at one of the public meetings at which one of the authors, Dr Bernie Amos, spoke, he observed that it would make a very good doorstop-and that it certainly does.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the question is: what will the report contribute in this country in relation to the important subjects that are addressed? The committee of inquiry covered all aspects of this subject. It covered health needs in this country into the next century; it described the undergraduate courses in medicine; it described medical student selection and training, pre-registration training, and advanced training both for general practice and for specialty practice as well as continuing education within the medical work force. The report drew attention to issues-issues such as why it is that more than one-third of the top one per cent of academic performers at year 12 still want to enter medicine as opposed to all other disciplines or forms of training. However, the authors of the report have not written either a readable or an easily used report.

I think that, above all, the report should have outlined a clear definition of needs that we face. The authors should have chanced their arm; they should have said that in their opinion this is where the needs will lie and that this is where the priorities will lie. I have to say that in a number of areas they are very descriptive, saying that they had had, say, 30 submissions, and that this was what a certain submission said and that was what another said. They are very descriptive; they do not really identify where the needs lie, and certainly not sufficiently to satisfy me. They do not sufficiently identify the purposes, goals and aims that are involved. They do not identify sufficiently the outcomes that must be achieved or the changes that they would like to see achieved.
The recommendations are very general indeed. I draw the attention of honourable senators to page 204 of the report, where the authors of the report merely say:
The Committee notes and commends curriculum changes in medical schools which indicate their awareness of the various concerns expressed by community organisations and the practising profession.

The report goes on, but it does not specifically refer to details to enable the Minister for Community Services and Health, or any other person trying to plan from the report, to know exactly what it is that should be done. That is the weakest part of this massive document, which has taken so much work and to which so many distinguished Australians have contributed. It is not a bad report. Even the descriptions and the summary of the various inputs are valid, and the fact that it identifies in a very broad way what some of the problems are will be helpful. But we are looking for clear statements of need, goals, aims, objectives, priorities, outcomes and desirable changes. In that regard, I have to say the report was weak; it is very hard to find those things, and it is harder than it should have been.

It is difficult to know how a committee like this should have proceeded. One can imagine the difficulties which Professor Doherty and his colleagues found in trying to deal with the matter. The failure to take clear positions is the most disappointing part of the report. We wanted some clear and succinct statements on needs, goals, outcomes and priorities, but having looked at the report I do not know what the views of the committee are on each of those matters. I know the general directions, but I do not know what the views of the committee are-although I do know what the submissions to the committee set out. A question that is often asked in management is, `So, what will you do?' That is the question that I throw back to the committee; I would say it is a very fine report, but what is it that the committee wants us to do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments on this quite extraordinarily extensive report from the Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and Medical Workforce. I do so from a medical point of view, as this involves the area in which I trained and my specialty, and I suppose that I found much in this report to comfort me-except in so far as I might have raised some of these points myself some many years ago, as I think many of us who have been through medicine have done. However, at least we now find these matters drawn together in this report. I want to highlight a few of the points that I find particularly relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I would like to say that I somewhat disagree with the emphasis given to various matters by my colleagues opposite. I think that the members of the Committee have made it clear, for instance in the area of medical curriculum, that they did not see it as their decision to design curricula but rather that it is for each institution to have the freedom to determine its own curriculum, taking account of the points that were raised by the many people who contributed to the submissions and the input into this report-as apart from the committee members themselves. I believe that it was the intention of the committee to collect as much information and to be as open as possible in presenting it. I will certainly be interested to see what the Government's response is, but I would think that it has here a starting document and some very important, useful, constructive and appropriate data on which to make that beginning appraisal of future medical planning and training in this country.
I want to draw attention to a couple of points. First, I refer to the reference in chapter 9 (v) to procedures for selection of trainees, as follows:

Procedures for selection of trainees should not discriminate against any group and should meet equal employment opportunity guidelines, and that colleges should establish policies and programs that will meet family commitments of trainees so far as is consistent with the maintenance of standards.

I am very heartened to read such words in a report of this sort, knowing as I do how postgraduate medical training in particular, and undergraduate training to a lesser extent, takes the medical experts and the medical specialist trainees away from their families for so much time. In particular, it has been a challenge for those who decide to go on into some specialty after obtaining their undergraduate degree, as those people have to face another 10 years of specialist training and at least four to six years of very extensive, comprehensive postgraduate study. Many of those people have paid a considerable price in terms of time spent away from their family.

As to women who graduate in medicine-and I think Senator Puplick raised the point, en passant, of why women in medicine earned so much less-to name just two reasons, I think the women in medicine earn so much less largely because they are practising medicine for less than full time and very much less in specialties. It is also because at the conclusion of their undergraduate degree they very often make the choice to take some years out of medicine to have and rear a family, at least in the early stages of their children growing up. I am delighted to see referred to in this report the challenge in relation to postgraduate medical training and the matter of family commitments not only for women but also for men who have to make a sacrifice in this regard.

Another area that interests me concerns the number of submissions referring to medical ethics and the importance for medical ethics to be seriously part of both undergraduate and postgraduate medical training. As far as I can ascertain, the committee does not define in the recommendations a clear statement that there shall be medical ethics in each curriculum, but what has been highlighted from the submissions and from an extensive consideration provided in this area is the importance of medical efforts, not only as part of a community debate and as part of proper medical practice but also as part of the question of where our world is to go. The questions of medical ethics are much broader than simply being confined to a school of medicine. They cover the intricacies of the life of every citizen. I think the committee rightly deserves commendation for drawing to the attention of medical manpower planners the importance of medical ethics.

Finally, I refer to the comment about the Flinders Medical School. I have had very close association with that and it is a body of which I would speak very highly. A recommendation is made that any medical school-but in particular the Flinders Medical School-should not be reduced to so small a size as to render it ineffectual. I am very pleased to know that Flinders Medical School does at least get an encouragement to continue, as do all the current medical schools in Australia. I believe that this is an excellent report, and it should be a very useful database for further planning in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and Medical Workforce entitled Australian Medical Education and Workforce into the 21st Century. I hope that the report does not become an extravaganza and a waste of time and taxpayers' money. But I fear very much that that is what will happen. The report is monumental in that it takes up nearly 700 pages.

SPEECH.PARA: Reference has been made to the qualifications of the people who made up the Committee. I would be the first to say that the members are most eminently qualified. One could almost say that they are killing themselves by degrees. But if we look at the people on the Committee, we find that not one of them is a private practising doctor. What shines through is that this is an academic report. As has been mentioned, the report does not get to the bottom line in any areas at all.

With the present shambles in the organisation of medicine in Australia today, with an expanding public sector, the strangling of the private sector and the public sector being more and more restricted, we could call for any number of reports. Reports such as this one or reports slanted every which way could be produced. But they would all be a waste of time and money because if we did get a proper balance between private medicine and public medicine, all of those reports, including the one before us, would become completely redundant.

I would just like to point out the problems that are being experienced in New South Wales, where the authorities are on the verge of closing the Royal Alexandra Hospital in Sydney. So I consider that the kind of recommendations that are in this report are impractical in terms of the development of medicine in Australia.

The report deals with medical education and medical manpower for the future and moving into the next century. I realise that the report is a good report in its way. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are looking at a report entitled Australian Medical Education and Workforce into the 21st Century. Several criticisms have already been made of this quite massive report. One criticism which I think bears emphasis and which has not yet been mentioned concerns recommendation 3 (ii) which states:

SPEECH.PARA: In future reviews of Australia's national health insurance system or its schedule of fees, full and careful consideration be given to the consequences, direct or indirect, that changes may have on the quality and accessibility of services and on the distribution and performance of providers.

We are all aware that the costs of medical care are increasing much faster than that celebrated measure of overall national benefit, the gross national product. One issue which our society has not yet faced, but which it should be facing, is what services should be provided and at what cost to the general public.

While the report does deal, as Senator Crowley has mentioned, with medical ethics, it does not deal with the question of involving medical students in the discussion of the question of what services should be provided at what cost to the public. I suspect that one reason why this is not included is that the people who have put this report together are like me-they are of the older school and these issues were not debated when they were at medical school. But it seems to me that to leave this out of the recommendation is simply to persist with this lack of consideration.

Certainly, the community at large should be involved in considerations of the cost of medical treatment-how much to spend on very expensive programs like heart transplants, artificial kidneys, artificial hearts, in-vitro fertilisation programs and the like. But the medical profession as a whole has a very important role to play. Unless these matters are discussed, and the discussion is started during a medical student's education, I do not think that doctors will be playing their proper role.

The report also makes mention of the salary disparity between doctors who choose to go into academic pursuits and those who remain in general practice. Of course, from time to time this has been a problem not only here but also overseas. There is a difficulty in attracting enough doctors out of clinical practice into academic life. However, the discussion begs the question of whether salaries as such should be addressed as a problem. I think that we as a parliament should certainly be addressing this problem because simply to chase one high salary with another high salary really does not get down to the more fundamental question of the disparity between salaries of academic or clinical medical people vis a vis other people in the community.

The report also suggests two years of pre-registration and this is breaking some new ground. It also, encouragingly, speaks of varied training and says that clinical training of undergraduates and pre-registration trainees should be carried out in a range of facilities including teaching hospitals, general hospitals, general practice, community health centres and so on. This is a very encouraging recommendation. It certainly differs very much from the training which I had, which was very much towards academic-type medicine. We were taught the minutia of very complex diseases which we perhaps very rarely saw in general practice but the treatment of complications of the common cold, which we later had to deal with every day, was left out.

Just briefly, I think the committee which put this report together indicates its own lack of being up with the times when it recommends that medical schools make greater use of computer aided instruction and of computers generally in their day to day activities. I suspect that most students who enter medical school from here on will have a great deal more experience with computers than their tutors or instructors. The fact that the Committee saw fit to make this a recommendation is a reflection on itself.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report sets out the ways in which the Australian Tobacco Board has sought to stabilise and help growers of tobacco. Although I am very much opposed to the activities of the retailers of cigarettes, I have no arguments of principle with tobacco growers, who work within the law, who make use of the subsidies and arrangements which governments provide and who make use of the marketing arrangements provided by the Government for what is in fact a legal addictive drug contained in tobacco. What I am interested in in this report is the information given by the Tobacco Board about consumption trends past and consumption trends likely. On page 3 of the report the Board makes the point:
Taking into account consumption trends, the 1988 national marketing quota-
that is, for green weight tobacco-
was set at 13.5 million kg . . .

This means that that amount of tobacco grown in Australia will be put onto the market to be made into tobacco products for smokers. The report also says that the Commonwealth Secretariat forecasts 1987 global tobacco leaf production to rise by some 7 per cent and identifies some demand depressing influences which are within the hands of government as, among other things, heavier sales and excise taxes. The report also draws attention to some concern about health matters.

I would like to identify for the Senate once again the ridiculous position in which we in Australia find ourselves. On the one hand we see the active promotion of the consumption of certain drugs which we define as legal. In my State of New South Wales, prominent among those is the consumption of beer, which is heavily promoted on television. There is heavy promotion of the consumption of tobacco on every billboard. I say to Senator McKiernan that the decision to smoke is a personal decision with which I do not argue; it is the promotion of addictive and destructive drugs which I find incredible.

We find that the Government, through the Department of Community Services and Health, is involved in funding some minuscule anti-smoking program and, through its social security mechanism, is involved in paying pensions for large numbers of families adversely affected by the use of tobacco. We find that another arm of the Government, the Tobacco Board, operating through the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, is engaged in matters rationalising, promoting and preserving the industry and writes very learnedly about how it wishes to encourage production in the most suitable areas for tobacco growing which are in Senator Macklin's electorate.

Let me make it quite clear that the tobacco growers themselves are merely engaged in a legal activity. I do not have an argument with them. I would like to see them encouraged-I would like to see it made possible for them-to engage in the growth of different crops. I would like to see government involve itself actively in helping the tobacco growers to remain in business but to do it other than by growing tobacco. I would like to see government start to address what is national hypocrisy, whereby we define certain chemicals as illegal and bad and seek to prohibit their use entirely, while certain other chemicals, some of them more addictive-nicotine in particular-are identified as good and legal and are allowed to be promoted for use and consumption throughout this country. It is a fact, as most honourable senators know, that the single greatest preventable health problem in this country is caused by the use of tobacco. The way in which we have such a divided and hypocritical approach to drug use generally and tobacco use in particular is absolutely criminal.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATUTORY INSTRUMENTS (TABLING AND DISALLOWANCE) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Statutory Instruments (Tabling and Disallowance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 amends the tabling and disallowance provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and of the Acts relating to the external Territories. It also makes consequential amendments to certain other Acts that apply the tabling and disallowance provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act to various instruments made under those Acts.

The tabling and disallowance provisions of Part XII of the Acts Interpretation Act provide the means of parliamentary scrutiny and control over delegated legislation. This control is essential to the functioning of parliamentary democracy. The current tendency towards embodying matters of detail in Ministerial instruments makes this scrutiny even more important.

The amendments in this Bill arose out of suggestions by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which, as you know, is the body charged with scrutinising subordinate legislation. The amendments do not extend the existing powers of either House of Parliament to disallow regulations and other subordinate instruments-rather, they are designed to fill 2 possible gaps in the system of parliamentary scrutiny.

Section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act requires regulations to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of the making of the regulations. If regulations are not so tabled they cease to have effect. Either House may by resolution disallow regulations. The disallowance resolution must, by s. 48 (4) of the Act, arise from a motion, notice of which was given within 15 sitting days of the tabling of the regulations. Thus the tabling of regulations allows for their scrutiny by the Parliament and disallowance enables the parliamentary control to which I referred earlier.

As the Act stands at the moment, it may be possible to circumvent this scrutiny by not tabling regulations and remaking the identical regulations on the day after the expiration of the 15 sitting days tabling period. By repeating this process, regulations could be kept in force indefinitely and Parliament would be prevented from exercising its right to examine and, if it felt it necessary, disallow them. Clause 6 of this Bill therefore inserts new section 48A into the Act to prevent the repeated remaking of untabled regulations and instruments and to prevent the repeal and remaking of tabled regulations so soon after tabling as to have similar practical effect.

Parliamentary control of subordinate legislation could be circumvented in another way. If regulations have been tabled and notice of a disallowance motion has been given, it would be possible, as the Act presently stands, to repeal the regulations and immediately remake them. The disallowance motion would of course fall as there would no longer be any regulations to which it could attach. The new regulations would be tabled and the process could be repeated each time notice of a disallowance motion was given. Proposed section 48B of the Bill, also inserted by clause 6, is designed to prevent such repeated repeal and remaking of regulations in respect of which a notice of motion for disallowance is in force.

The Acts governing the A.C.T. and the external Territories require Ordinances made in relation to those Territories to be tabled in the Parliament. Those Acts contain similar disallowance provisions to the Acts Interpretation Act. As it is desirable that these tabling and disallowance provisions follow the Acts Interpretation Act, the Bill makes similar amendments to the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, the Norfolk Island Act 1979, the Christmas Island Act 1958, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955, the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933, the Coral Sea Islands Act 1969, the Australian Antarctic Territory Act 1954 and the Heard Island and McDonald Islands Act 1979. The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 also contains its own tabling and disallowance provisions and similar amendments are being made to it.

The remaining provisions of the Bill make consequential amendments to other provisions in Part XII of the Act. Apart from amending the specific Acts I have just referred to, the Schedule applies new sections 48a and 48b to various instruments to which the existing tabling and disallowance provisions already apply.

I should state that, while proposing these amendments which, as I said earlier, arose out of deliberations of the Senate Committee, the Government is in no way suggesting that the Governor-General in Council is likely to repeal and remake regulations in order to avoid Parliamentary scrutiny. This scenario is one which I feel is most unlikely to occur.

The possibility, even if still unlikely, could, however, arise in the case of the multiplicity of Ministerial and other instruments to which the tabling and disallowance provisions apply. The Government is concerned that the ability of the Parliament to scrutinise the actions of the Executive be maintained, and for this reason is proposing these amendments of the Acts Interpretation Act.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australia Council Act to implement the Government's decisions in response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure Inquiry into Commonwealth Assistance to the Arts. The Report of this Committee, entitled `Patronage, Power and the Muse', is generally known as the McLeay Report after the Chairman, Mr Leo McLeay, MP.

The Government's response to the McLeay Report was tabled in the House of Representatives on 28 May 1987. At that time, the then Minister for the Arts, the Hon. Barry Cohen, MP, outlined the process of wide consultation with the arts community which led to the preparation of the McLeay Report and the development of the Government's response. The Australia Council was involved in the consultation process and conducted its own review of its role, structure and functions at that time.

Many of the McLeay Report's recommendations focused on the Australia Council, the Government's arts funding body. The Government agreed with the McLeay Committee that the Council's administrative structure should be streamlined and that the Council should take account of Government policies at the Commonwealth, State and local government levels. The Government also agreed that community cultural developments should be accorded a higher priority in the Council's activities.
The Australia Council supported these recommendations and has already acted to implement those aspects of the Government's response to the McLeay Report which did not require amendment of its Act.

The provisions of this Bill enable the Australia Council to complete the implementation of those aspects of the Government's response to the McLeay Report which relate to the operation of the Council. The main provisions of the Bill are as follows:

The Act is to be amended to ensure that the Council has regard to Government policies and, where practicable, the policies of State and local Governments as they relate to the arts. The amendments also provide for the Council to have regard to any matters which the Minister may specify in writing. The Minister will have the power to issue directions to the Council but this power will not apply to the Council's ability to make or refuse to make grants. The `arms length' principle of arts funding is to be retained.

The amendments allow representatives of the community interest to be appointed to the Council and its Boards. This will allow the Council to broaden its focus to better reflect the concerns of the consumers of arts programs and the general public. The amendments also remove the requirement for Government representation on the Council and ensure all Board Chairpersons are members of the Council.

Consistent with the need to streamline administration through the amalgamation of Boards and enhance flexibility, provision for the maximum membership has been increased from eight to nine and minimum membership has been reduced from six to five.

Another major change is the establishment of a new coordinating Board which may have a membership of thirteen, including the Chairperson. This new Board will have a large, flexible membership which may comprise the Chairperson and members of the Council, the Chairperson and members of Boards and wide representation from community arts and the broad public interest. The new provisions allow the Minister to establish this Board as a Community Cultural Development Board to further the development of community cultural activities, in line with the Government's response to the McLeay Report.

A Community Cultural Development Board should assist the development of arts practice and access to the arts at the community level. It might also provide incentives for local and State organisations to promote existing cultural facilities and to creatively extend the use of our libraries, museums and art galleries.

These amendments will not require additional funds for implementation. In line with Government policies in general and the Government's response to the McLeay Report, the Council is continuing to give consideration to streamlining its administration.

I am confident the amendments will provide the impetus to carry the Australia Council forward into the next decade with a structure which is responsive to changing needs and priorities and which is in line with prevailing community wishes.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
