DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Today I place before the House legislation to establish a new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission commonly known as ATSIC, a statutory body which represents a radical and timely change in the administration of Aboriginal Affairs in this country.

Today, 21 years after the 1967 Referendum which gave the Commonwealth the power to legislate for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, I present legislation which, for the first time, will ensure the place of the indigenous peoples of this country in the decision making processes of Government.
Before I proceed to the substance of this Bill I would like to recount a story which I believe illustrates very vividly what ATSIC is all about.
It's a story about a meeting, held in February this year, in a dried up creek bed at a place called Wingellina on the borders of Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory.

There were between two and three hundred people at this meeting, many of whom had travelled long distances from some of the most remote areas of this country. It was familiar land to them, it was the land of their ancestors, their home country.
They had gathered together to discuss a new proposal. A proposal which would allow them to have, for the first time, a direct involvement in the decisions which affect their own lives.

In their own language, over three days, they worked through the proposal. The chairman of the meeting, a man named Yami Lester, well known and respected by all who know him, guided the meeting through the details.
The proposal these people were considering was the setting up of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

For the Ngaanyatjarra/Pitjantjatjara people, the new body would mean they would be charged with setting the priorities for their own people in their own regions. It would also mean their own elected representative, one of their own people, would be part of a Commission which would have the power to formulate and implement policies for all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
The people who attended the meeting decided that such a body would be a good idea and they voted unanimously to support it.

That meeting in far away Wingellina, was just one of hundreds of meetings around the country held to discuss this new proposal. The decision taken at that meeting in favour of the new proposal was similar to the overwhelming majority of decisions taken by Aboriginal and Islander communities around the country.

It is therefore with confidence and great pride that I now bring before the House legislation which will give effect to the proposals which have been considered and endorsed by that overwhelming majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

The legislation will establish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, a statutory body amalgamating the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission and incorporating Aboriginal Hostels Limited and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies.
The proposal to establish ATSIC was first announced in a statement I made to the Parliament on 10 December, 1987, called Foundations for the Future.

The philosophy underlying the ATSIC was that it was to be a solid foundation-a foundation that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people could use and build upon in their quest for self-determination and self-management.

In proposing the establishment of ATSIC, the Government recognised and accepted the persistent demands of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this nation to become involved in the decision making processes of Government. ATSIC is an acknowledgment by all of us that it is no longer acceptable for Government to dictate what is best for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; they should decide for themselves what needs to be done.

And that's exactly what will happen when this legislation is enacted. The people from Wingellina, like the people from Melbourne, from Broome and from the Torres Strait, will all begin to have a real say in the running of their own affairs.

In this regard, ATSIC represents a significant and major step towards the achievement of self-determination for the indigenous peoples of Australia. In case there are those who are fearful of the concept of self-determination for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, there is no cause for alarm. Self-determination does not imply separate nationhood or the granting of sovereignty; rather it embodies the ambitions and aspirations of the indigenous communities to play their role in and make their contribution to, the development and advancement of this nation. They seek to do this in a way which is meaningful to them and by way of mechanisms and programs over which they exercise significant control. ATSIC provides a means by which this contribution can be made.

It must be remembered, however, that the Constitutional responsibility for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs is a concurrent one shared between the Commonwealth and the States. Nothing in this legislation detracts from the responsibility of State Governments to make provision for the needs and requirements of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens of those States, particularly in relation to basic services such as water, sewerage and education which all other Australian citizens take for granted.
As I stated earlier, this legislation is the product of a great deal of consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

In January of this year, more than 21,000 copies of my parliamentary statement, Foundations for the Future, and 1,000 copies of a video were distributed to more than 1,000 separate Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and communities throughout Australia.
In the order of 537 preliminary meetings were held involving some 14,500 people to discuss the proposals outlined in Foundations prior to my meetings with communities and organisations.
Between 23 January and 10 March of this year, I personally visited and spoke with some 6000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander representatives at 46 separate meetings.

Subsequently, an options paper was prepared which identified a range of alternative proposals based on suggestions and recommendations received as a consequence of my consultations with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. That paper was widely circulated and was discussed at another 88 meetings involving some 2700 people.
Some people suggested at the time that these consultations were not serious and alleged that Aboriginal and Islander people were unable to understand the ATSIC proposal.

My answer to those people is simple: look at what happened at Wingellina and the many other meetings to which I have referred as well as the response of this Government in making changes to the original proposal as requested by those communities.

This legislation is the product of that comprehensive and might I say, exhaustive consultative process: a process which has no precedent in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. As a consequence, there is nothing of major significance in this legislation that has not already been discussed at length with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, and upon which they have already indicated their general support.
I turn now to the main elements of the Bill.
Preamble

In my statement of 10 December I indicated that it would be fitting, particularly in this our Bicentennial year, for the legislation establishing the Commission to contain a declaration, in the form of a substantial Preamble, which sets down the Australian people's commitment to the recognition and protection of the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and to measures to overcome their disadvantage.

In addition, I made it clear that the Preamble would contain a significant and historic recognition by the Commonwealth Parliament that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Australia were the prior occupiers and original owners of this land. Since making that statement, much has been said and written about the proposal to have the Commonwealth formally recognise what the vast majority of Australians have been prepared to acknowledge for some time as historical fact.

There has been considerable discussion amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups, and between them and the Government, about the wording of the Preamble. In particular I wish to inform the House of consultations which have taken place on recital three of the Preamble and the role of these consultations in the formulation of recital three.

During the consultations some Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups expressed concern about the Government's original formulation of recital three. They feared that it could lead to certain Aboriginal and Islander groups being disadvantaged in current litigation.

The Government's intention has, by contrast, always been that the language of the Preamble would be neutral and have no legal consequences for present or future litigation in relation to land claims. The language was, and is, in no way intended to recognise land rights claimed to exist, to create new rights for land or compensation or to remove or qualify rights under existing law. Nor was it, or is it, intended to restrict any future developments in the law. Accordingly, the Government was prepared to agree to amend the original language of recital three to meet the perception by some groups of a possible negative impact upon current litigation.

I emphasise the neutrality of recital three conscious of the fact that courts can, in certain circumstances, have regard to second reading speeches and other extrinsic material to assist in ascertaining the Parliament's intention with regard to relevant legislation. Recital three, as now written, is intended simply to record the historical fact that up to the present time the Australian courts have not recognised Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander property rights in land except in relation to title granted by Federal, State and Territory Governments.

When endorsed by the Parliament in the name of the Australian people, the Preamble will stand as an historical expression of philosophy and principle. The intention that the Preamble has no legal consequences in no way detracts from its importance as a statement of those facts. I am happy to state that the Preamble has the support not only of the vast majority of the indigenous groups of this nation but also will, I am confident, enjoy the support of the wider community throughout Australia.
The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

The Bill provides for the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The functions of the Commission are set out in the Bill and include the formulation and implementation of programs designed to advance the social, economic and cultural condition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The Commission will also prepare policy proposals to meet national, State and regional needs and priorities of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. In addition, it will have the important role of advising the Government, through the Minister, on the coordination of the activities of other Commonwealth bodies that affect the interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

I want to emphasise that the legislation will ensure that the Commission will not be merely an advisory body. It will exercise significant executive powers and have responsibility for the administration of those programs currently undertaken by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission. Moreover, the Commission will be assisted by, and be responsive to, the Regional Councils established by the legislation, and which are an integral part of ATSIC.

The Commission will comprise a Chairperson and 14 other Commissioners. Twelve of the Commissioners will be elected by Regional Councillors to represent each of twelve zones established around Australia. The remaining two Commissioners and the Chairperson will be appointed by the Minister.
Regional Councils

The linchpin of the new Commission structure will be the establishment of 60 Regional Councils each of which will comprise up to 20 Councillors elected from within their respective regions on the basis of one person, one vote.

As honourable senators will be aware, my original proposal provided for Regional Councils based on existing Regional Office structure of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and would have comprised representatives of each incorporated Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisation in their respective regions. However, as a consequence of my consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, the proposals now embodied in the legislation, involving elected Councils for areas determined by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities themselves, are clearly preferred as being more equitable and appropriate.

Regional Councils provide the means by which people at the grass roots are able to have their views and decisions flow through to the centre of Government in a way which has never been available to them before. It is here, at the Regional Council level, that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this country will start to influence the programs and policies which impact upon their lives. It is here that the success of ATSIC will ultimately be determined.

The creation of the Commission, based on the network of Regional Councils, will ensure a much more effective and responsive administration than has hitherto existed in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. In addition, it provides for the first time since the demise of the National Aboriginal Conference (NAC) for a formal means by which the voice of the indigenous peoples of Australia will be heard at a National level.
Torres Strait Islanders

I know that honourable senators will be aware that Torres Strait Islanders have made clear in recent times their discontent and concern at what they allege to have been the lack of interest shown by governments, both State and Commonwealth, in relation to meeting their needs. While this Government does not wholly accept that criticism, it does recognise that there is a need to focus more clearly upon the needs and priorities of the Torres Strait Islanders.

It is for this reason that the legislation provides for the establishment of a Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board which has as its function advising the Minister, the Commission, and the Torres Strait Regional Council, on matters relating to the furthering of the social, economic and cultural advancement of Torres Strait Islanders. The Advisory Board will be made up of a Chairperson being the Commissioner elected by the Torres Strait Regional Council, and six Torres Strait Islanders living on the mainland. This is intended to take account of the fact that more than three quarters of all Torres Strait Islanders now live on the mainland.

In addition, the legislation provides for the establishment of an Office of Torres Strait Islander Affairs within the Commission. The Office will ensure that attention is given to the development, conduct, and effectiveness of programs aimed at alleviating the disadvantage suffered by Torres Strait Islanders throughout Australia.

Lastly, the Regional Council for the Torres Strait will be given direct access to the Minister at those crucial times when estimates of expenditure are being prepared and approved. This statutorily guaranteed access is not given to other Regional Councils; it is meant to offset the fact that there is likely to be only one Torres Strait Islander on the Commission. This provision fulfils a commitment I gave to Torres Strait Islanders in the Torres Strait with a view to overcoming their concern that they could be disregarded in the Commission's processes for developing estimates and the making of decisions on funding allocations to Regional Council areas.

This combination of provisions will ensure that the Torres Strait Islanders can be confident that their interests, needs, and priorities can be placed before Government without fear of intervention or clouding by bureaucratic or other interests.
Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation

The legislation provides for the establishment of a statutory Corporation, under the control of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, with a broad charter to engage in commercial and financial activities.

The Corporation's capital base will comprise the $20 million which has been allocated to the Capital Fund of the ADC since its establishment plus an additional $40 million to be allocated over this and the next three financial years. As a consequence, the Corporation will have a very significant capital base.

The Board of Directors of the Corporation will comprise a Chairperson, a Deputy Chairperson, and seven other members all of whom will be appointed on a part-time basis by the Minister on the recommendation of the Commission. At least three of the Directors will be members of the Commission.

The Corporation's primary function is to engage in commercial activities in accordance with sound business principles. In performing its functions, the Corporation is required to have regard to various matters which might be summarised as advancing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander economic interests. The Government expects that the Corporation will enhance the opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to begin to break free from the web of dependency and achieve a significant degree of economic independence. It is only when Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are able to take up the challenges of commercial development, and exert influence in the private sector as well as the public sector, that they will be able to participate fully as equals in the nation's economic and political life.
Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

This new body replaces the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies (AIAS), established by an Act of this Parliament in 1964. In large measure, the legislation enables the new Institute to operate very much as the AIAS currently operates, undertaking similar functions, but with a new emphasis on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander control and participation.

The Council of the new Institute will consist of four persons elected by the members of the Institute, one person who is a Torres Strait Islander appointed by the Minister, and four other Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders appointed by the Minister, of who at least three will be Commissioners. The Council will therefore comprise a majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander members, and will determine the policy of the Institute with respect to all matters. There will be a Research Advisory Committee with a majority elected by the membership of the Institute.

Membership of the Institute will be made up of those persons who are now either members, associate or corresponding members of the AIAS, plus such other persons appointed by the Council to be members.

The provisions of this legislation in no way compromise or remove the academic freedom or scholastic excellence which is very much a part of the operation and history of the AIAS and which has led to the Institute being a nationally and internationally recognised focus for study and research related to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs.
Aboriginal Hostels Ltd

The new Commission will not have any major impact upon the operations of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd which, as Honourable Members will be aware, is a highly successful company providing accommodation for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The Board of AHL will, however, be reconstituted to provide for at least 3 of the Directors to be Commissioners of ATSIC. This will ensure that, as a subsidiary of ATSIC, the company will operate in a way consistent with the general policy directions set by the Commission.
Miscellaneous, Consequential and Transitional Provisions

The Bill also provides for a number of miscellaneous matters such as the declaration of certain bodies as Aboriginal Corporations, the remuneration and allowances payable to certain office holders under the legislation, review of certain administrative decisions, the audit of subsidiary companies, and the making of regulations.
There are also a number of consequential amendments to other legislation, and detailed provision for the transitional arrangements in the establishment of the Commission.

Honourable Senators will be interested to hear that the Bill, although quite complex in structure, has been drafted throughout in plain English. I wish to acknowledge the highly professional assistance provided by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel in the drafting of the Bill.
Conclusion
I said at the beginning that this legislation represents the product of a very extensive and exhaustive consultative process.
And that is how it should be.

The establishment of ATSIC will lead to a very significant change in Aboriginal Affairs and in the way the portfolio will be administered in the future. It is important, however, that this change not be looked at in isolation, but as part of a series of changes aimed at bringing about long overdue reforms. These reforms can and should only occur with the proper participation and involvement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The implementation of reform in Aboriginal Affairs depends largely on how Governments, the bureaucracy, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and broader community tackle the challenges that now confront them.

At a Government level it is important to maintain the political will to follow through the changes. The challenge for the bureaucracy is to adapt positively to changes in their roles in a responsive and constructive way. It is equally important that the broader community builds on the understanding and support that currently exists in society to bring about far reaching reform.

Finally, in order to realise the philosophy of self-determination and self-management-demands Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have been talking about since well before the 1967 Referendum-it is crucial that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people take up the challenge and provide the direction for all of us.
I have great pleasure in commending the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Committee last met, which seems a long time ago now-it is about three weeks-I moved amendments Nos 8 and 34. They are being taken together because they are on a related matter. Amendment No. 8 refers to clause 95 of the Industrial Relations Bill. I will take some time to explain this, since it is three weeks since we last discussed it. I will try to pick up the threads of the debate by going through what the amendments actually cover. Probably by the time I have done that, Senator Cook will be here.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government provides, in clause 95 of the Bill:

The Commission is not empowered to include terms in an award, or make an award under section 112 that includes terms, that are based on the terms of a certified agreement unless the Commission is satisfied that including the terms in the award, or making the award, would not:
(a) be inconsistent with principles established by a Full Bench that apply in relation to the determination of wages and conditions of employment; or
(b) otherwise be contrary to the public interest.

What the Government is seeking to do here is to insulate from the wage fixing system generally any separate certified agreement which is made which might cause problems in terms of the principles which a national wage case or some similar case might involve. The Government is trying to insulate the process of having a move towards direct agreements, subject to fairly rigid Industrial Relations Commission control, from, in a sense, polluting the general centralised wage fixing system.

The Opposition is sympathetic to that view because the Opposition's policy would go much further than the Government is going in this Bill with respect to opening up the industrial relations system to agreements. Our broad approach is that the Opposition is advocating a right for employers and employees, where they wish, to enter into agreements determining the conditions of employment and agreeing not to be bound by awards. There is nothing very revolutionary about that any more, Mr Temporary Chairman, because in your State of Queensland the South East Queensland Electricity Board (SEQEB) is operating with a fair degree of freedom to enter into agreements between employer and employee. Indeed, there is an Act of the Queensland Parliament which provides a fair amount of freedom to enter into contractual agreements-voluntary employment agreements-and a number of agreements have been made.

Whether we go down the Government's more limited route or down our route, clearly we do not want a situation in which the old principles of comparative wage justice and so on simply feed any benign agreement-that is, benign from the point of view of the work force-through to the generality of the work force. The whole idea of encouraging agreements because they are a means of achieving greater productivity, enabling an enterprise to lift its performance above the ruck and hence to pay, perhaps, better wages to its employees, becomes counterproductive if the effect of a single success within an enterprise is to create a flow-on into enterprises which have not achieved the same cooperative, productive arrangements between employer and employee. We are not looking at a difference of principle here; we are looking at a difference of degree.
My amendment No. 8 seeks to delete the Government's clause 95, which I read out, and insert, under the heading `Effect of certified agreements', the following:
``95. (1) The Commission is not empowered to include terms in an award, or make an award under section 112 that includes terms, that are based on the terms of a certified agreement.
This amendment uses the first words of the existing clause 95 and removes the `except' exemption-the `unless' part of it. The amendment goes on to say:
``(2) Subject to subsection (3), the Commission shall not have regard to any argument raised before the Commission that is based on any matter included in a certified agreement.''
Again, that is simply an insulating proposition: it ensures that an agreement will not pollute or distort the general centralised wage fixing system. Finally, sub-clause (3) of my amendment states:
``(3) The Commission may, in proceedings relating to a certified agreement, have regard to arguments based on matter included in that agreement.''.
I turn now to amendment No. 34 which deals with offences. Amendment 34 proposes the insertion of a new clause which, under the heading `Offences relating to certified agreements', provides:
``298a. A person shall not, on behalf of an organisation, make a claim to the Commission that is based on matter included in a certified agreement to which that organisation is not a party.

It proposes a penalty, in the case of a natural person, of $500 or, in the case of a body corporate, of $2,500. That simply adds a buttress to the general effect of clause 95 that we are seeking to insert by making it an offence for a person to act in a way which seeks to subvert the provisions of clause 95 as it would be worded. Indeed, I think that the clause would be relevant even if the Government's clause remains, because it would be a useful buttress to what the Government proposes.

The Opposition believes that the Government is proposing an approach to certified agreements which is too limited, which is too narrow and which goes beyond what is required, and indeed to some extent will be counterproductive in terms of the common objective-in the rhetorical sense anyway-which I believe the Government shares with us, of wanting to encourage a more flexible labour market and to encourage a circumstance where employers and employees work together and, where they can see that it would be mutually profitable, to regulate their affairs by agreement. I stress that we are looking at a situation where it would be seen that it would be mutually profitable.

It is interesting to note that in your State, Mr Temporary Chairman, we are getting some experience of direct agreements between employers and employees. In the SEQEB case, the agreements which are being entered into provide not for reduced remuneration for employees who choose to move from the award to the agreement, but for increased remuneration. There is a margin in favour of working under an agreement. The advantage of that from the employer's point of view is that there is a productivity benefit because the agreement involves stepping away from some of the restrictive practices which have existed in the past and which have led to inefficiencies. It is very encouraging, when one looks at this area of the law, to note that in Queensland electricity costs have risen very slowly compared with electricity costs in other States. In other words, I think that we have the combination which the people of Australia would agree is desirable, that is, lower electricity tariffs, a better position for employers in that they are getting their product produced more cheaply, and a situation where employees are getting a higher remuneration.

I do not think that in looking at these clauses one should think that one is dealing with some esoteric points of narrow interest. This is the area where, even if the Government's more restrictive approach is adopted, we are going to see considerable advances. I think economic necessity will impose that upon the industrial relations system. I do not want to keep harking back to Queensland but when we are dealing with this section of the Act I think it is very instructive to do so. Senator Cook, who is now at the table, is probably aware that there has been some very useful trend setting in Queensland with the agreement that was entered into with respect to Sanctuary Cove. Senator Cook can feel very relaxed about that because it was an agreement which was entered into with the Trades and Labour Council, or its equivalent in Queensland, and he was very directly involved. The employers found that by entering into a direct agreement they could come to arrangements which again suited the employers better and which involved the removal of the usual penalty rates arrangements in favour of a loaded hourly rate and this provided more adequately for the requirements of the tourist industry. Since we were last debating this issue there have been further significant advances in the Queensland tourist industry.

There has been a quite substantial additional agreement. I have not seen the detail of that agreement and I am relying on the media reports of it. The reports indicate that a substantial number of resorts have now entered into a similar style of arrangement in Queensland. I stress that this is something which has been done not in some unilateral or high-handed way. It has been done very much by a process of cooperative negotiation involving employers and employees and the employees' representatives-in this case the trade unions.

I return to my amendments by saying that the Government is right to be seeking to insulate the registered agreements from the general flow of award determinations. Clause 95 of the Bill does that but in our view it does not do it in a sufficiently strong way. That is why we are moving to strengthen what the Government is proposing. Further, we are seeking to reinforce that by making it an offence to make a claim based on a matter which includes certified agreement to which the applicant is not a party. Again, the Minister at the table is a Minister with very significant personal experience in the industrial relations field as a secretary of the Trades and Labour Council in Western Australia and as a trade union official in other capacities. If he were able to be frank and realistic in this debate-and we will soon find out whether he is-he would concede that there will inevitably be pressures to bear.

It would be very odd if trade unions saw an opportunity to argue some old tried and tested principles of comparative wage justice flow-on and did not try to grab the ball and run with it. The Minister will assert the strong need for clause 95 in its present form. I ask him, in the interests of trying to produce the best possible industrial relations law for this country, whether he will look at the significant improvements we are suggesting to clause 95 and the buttressing of that clause which we are proposing with respect to new clause 298a and then he might consider taking that back. After all, we have a new Minister now. Mr Peter Morris might not feel quite as popish about the Bill that is before us as Mr Willis apparently felt in his Department and we might actually get some sensible consideration to these amendments rather than the blank wall that we have faced to this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have been enjoined to be frank and realistic about industrial relations. That is an invitation that is not often extended to me but whenever it is it is one which I am pleased to pick up and respond to. One of the hallmarks, as Senator Harradine would know, of people who are engaged in industrial relations, is a penchant for frank and realistic assessment situations, in direct and open speaking. There is not a great deal of difference between the Government and the Opposition on this amendment but as someone once said sometimes a small difference can, in effect, in the end mean a great deal of difference in the outcome. I think it is reasonable to say that what we are both on about is similar. We think that what we are on about is more sensible and realistic concerning how the Commission works and how the industrial relations system functions than what the Opposition is proposing.

SPEECH.PARA: These clauses and amendments are about where agreements fit in between the parties-employers and the unions-when there is a compulsory arbitration system which brings down decisions on awards based on evidence put to it and a consideration of what applies in general industry. The reason why there is some anxiety to get these provisions right is that this is not unrealistic. I have noticed that from time to time agreements are reached between employers and unions which bestow on members of those unions covered by these agreements more beneficial conditions than would be obtainable from the Commission. They are bestowed for whatever particular local reason might apply. It should also be said that the obverse is true where poorly organised, or not organised at all, workers are sometimes drawn into agreements where the conditions that they have purported to accept by way of a certified agreement are conditions which are more onerous than might generally be applied. I can think of examples on both sides of that fence.

I do not think this is a debate in which it can be argued that there is purity on the one side and malice on the other. It is an argument that can be applied realistically in the real world of industrial relations in a way in which sometimes dominant groups take advantage of their position and effect agreements with groups less able to resist. That applies on both sides of the spectrum. The question here is to what extent should a commission have cognisance of the terms of such an agreement. We think that the provisions that we are putting forward are more sensible for the reason that it enables some scope for the Commission to have regard, where it is appropriate to have regard, for provisions reached by negotiation and provisions which figure in certified agreements. For example, there may be occasions in the public interest where it is appropriate that the Commission take such a view. There may be occasions where there is a need to have regard to the wage fixation principles where the Commission should take such a view. Where the appropriateness of those considerations applies it is proper that the Commission do so.

If the amendment were to be carried the Commission would be disbarred from doing what are commonsense things. In fact, it would not only be disbarred but it could become an offence for the Commission to have regard to any of those such matters. If one wanted to follow an argument by reducing it to an absurdity one could easily do so. Things that figure in agreements that are reached which are perfectly sensible and reasonable would be disbarred from being considered by the Commission such as a perfectly sensible grievance procedure which might have been worked out, or where effective safety standards are somehow encoded in an agreement, or if there are worthwhile provisions for eliminating inefficient work practices. I do not think any senator here would argue that those things should not be considered by the Commission. But the amendment would prevent it from being considered, and prevent it from being considered in a way in which there may be an offence created.

The second thing that needs to be said about it is that there appears to be at least a threshold constitutional issue. The amendment appears not to be a limitation on the Commission's jurisdiction, but a constitutionally impermissible interference with how the Commission exercises its powers of conciliation and arbitration. In any case it is one thing to identify a term of an award which appears to be based on a term of a certified agreement, but it would be far more difficult and uncertain to ascertain how and when an argument is based on a matter included in a certified agreement.

I think in the end we have to recognise that the reason why we put on arbitration benches people with extensive experience in the real life of arbitration, to use Senator Chaney's words, with the frank and realistic practice of industrial relations, is so that they can make commonsense views, and if the parties believe those views are not common sense, they can appeal through the structure. But there needs to be some way in which things that are appropriate for consideration can be considered, even from documents such as consent agreements, in the award process. That is not to run away from the point that Senator Chaney validly raises about agreements that might be hammered out in private which might sometimes reflect conditions or provisions which should not under any circumstances flow on. Those sorts of agreements, I think under a former Liberal Minister in this portfolio, Mr Viner, were named as sweetheart agreements. They may be sweetheart agreements, or they may be agreements of another sort; but if the Opposition can accept the views that I have put, I think it will see that there is not here any smart or sharp attempt by us to undermine the force of its position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not accusing you of that.

—I appreciate that, but I am making that emphasis so that I can conclude by making the point that we are trying here to fashion an Act which has the provisions which give the Bench the flexibility in all the circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

SPEECH.PARA: In a sense, these clauses are about movements away from the traditional line of thought. TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Chaney says, the amendment to clause 95 is very reasonable and logical. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will know, this is my first contribution to this debate on the Industrial Relations Bill 1988. Regrettably, I was unwell on the last occasion it was debated. I wish to deal with clause 95. I know that I cannot deal with any other clauses because this is the committee stage of the debate. Let us not forget that clause 95 really relates to awards that are made under section 112 of the Industrial Relations Bill. By definition those awards are called consent awards. Under those circumstances, of course, it is for the employer and the union to consent. What the proposed Industrial Relations Commission must do under the provisions of this clause is to ensure that that consent is not inconsistent with the principles established by the Full Bench that apply in relation to the determination of wages and conditions of employment or are otherwise contrary to the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, if honourable senators have been following the national wage decisions on the last two occasions at least-probably it applies in decisions before those as well-they will have noted how constricted the trade union movement has been in attempting to achieve wage increases for its members. Honourable senators may not realise that about 25 per cent of the work force has not yet received the 4 per cent wage increase and thus has not participated in the two-tier wage system. Now we have a new set of principles which, broadly speaking, are called the structural efficiency principles which tie in the trade union movement very strictly to a series of guidelines. These principles operate, as it were, as a straitjacket. What the provision does here is to tie consent awards to that straitjacket. Honourable senators must realise that this is something that, obviously, many people in the trade union movement would not agree with. It is a decision that has been taken by the Government. I see a similar philosophy behind the Opposition's proposed amendment. However, I point out to the Opposition that I cannot understand quite what is meant by the words:

We are talking about consent awards. In fact, the discussion that takes place before this type of agreement is arrived at would naturally, in some cases, deal with conditions that apply in certified agreements. Is it proposed by the Opposition that any agreement arising out of that discussion could not thereby be included in the new consent award? Is that what is being proposed? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chaney I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 47, after subparagraph 111 (1) (g) (iii), insert the following new paragraph:
``(iiia) that an organisation that is a party to the industrial dispute and that is seeking the making of an award does not have a significant number of members who would be covered by the award;''.

Section 111, like existing section 41 (1) (d), acts as a mechanism whereby the Commission may have before it a valid interstate industrial dispute, but it may refrain from making an award which would override State coverage, if it believes that State jurisdiction is more appropriate. It gives some protection to the Federal-State system against Federal award coverage. Of course, it is the view of the National Party and the Liberal Party that there ought to be a sensible balance in terms of jurisdiction in industrial relations areas and the State jurisdiction ought to be properly provided for and not interfered with when it is the most satisfactory and suitable body to have jurisdiction.

The threat to the State system is that areas of work previously covered by State awards and determined can become the subject of a Federal award coverage by the creation of an interstate industrial dispute. A dispute can be found in the Federal jurisdiction and, subject to this clause, an award for certified agreement can be made in settlement of the dispute and, by virtue of section 109 of the Constitution, the Federal award prevails over any existing State award or determination. An action to obtain a Federal coverage can of course be initiated by a federally registered organisation that has virtually no membership within the State. That body could create an industrial dispute on paper and therefore become able to apply for the Federal award coverage. This, as we know and have seen, can lead to an intrusion of the Federal jurisdiction into State areas which, by any definition and common sense, are better dealt with by State awards, but it might just suit some to seek to have a Federal award, to have Federal jurisdiction.

I make that point to the Minister because I am here bringing forward a matter which certainly has the intellectual assent of the Opposition and it is totally consistent with our view that there should be a decentralised system of industrial relations. It is also the view of a significant number of trade unions that this is the desirable position. Earlier in the debate I referred to the fact that the push for centralisation can at times be related to attempts to quash the very sort of conduct that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce claims that he is seeking to encourage; namely, a greater degree of flexibility at the workplace. After all, we have had clear statements from a number of Ministers that that is a government objective. We had the statement last May from the Treasurer, Mr Keating, that the great challenge facing the Government is to have further deregulation of the labour market and to have the capacity to pay differently in different industries, according to their capacity and so on. They are fine sentiments and they are absolutely correct as they are expressed, but earlier in the Committee debate examples were given of attempts made by people to have more flexible arrangements being overridden, or attempts being made to override them by seeking to bring them within the Federal jurisdiction.

I referred to the challenge to the Sanctuary Cove arrangements and to what were effectively challenges to the voluntary employment agreements entered into under the Queensland State legislation. After the union had fought against those voluntary employment agreements, trade union interests attempted to override the agreements by bringing the employees within a Federal award, thereby overriding the State jurisdiction because of the predominance of the federal constitutional provision where there are co-existing laws. What we are talking about here is clearly within that ballpark of concern that the Opposition has about this Bill. Rather than promoting the sort of flexibility, which the Government talks about and which the Bill is to some limited extent promoting, it contains specific provisions which result in there being tools which can prevent the sort of result that the Government says it is seeking. The amendment that the Opposition is seeking is limited. We are simply seeking to add to the existing clause a new sub-clause in these terms:
that an organisation that is a party to the industrial dispute and that is seeking the making of an award does not have a significant number of members who would be covered by the award.

In other words, what we are saying is that, if there is not a fundamental interest on the part of the person who is seeking the making of an award, surely that should be properly taken into account as a matter which would lead the Commission not to intervene. Surely it is flying in the face of the Government's industrial relations intentions to have a situation where a State union which is operating satisfactorily under a State jurisdiction can be overridden effectively, not by an organisation with a common membership but by an organisation with a nominal membership as far as that State organisation is concerned. There are questions of fairness as well as flexibility involved, and I find it difficult to see why the Government could not entertain an amendment in these terms. Since the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who has the conduct of this legislation, is now at the table, I might say that, now we have a new Minister, I express the hope that we might get a less popish approach to the legislation and less of the attitude that the words written are infallible.

TALK.START.PARA: —A new shadow Minister, too.

—Indeed; if that will alter the equation I for one will be delighted. My plea again is for the Minister to give some rational consideration to this and, given that, in my view, it would contribute to the outcomes the Government claims it wants, to agree to it rather than simply mulishly opposing it because it happens not to be in the Government's draft.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am about to mulishly oppose the amendment because it happens not to be in the Government's draft. More seriously, the Government has considered this matter and it does not regard the Opposition's amendment as in any way necessary. The terminology of the amendment is somewhat unclear. It is specific in one sense and very vague in another. The criterion is the number of members but the description is a significant number of members. That is far from clear. That is not the main reason for opposing the amendment moved by the Opposition. The Opposition has asserted that the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems made a recommendation of this kind. I am not sure whether it was precisely the same. It is the Government's view that the Committee overlooked the provisions of section 41 (1) (d) (iii), which allow the Commission to dismiss matters on the grounds that they are not in the public interest. Indeed, under this provision--
—What is your definition of `public interest' in all of this?
—It is defined, is it not? Perhaps it is not; I do not know.
—I think Lewis Carroll could have defined it.

—There are all sorts of things defined in this legislation which Lewis Carroll could well have had a go at; I concede that. There is a specific discretion vested in the Commission to determine the public interest. Indeed, under section 41 (1) (d) (iii), the Commission has exercised that public interest discretion to dismiss matters in which awards were sought which would affect very few employees.
—It can be done. We want to make sure it is more likely to be done.

—I understand that. That is the difference between us. We say it can be done and, therefore, to that extent the amendment is unnecessary. Of course, subclause 111 (1) (g) also gives the Commission discretionary power in relation to a number of other grounds, such as triviality, better dealt with by a State tribunal, and of course, the one I have mentioned, not in the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to one or two comments that have been made, I draw the Senate's attention to the incidence of awards in Australia and the coverage by Federal awards as against State awards. As at May 1985, 32.6 per cent of employees were covered by Federal awards, 49.8 per cent were covered by State awards, and 15 per cent were not covered by awards, determinations or collective agreements. It could be argued, on the basis of those figures, that section 49 (1) (d) (iii) has not in fact had the effect of undermining the State system. I think this was the burden of one of the specific points made by Senator Crichton-Browne. For those reasons the Government does not accept the amendment moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 111 sets down particular powers that, subject to other provisions of the Industrial Relations Bill, are available to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in proceedings before it. This includes powers such as the ability to make awards or orders, certify agreements, give specific directions to summon parties, witnesses and other persons, and to compel the production of documents. There is also a range of more technical powers that the Commission is given under this clause. We are dealing with subclause 111 (1) (g), which permits the Commission to dismiss a matter or to refrain from hearing a matter if it is trivial; if a State industrial authority is dealing or may deal with it; where further proceedings are not in the public interest; where a party to a dispute is engaging in conduct which the Commission considers to be hindering the settlement of that or any other dispute; or where a party has breached an award or order or has contravened a direction or recommendation of the Commission to stop industrial action.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney's amendment, which was moved by Senator Crichton-Browne, is to insert an additional subparagraph (iiia) after paragraph 111 (1) (g) to include an organisation that is a party to the industrial dispute and is seeking the making of an award but does not have a significant number of members who would be covered by the award. In other words, the Commission would have an additional power to dismiss a matter that has been brought before it. This clause is similar to the existing section 41 (1) (d) in the old Act. It acts as a mechanism whereby the Commission, although it has a valid interstate industrial dispute before it, may refrain from making an award, thus overriding State coverage, if it believes that a State jurisdiction is more appropriate to that particular award. It therefore gives protection to the State industrial relations systems against Federal award coverage interfering with State industrial jurisdictions.

The threat to the State system is that areas of work previously covered by State awards and determinations can become the subject of Federal award coverage by the creation of an interstate industrial dispute. We are all aware of the means whereby paper disputes are created to establish the validity of an interstate dispute for the purpose of gaining a Federal award at the expense of an existing State award. The dispute can therefore be found in the Federal jurisdiction and, subject to this clause, an award or certified agreement made in settlement of that dispute.

By virtue of section 109 of the Constitution, a Federal award always prevails over any existing State award or determination. It is through that constitutional provision that Federal awards gain that coverage and subvert the State award. Action to obtain Federal coverage may be initiated by a federally registered organisation with little or no actual membership creating, as I said a moment ago, an interstate industrial dispute on paper and applying for Federal award coverage. This can lead to the intrusion of the Federal jurisdiction into State areas where, on a rational assessment of the facts, it is not justified. In the coalition's industrial relations policy, which was recently released and which updates our policy of last year that was so well received in the community at large, particularly in the business community, we say that we will ensure that a proper balance will be maintained between Federal and State jurisdictions. For example, we will prevent the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission from making a federal award covering an area of employment which is satisfactorily handled by a State jurisdiction. That is the reason for our amendment, to give effect to that section of our policy which ensures that we will provide appropriate protection for State jurisdictions. I strongly support the amendment and I urge all honourable senators to join me in that support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce a pretty basic question, namely: Does he believe that there should be a proper balance between the Federal and State jurisdictions? Does he believe that that is fair? Is it the Government's policy that there should be a proper balance between the Federal and State jurisdictions in this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —My answer to that question, of course, is yes. There should always be proper balances between the various jurisdictions, and so on.

—Does the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce believe that it is proper for the Federal jurisdiction to take over when an award is being handled correctly at the State level and when the Federal jurisdiction has very small numbers?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the responsibility of the appropriate arbitral bodies et cetera to assess in any particular set of circumstances. It is a matter in relation to which discretion is vested in them. As I have said, in commenting on what Senator Chaney had said, this in fact has been done by the arbitration bodies.

—The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce is not answering the question. I asked the Minister whether he believed that the Federal jurisdiction should take over when a matter is already being satisfactorily handled by the State jurisdiction.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator is asking me a very hypothetical question. The point is that it is not for me to determine. In these matters, the Conciliation and Arbitration Act has always vested discretion in the tribunal, and with quite adequate recourse, I think, for representatives of the State industries and, where necessary, the State tribunals. If the honourable senator is seeking to make a broader point that there is some advocacy in the Government or some scheme in this Bill to provide a sort of sinister Federal takeover of State jurisdictions, my response to that is that that is not the case. I refer the honourable senator particularly to part VII of the legislation, dealing with cooperation with the States. If the honourable senator is seeking to flush out my personal view, I cannot take the matter much further than to say that the best arrangement is the one which is the most efficient in terms of the interests of a particular industry or industries.

—That suits fine, but my one remaining question is: If the State jurisdiction has the overwhelming numbers and the Federal jurisdiction has only a very small number of people-and the State jurisdiction does not seem to be doing a bad job-what is the Minister's opinion in that case?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to answer that question in the same way as I did before. More than 49 per cent of all employees are covered by State awards, on the figures which I referred to earlier, and about 32 per cent of employees are covered by Federal awards. That does not suggest that, during the 80 years of our having an industrial conciliation and arbitration system of one kind or another, there has been an enormous imbalance in favour of the Federal jurisdiction-in fact, the contrary has been the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to have this opportunity to participate in this debate prior to suspension of the sitting for dinner. I am sure that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) does not have much to do over the dinner break, and he might like to address the point that I will now raise and reply at 8 o'clock. I address my initial remarks in support of this amendment by pleading in aid the views of the Queensland State Service Union-which did not seem to melt the Minister's heart at all. Therefore, I refer the Minister in more detail to what was said by the Hancock Committee of Review into the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems.

SPEECH.PARA: At page 296 of volume 2 of the report, Part VI deals specifically with the issue that we are currently debating. The view that was put forward by the Queensland State Service Union is precisely the view which was adopted by the Hancock Committee in Part VI. It is interesting that the Hancock Committee refers to a number of arguments that have not been brought forward in the Committee so far. For example, at paragraph 6.115 Hancock refers to the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI), suggesting that the means of producing more inter-governmental agreement in this area would not be found while section 41 (1) (d) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act enables the Federal Commission unilaterally to remove areas of present State jurisdiction without reference to the State tribunal.

So, a series of submissions were made to the Hancock Committee, which, after all, was a Government inquiry. The Government seemed to regard the Hancock report as a matter of great importance, and it laboured for years after the report to produce some legislation to flow from it. I think the Minister owes us an explanation of why the Government has rejected this part of the Hancock inquiry. Hancock reports that there were submissions indicating dissatisfaction with the way in which one of the sections-which is repeated in this Bill-operates. A major concern expressed was:
Intervention of a federally registered organisation poses a threat to the viability and structure of a State based union which has been party to the State regulation.

A series of paragraphs are involved, but I will not burden the Minister by reading them all into the record. However, I ask the Minister to examine them and to explain precisely why the Government came to a conclusion contrary to that which is recorded in paragraph 6.118, as the conclusion of Mr Hancock, who has now been appointed to the Commission by the Government, as well as that of Mr Polites and Mr Fitzgibbon. Their conclusion was:
. . . amendments to section 41 (1) (d) (ii)-
which is the parent of and precisely the same section as that with which we are dealing here in this Bill-

are desirable to give more protection to State awards. The present constitutional position is one of shared power between the Commonwealth and the States. The legislative framework should reflect this position. If the balance between the coverage of the federal and the States' systems is to change, this should be effected in a systematic way as part of a deliberate and conscious policy. The widened interpretation of `industrial dispute' by the High Court in the Social Welfare Union case, and the recommendations which we make to have the jurisdiction of the federal industrial tribunal as broad as possible, may imply a significantly increased potential for the growth of the federal jurisdiction at the expense of the States.

The Minister's figures are meaningless unless one looks at them in terms of which way the system is trending. The Minister might tell us whether, in fact, he and the Government are seeking an expansion of the Federal jur- isdiction at the expense of the States-as suggested might occur by the Hancock Committee. Paragraph 6.118 continues:

In many instances, this will be a development which benefits the parties and the community; but there is a risk of transfers to federal regulation in cases where most of the interests concerned find State regulation more suitable. There is merit in the argument that the move from State to federal jurisdiction may often not be in harmony with the wishes of the employees involved. A more rigorous test is justified.

The precise sort of amendment that we have proposed is what is being pushed forward by the Hancock Committee. A number of other arguments are dealt with in Part VI of the report, but in the light of the time I will not pursue them at this stage. However, I ask the Minister to address over the dinner break the points that I have raised, but if he is not prepared to do that he might ask his weary exhausted advisers, who have laboured over this Bill so hard and for so long, to address themselves to these matters and to let us have some advice on this after dinner.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner Senator Chaney referred to some specific passages of the report of the Hancock Committee of Review into the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. I really do not have much to add to what I said in the earlier part of the debate. The Government, in considering the Hancock report and the general discussion which took place around that report's proposals, felt that this amendment was not necessary because of the matters I referred to which are contained in section 41, particularly the matters contained in section 41 (1) (d) (iii) which enable the dismissal of a matter by Commission on the public interest ground, which includes an inadequate number of members.
—That was there when Hancock made the recommendation.
—I understand that. The Government's view is that the Hancock Committee overlooked that provision. I think I said that earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: On the more general issue which has been raised by Senator Chaney and others, I again refer to the point that I made about the coverage of Federal awards and the relative coverage of State awards in terms of numbers of employees. Since Federation the Federal jurisdiction has naturally increased in size. That growth has not at any stage been dramatic. There have been fluctuations in the movements of relative coverage by State and Federal awards in terms of number of employees.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Crichton-Browne's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Page 51, clause 116 (4) (c), line 29 and line 31, leave out ``or part of the business''.
(18) Page 68, clause 149, paragraph (d), line 32, leave out ``or part of the business''.
(25) Page 88, subclause 195 (2), leave out the subclause.
(35) Page 155, clause 308, leave out the clause.

This group of amendments relates to the provisions in the Bill which bind successors to part of a business under a certified agreement. Clause 116 refers to the operation of a certified agreement and provides in subclause (4) that it is binding on the parties, all members of an organisation and:

an employer who is a successor, assignee or transmitee (whether immediate or not) to or of the business of part of the business of a party, including a corporation that has acquired or taken over the business or part of the business of the party.

Amendment (10) prevents an award constituted by a certified agreement being binding on a person who takes up a part of the business of an employer who is a party to an agreement. It complements amendment (18). Employers consider that the provisions in the Bill are virtually unworkable as it is extremely difficult to define what constitutes part of a business. Indeed, this was a matter of specific representation to us from the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, which had that view. It has said that it is concerned with the provision contained in clause 149, which goes to the next amendment, a related amendment. Clause 149 states that, subject to the order of the Commission, an award determining an industrial dispute is binding on a successor, assignee or transmittee to or of the business of a party to the dispute, but also on any successor, assignee or transmittee to or of part of the business. The Chamber of Manufactures sees this provision as being virtually unworkable, and I would like the Minister to explain why that is not so. Amendment (18) is an amendment to clause 149 of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the same argument.

—Exactly, so I do not need to repeat it. I thank the Minister. Amendment (25) relates to the obligation on employers to advise of the sale of a business. There is a requirement in clause 195 that employers must notify their employer organisation if their business is sold or transferred to a non-member. Clauses 195 and 308 require that the rules of an organisation of employers must provide that members notify that organisation within 14 days if:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the business, or part of the business, of a member . . . is assigned or transferred to a person who is not a member of that organisation; or
(b) such a person succeeds to the business, or part of the business, of a member . . .

It would be an offence with a prescribed penalty of $500 for an employer organisation to fail to give written notice within 28 days of being notified of such a change to the Registrar and any registered union bound by an award or an order of the Commission that also bound the member in relation to the business or part of the business. Once again, there are difficulties in interpreting these provisions. The question again arises as to what constitutes part of a business. They are onerous administratively and are objectionable in principle, since they oblige employer organisations to report employers' business dealings directly to trade unions for the latter's benefit. In the view of the Opposition, that is not the direction in which we should be taking this matter.

As I have said, the amendments I have just moved are related. Amendment (35) simply removes the obligation on an employer organisation to notify a union if one of its members has assigned or transferred his business to a non-member. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to explain the Government's intention with respect to this matter. It has always been the case that, if an employer, that employer being bound by an award, transmits a business to a stranger and he and the employees concerned continue to remain in the industry, such a transmission carries the award coverage with it. There are a number of decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on the record to that effect. Perhaps I should give an example by way of illustration. If a motel in a motel chain is sold, it is appropriate in the Government's view that the owner or transmittor of that business, which is part of a larger business, advise the appropriate employer organisation of the transmission having taken place. Obligations are imposed on registered organisations in other sections of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Employer registered organisations have obligations, just as employee registered organisations have obligations, by virtue of their registration under the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: In the example I gave-the transmittor being a motel chain selling a particular motel to another party-it is not entirely or necessarily to the benefit of the employees that such notice should be given to the employer organisation and, appropriately, to the Commission. If the motel chain is covered by a Federal award and as a result of the sale of the business the new business in the hands of the transmittee falls within the jurisdiction of a State award, the new employer, as well as the employees, ought to be aware of their rights and obligations. That is the purpose of the notification of the kind mentioned.

I am surprised that Senator Chaney tells us that employers are concerned about this matter as if it was something new. We have heard a little in the debate on the preceding clauses of this Bill about the importance which the Opposition, quite understandably, attaches to State jurisdictions. There is nothing unfamiliar about this concept in State jurisdictions. Every State long service leave Act contains provisions almost identical to the one which the Government seeks in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Every State long service leave Act contains a provision about the sale of part of a business. I understand Senator Chaney's point about definitional problems, but part of a business is referred to in all those Acts and, presumably, is interpreted by each of the State industrial commissions, or by a court, in the event of an employee suing under the long service leave legislation. We say, first of all, that it is of benefit, in some circumstances, to not only employees but also employers and, secondly, that there is nothing new about this provision. It is in the legislation in the State systems and, for that reason, should be in the Federal system, because it is a matter involving the protection of rights whether of one or other of the parties.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move amendment No. 4 to clause 3 of the Bill, that is, the objectives clause-which seeks to add additional objectives to the existing objects clause:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 2, clause 3, after paragraph (b), insert the following paragraphs:
``(bb) to encourage direct dealing between employers and employees within each enterprise;
``(bc) to minimise interference in relation to enterprises by persons or bodies who have no direct interest in those enterprises; and
``(bd) to facilitate the consolidation of single enterprise bargaining units;''.

To explain this amendment, it would be desirable for me to turn to the Opposition's policy which underlies our approach to this and the related amendments which go to trade union structure. The issue of trade union structure is of fundamental importance. It is an issue on which there are very strongly held views. For example, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) has indicated that it is seeking to establish a relatively small number of large unions: I think that a general number of around 20 has been indicated by Mr Kelty. The early indications are that the issue of union amalgamation is being actively pursued and various possible amalgamations are currently being mooted.

The Opposition policy, until the reconsideration of our policy this year, was to encourage a structure of industry-based unions. The matter was examined very carefully by the Opposition, mainly in the context of trying to ascertain what it was that employers and employees wanted and what it was that would be likely to produce an effective economic result. Undoubtedly, the Opposition's approach was very heavily coloured by the very firm view that we developed, that is, that the successful operation of an enterprise in a modern economy requires very close cooperation between employer and employee. That is not least evident in the manufacturing sector for which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, is primarily responsible in the Government. I think he would agree that, in those manufacturing enterprises where there have been successful gains in productivity, that is almost always achieved on the basis of a very close working relationship between employers and employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree. I say that I agree because you chastised me before for not acknowledging your rationality.

—Senator Button agrees. One of the clear points which emerged from our very extensive discussions with industry, industry organisations and representatives of the trade union movement was that there was a broadly common view that the desirable situation was to have a single bargaining unit for an enterprise, a situation where employers and employees could deal together face to face with minimum interference from outside. That is highly desirable as it facilitates communication and the sort of cooperative endeavour that is very much the stuff of modern industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The policy which we announced in June dealt with trade unions in terms to which I will now refer. In that policy we talked of our fundamental goal of promoting close, cooperative, flexible and productive relationships within enterprises for the mutual benefit of employers and employees. We expressed the view that we wanted genuine voluntary unionism and so on. The policy refers to the fact that the existing union structure is a significant impediment to improved relations between employers and employees in many enterprises and that most employers are forced to deal with several unions which tend to vie with one another and press narrow sectional interests within the labour force, thus creating demarcation disputes and disrupting employer-employee relations. We refer to the historical fact that the existence of unions largely based on occupation rather than industry or enterprise also encourages the rapid flow of wage adjustments from one part of the economy to other areas. We went on to deal with a number of issues relevant to that.

In terms of the structure of registered trade unions, we say that, in enterprises which operate under the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and its awards, the structure should be determined by the wishes of the members of those unions. We said that freedom of association would be preserved subject only to the Commission's supervision of matters relating to the formation of new unions and amalgamation or fragmentation of existing unions with a view to ensuring that, as far as possible, new union structures contribute to the objectives of: ensuring that employers and employees within an enterprise deal directly with each other; minimising interference by people or bodies with no direct interest in the enterprise; and facilitating the consolidation of single enterprise bargaining units. We went on to make the point that a variety of union structures and sizes could meet those criteria, including unions organised on an industry or enterprise basis.

I suppose it is fair to say that we believe that it is important to decide what one's objectives are before one decides what the structure should be. I think it would be fair to say that both the Government and the ACTU frequently have drawn the attention of the Australian public to overseas examples. They refer, in documents such as Australia Reconstructed and others, to the experience in Scandinavian and other European countries and often indicate circumstances where large unions appear to operate very successfully. On the other hand, one can point to Japan where a very large number of small enterprise based units seem to deal with industrial matters very successfully indeed.

The amendment goes to the starting point in all this. What are the objectives? We say that the objectives are those which are set out in the amendment. I would have thought, in terms of the Minister's views on these matters, that he and the Government would have supported the direction that we are indicating. I invite the Minister to indicate to the Committee-if he is not prepared to accept this amendment-to what extent he objects to the idea that it should be one of the objects of the proposed Act to encourage direct dealing between employers and employees within each enterprise. To what extent does he object to the idea that the Act should be promoting the other objective which is to minimise interference in enterprises by persons or bodies which have no direct interest in those enterprises and, finally, to facilitate the consolidation of single enterprise bargaining units? I invite the Minister to tell us what, if anything, he disagrees with with respect to those objectives.

I refer to the sorts of objections that one gets from some elements of the trade union movement and indeed sometimes from the Arbitration Commission.
