The reality is that some trade unions actively discourage direct dealings between employers and employees within an enterprise. It is not hard to understand why that should occur because it could be seen as a threat to the allegiance to the union and the support of the union if the employer and employees find that they can get on without the union. It is perhaps more serious than the mere protection of the vested interest of the union when we get the sort of example which I have raised in this committee debate before where, in cases involving meat industry employees, direct dealings between the employer and employees have been actively discouraged by the Commission. I quoted the Castle Bacon Pty Ltd situation and another meat industry case from Queensland which came before the Commission. In the latter case I think it was Commissioner Riordan who made the point that it made the job of the Commission more difficult to have this direct dealing between employers and employees without the involvement of the union. It is interesting to see that progress is being made in this area. It would be a pity if the Government were behind the play. One of the most encouraging industrial documents I have seen for some time was issued jointly by the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers in conjunction with the Metal Trades Industry Association Inc., the ACTU and the--

TALK.START.PARA: —CAI.

—No, there was another union involved, the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia. If the Confederation of Australian Industry was also associated I am sorry but I did not notice that in the documentation. I apologise to it if that is an omission of mine. The important thing I noted about that document related to the issue of employee participation and the encouragement of better dispute settling procedures. The encouraging thing about that document, which came out under the auspices of employers and trade unions, was that throughout the document there was clear reference to the importance of these matters being dealt with by employers and employees. There is quite a significant difference in the wording of that document and in some of the other two-party documents which have been issued promoting improved industrial relations and coming from the employer and trade union structure. In that sense direct dealings between employers and employees is something to be throttled or overcome as it is very destructive indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission is going to play a very important role not only in the operations of industrial relations systems over the coming period but indeed in the development and change which is occurring within that system. I think it would be a pity not to give the Commission the sort of steer that this particular amendment provides. What we are saying is basically accepted by plenty of people on the employee side of the equation. It is quite clear that the sort of flexibility of work which is central to modern enterprises, the sort of employee participation which involves the capacity of the work force to contribute to the almost daily improvement of the production process, and certainly the daily monitoring and ensuring that the production process is efficient, is simply not going to be achieved to the extent that there are intermediaries who interfere with the rapid and very easy flow of information between employers and employees. I think the truth is that where this is working the distinction between employers and employees and between management and labour becomes steadily less important.

I suppose that one of the heartening elements of the good examples that we have of modern management in Australia is the extent to which it contributes to acknowledging the essential dignity and worth of everybody who is part of the process and the capacity of every individual in the process to contribute. It seems to me that these amendments, which are simply the objects clause of the Bill, are very significant. They enshrine a significant principle about which we should be concerned. I trust that the Government might consider them and adopt them as part of its own approach in this very important area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a short contribution to this matter. I agree with Senator Chaney that we need to set the objectives before we look at the means used to achieve those objectives. I was very interested to hear him talk about considering international behaviour when on other occasions he and other members of his Party continue to ridicule the idea that we may import some ideas from Scandinavian countries about how industry and the economy should run. Senator Chaney talked about the Japanese experience which has been a very paternalistic one and so contrary to the way in which we have operated in Australia that it does not even bear examination. What he proposes is something that is fairly negative and which looks at a question of an enterprise decision in relation to workers on the job belonging to a particular union or unions. If one looks at the provisions in the Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988 it can be seen that the opportunity is given to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to make the various decisions that will bring order where chaos might reign.

SPEECH.PARA: For many years the trade unions have collectively managed to solve demarcation disputes. It would be fair to say that nowhere near enough have been solved but everybody on both sides of the industrial fence has recognised that one of the most harmful, negative and wasteful disputes that can occur is the demarcation of work. However, for many people it has meant job security. In the terms that we suggest, the Act will enable the Commission, which has a great deal of experience and can listen to argument from practitioners within the industry and from within the calling, to bring down decisions and make suggestions that will have a common thread throughout the whole community and lead to more solutions of demarcation problems within the trade union movement. If that can happen it means that no physical disputes will occur. After all, that is what the captains of industry always seek.

If we accept the proposition which Senator Chaney has put forward we will have a situation where continually smaller groups of people who do not understand the larger problems and who may have only a selfish motive will be casting votes which will create problems based on no facts at all and will not give consideration to the general overall public interest, let alone the general collective interest of the trade unions. I think the propositions in the Bill are correct and I am surprised that the Opposition would put forward such a proposition which is negative and divisive. The Opposition continues to say that it is looking to industry to be cooperative and to get the highest levels of productivity. This amendment would reduce those opportunities and it should be rejected for those reasons alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Burns, who has just resumed his seat, for his comments. I am very puzzled by them because I do not see these objectives as being destructive but rather as being quite the reverse-that is, as being very constructive. The concerns we have about these provisions are not concerns which are confined to the Opposition. When we move on past amendment No. 4 I will quote at greater length some of the industry and academic views which have been expressed about the general approach to the trade union structure which has been adopted by the Government. In response to Senator Burns I simply wish to say that the ideal of having direct dealing between employers and employees, which he sees as opening people up to exploitation, is I think a matter of looking backwards instead of forwards. It seems to me that in substantial areas of the economy the simple truth is that the economic results that are being pursued by employers will be achieved only by adopting modern management methods and a progressive and humane approach to the work force. `Humane' is probably the wrong word because it suggests some sort of looking down. I think there is now an absolute requirement of partnership in the productive process in many areas and I think the game has changed. We talked in this debate earlier of the change in attitude of the trade union movement in the senator's own State of Queensland with respect to the reorganisation of some past practices in the tourist industry and so on. So I suppose to some extent the difference between the senator and the Opposition is that we see the movement as being in a very positive and constructive direction, and I think the senator is essentially looking back in the remarks that he made.
—The proposals will allow that to flow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of many industries I understand what Senator Chaney stated as being the objectives, namely a community of interest between employers and employees in promoting good industrial relations, harmony in the work place and more productive practices and things of those kinds. There is no doubt about the desirability of that. The question between the Opposition and the Government is how we get to that point-what route to follow and what time we take to get to that point. These things are not going to be determined ultimately by legislation. In my view they will be determined by a process of attitudinal change.
—But you would not say that the legislative framework is irrelevant.

—No, I would not, and that is the point I am coming to. The Opposition's amendments really seek to substitute for the present system-I do not think this is an unfair characterisation-a system of enterprise bargaining from which trade unions are excluded. Earlier in this debate, when we discussed the question of enterprise bargaining and so on, we also discussed the question of how that would work, because what the Opposition is doing is substituting a new system for an existing system which the Government seeks to modify, with no transitional provisions which would assist it to come into being. For example, if we look at the constitutional power for the settlement of industrial disputes, which is what this legislation is all about, single enterprise bargaining units are not, in our view, support- able by the constitutional conciliation and arbitration power, because that requires the creation of an industrial dispute extending beyond the limits of any one State. The creation of an industrial dispute by an enterprise union working in one plant in one State does not give rise to the exercise of the power under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to create a dispute. So we have serious doubts about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the constitutional difficulties there are the practical questions. The proposed amendments are quite silent about existing organisations and existing awards. I suspect it is unlikely that they would voluntarily vacate the field and cease making claims for awards if there was a sudden transition, as is foreshadowed by the Opposition, for a new enterprise bargaining system. In any event, existing awards will continue in operation and it will be open to unions which are party to them to call on the Commission to decline to make awards in relation to new enterprise unions. Those difficulties would be compounded by the prospect of demarcation disputes arising between existing unions and new enterprise oriented unions. So there are a number of objections which are both practical and constitutionally based.

In clauses 115, 116 and 117 of the Industrial Relations Bill, in the provisions relating to certified agreements, the Government is moving some of the way down this track because it makes provision for agreements to be negotiated at the enterprise level, but it has the additional requirement that they be certified by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that necessary?
—For two reasons, Senator. First of all to protect employees or, if one likes, employers.
—Do you think they cannot look after themselves?

—There have been circumstances in which that has clearly been the case. The Opposition has complained about some of those in this debate, and our side has complained about some of them too. So clearly there are circumstances where that happens. The second point is that in the current economic situation it is important that one maintain a degree of influence or direction in a wages system. If agreements have to be certified the Commission can take account of the whole range of issues relating to the wages system as a whole. To illustrate this point I refer to an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review which discussed the industrial relations policy of the Opposition and described it as `a theoretical exercise in laissez-faire economics and cutting back union power'. But I think the important question which I want to raise on this point is revealed in this quotation:

SPEECH.PARA: More importantly, it does not answer how a Liberal Government will control aggregate wage outcomes responsibly in an economy left to the will of the market.
The policy is aimed at deregulating the labour-market-and as a `facilitator' neutralising trade unions and limiting the scope of the centralised institutions which govern industrial relations.

The exerting of influence and control on aggregate wage outcomes is, I think, a very important question for a responsible political party, whether it be Government or Opposition, to confront. The exercise in laissez-faire economics, which has some attraction about it-it might be a slightly unfair characterisation-as a description of that position, would in our view clearly lead to that result. In respect of the clauses relating to the objects of the Act about which I have had something to say in the second reading stage of this Bill, the Government does not accept those amendments. I take it they are the burden of Senator Chaney's remarks at this time. He wants to go further and deal with the question of organisations. Finally, in support of Senator Chaney's argument he cites the Sanctuary Cove case and similar things and says that these things can happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —They actually happened within the arbitration system.
—I understand that. These things can happen.
—It was not the rank and file that created that.
—I readily concede that but I would argue that they are happening less and less and they are likely to happen with much less success.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not quite follow the last point made by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). Could he clarify it? I understood everything else in his contribution, but I could not follow the last point he made about Sanctuary Cove and what was going to happen less. I think the points that have been made by the Minister require some response because to some extent he was inaccurate in terms of his comments on the Opposition's approach. For a start it is wrong to say that the policy basis is that we are anti-trade unions and that we are saying that there is not a place for trade unions. If we turn to the coalition policy on voluntary agreements we find specific reference-this is indeed a change from the 1986 policy-to what was only implicit in the previous policy, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: Employees may appoint an agent, including a union, to negotiate on their behalf.

Even within the voluntary agreement structure this is essentially an attempt to give people greater freedom of choice. That is one of the elements of this. They may choose to remain within the centralised system, they may choose to remain within the award situation or they may choose to get a union to act on their behalf. Again, we are not talking about something which is theoretical and which has never happened. It has certainly happened recently in the United Kingdom, in a way which probably Senator Burns would object to, in terms of the role of the Electrical Trades Union (ETU), which I visited whilst in the United Kingdom in June. That union has, unfortunately, just been expelled from the Trades Union Congress. It is interesting to see the role that the ETU has adopted. What it has said is that it is prepared to act on behalf of a body of workers who want a single union and who wish to negotiate an arrangement with their employer. It is interesting that the new enterprises in the United Kingdom are substantially using that sort of approach and that what we have is a situation in which a union is establishing itself as the body with expertise to operate within that arrangement. Honourable senators might say that the United Kingdom system is very different from the Australian system. That would be a correct statement. But, if we look at what is occurring--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are always talking about pommy shop stewards being crook.

—I think that the ETU is a long way from the caricature of the pommy shop steward that Senator Burns has brought into the debate. What we have is people who I think are genuinely committed to the idea that if there is to be a long term employment prospect for their workers British industry has to be modern, up to date, competitive and a lot more efficient than it was until very recently. We know what was the state of British manufacturing. We know the travail British manufacturing has been through. I believe that happily we can achieve much of our improvements without having to go through some of that travail. The ETU as a trade union has adapted itself to meet the challenge of change in a way that I think is very positive. The Liberal Party and the National Party in this policy have quite overtly acknowledged that if employees want to employ an agent that right extends, of course, to appointing a union to act on their behalf. In terms of how practical that is it is very interesting to see what is happening, again in the honourable senator's State of Queensland, with respect to the voluntary employment agreements and to the operation of the South East Queensland Electricity Board which is operating under a statute in which there is an entitlement to enter into agreements directly with members of the work force.
—Not many people have taken it up.

—A substantial proportion of the work force has done so. Those people are, of course, represented by an association. Just as in our policy, that is not a registered association. People who choose to operate by agreement will have the freedom to decide precisely what association, union-call it whatever we like-they want to represent their interests.

SPEECH.PARA: The thing that struck me and, indeed, those people who were with me when we were talking to the parties involved in that exercise was the acknowledgment by the association leadership that they had to work very hard for their members. They did not have the luxury of conscripting their members through preference clauses or whatever. They had to get their members by showing that they could perform. Quite frankly, I think that is a nice sanction and a very nice pressure for any union, whatever it might be called, to be under.

Let me simply say that I think the experience within Australia reflects the experience in the United Kingdom, namely that if there is greater freedom structures will adapt to provide the services that are required by employees. Our approach is very much based on providing more flexibility so that structures can emerge which meet the requirements of both employers and employees. If, under the very able current leadership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), the existing trade union movement is able to offer the best representative capacity for workers under our policy, of course the employees concerned will use those structures. In Queensland again, with respect to the voluntary employment agreements, it is interesting to see the other sorts of consultants that are springing up to offer their services to people who wish to negotiate these sorts of agreements. How in the world can that be a bad thing? How can that be inimical to the interests of employees, workers-call them what we will?

TALK.START.PARA: —They only want to make a quid. They don't care about the people they work for.

—Senator Burns says that they only want to make a quid. When we talk to people in the trade union movement about the problems of union amalgamation they will freely admit that the desire of officials to keep making a quid is one of the major impediments to structural change.
—Serve the membership.

—I am touched by Senator Burns's belief that all union officials are activated merely by the desire to serve the membership. All I can say, Senator Burns, is that good trade union officials have said to me-I am sorry to get disorderly, Mr Temporary Chairman, I should talk through you-in a quite open and frank way, that the vested interests, and there is nothing wrong with that, or the desire of union officials to keep their jobs in existing union structures is a very substantial impediment to change. Economic influences such as that are going to occur whatever approach we adopt.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I want to address in terms of what Senator Button had to say tonight is his statement that we are pursuing enterprise bargaining from which trade unions are excluded. That is specifically not our policy. It will be a case of the race being to the swift and the effective. With respect to the second point that I think was very significant in what Senator Button had to say, he challenged the constitutional basis of our policy. Because Mr Willis has frequently made these statements, I can only assure the Committee that we took advice from senior counsel both before the 1986 policy and again before the issue of the 1988 policy. The two policies are, of course, in the same direction but there is simply some detail development and difference on the trade union structure side between the two. However, on the voluntary agreements matter, the policies are essentially the same thing. I can assure the Committee that senior counsel in each case have advised that there is no constitutional difficulty.

I have been standing in this chamber for some time and making the point, with respect to the proposed constitutional amendments, that no lawyer, however eminent, can predict with absolute certainty what a decision of the High Court of Australia or, indeed, any other court will be. I am sure we are all familiar with that. Government Ministers, when discussing the referendum Bills, made the point that they could give no firm and clear undertaking as to what decisions the High Court might make in respect of the constitutional changes. But, the point is that the advice from senior counsel which we have obtained is sharp and clear. I must say that my own concerns about that matter are very slight. Indeed, I do not have before me the Australian Financial Review article written by Pamela Williams which was quoted by the Minister. I thought the article appeared more than a few days ago; however, it was certainly quite recent. I simply say that when I read that article I disagreed with it very strongly. Since we are going to throw newspaper opinions around I would like to contrast that article with the view of Mr Charles Fitzgibbon. I think Mr Fitzgibbon is a more distinguished participant in the trade union movement than Ms Williams. I mean no disrespect to her but Mr Fitzgibbon is of an age which means that he must have more experience than she has. He has been a vice-president of the ACTU and a head of the Waterside Workers Federation. I think very significant also for the current debate is that he has made the most extraordinarily constructive contributions to the industrial relations debate over recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You never used to say that about him.

—Senator Burns should be pleased if he sees in that remark some sign of conversion. If he reads what Mr Fitzgibbon said in 1986 to the Productivity Council of New South Wales and the Economic Planning Advisory Council, I think he will get a very good exposition of many of the defects of the present system and why change is needed. I congratulate Mr Fitzgibbon for his continuing contribution to public debate. I think he is making an extraordinarily good contribution. He also writes in the Australian Financial Review. On Friday, 23 July, he wrote about the Opposition's industrial relations policy. Since Senator Button has made the point about Ms Williams's comments, let me cite what Mr Fitzgibbon had to say.
—Are you saying he is the only one?

—No, he is not the only one. There are plenty of other people. If Senator Button wants to get into that debate, I am happy to keep going. I would be happy to incorporate the whole article as I do not wish to misrepresent Mr Fitzgibbon's position at all, but I wish to quote selectively from it in the sense that I only want to quote some paragraphs. Does Senator Button want the whole article incorporated?
—Yes. I would like to read it.
—Has the honourable senator not read it?
—I do not recall the particular one. I have read many.
—I will not read all of it. I freely concede that it does contain some criticisms of the Opposition's policy, but in his general approach he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing impracticable in the Coalition's industrial relations policy document and nothing that cannot be practically introduced.

He talked about the fact that there is some vague wording here and there and so on, and said there is room to manoeuvre, and what the intent is with respect to some provisions only time will tell. He said:
Much of the policy is capable of implementation without setting too many teeth on edge, because in many ways it continues trends already evident in society.
A little later he went on:

It is now generally accepted that productivity, especially in the manufacturing sector, is the key to balancing our society between its rural commodity, mining commodity and manufacturing roles, in making that sector internationally competitive: and that the best way of doing that is by forgetting the `them and us' concept and instead forging an overall unity at an enterprise level.

That is not possible for every industry or undertaking. Undertaking is not liked too much by the political ideologues in our midst and may produce many hiccups along the way, but the concept is developing faster than a lot of people believe. He talked about more flexibility being engendered in the system by way of profit sharing and share deals and legislation being enacted to make this development easier. I interpolate there, Mr Temporary Chairman, that the Government has picked up more than half of the proposal that I presented during the last election campaign with respect to employee share ownerships, and I thank the Government for that. I congratulate the Government for that. The article continued:
Already there is a degree of cooperation between State and Federal systems.
A little later he said:

Whether everyone in the community likes it or not, we are moving towards a more market-oriented system of wage determination. The contradiction which exists is that the radical leftist organisations or individuals who organise street marches or wage demands of the general norm are hastening that day. The coming of such a system has almost the feel of inevitability about it. So, many of the matters covered in the policy document are already under development-thus it will certainly be possible for the authors to refer to events and say, `There you are . . . we were right'.

That is an assessment in the newspaper that was quoted by Senator Button a few minutes ago, written by Mr C. H. Fitzgibbon, a former industries assistance commissioner, General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation and, as I understand it, a former Vice-President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I quote him as an authority that I would line up, as I say, with the greatest respect against Ms Williams and with a great deal of confidence. The Minister conceded that his description of this as being a matter of laissez-faire economics is a little unfair. It certainly is unfair. After all, we still have a system where the Commission is to continue, where people may remain within the centralised system if their belief is that that is the best option for them. What we are saying is that a movement towards greater flexibility is very desirable. I think it is misunderstanding on the part of Senator Burns if he does not understand that the Government itself is moving part way down that track with this Bill, with respect to the agreements that can be entered into on a more restrictive basis.

Going back to the issue that we are debating, the Minister ranged very widely in his response, but what we are saying is that we think it is fundamental to an improved industrial relations structure in this country that we have as an objective the encouragement of direct dealing between employers and employees within enterprises, minimising outside interference and facilitating the consolidation of single enterprise bargaining units. Frankly, I find it extraordinary that a Minister with Senator Button's record of trying to encourage more rational industry arrangements could deny the validity of that approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution will be brief because I believe Senator Button has answered the proposal of the Opposition. Although Senator Chaney talked about freedom of choice when he referred to his objectives, in fact they are a prescription for anarchy. That is the simple fact of the matter. When he referred to minimum interference from outside he showed that he has a pathological misunderstanding-I believe it has to be a bias that causes him to make this error-about the trade unions and their role. Members of the Opposition continually suggest that the trade union movement does not play a positive role in industry. That is not right. Senator Button has pointed out, and it is obvious, that the Bill is a modification of an existing system that will allow for agreements at the enterprise level; in other words, the very things that Senator Chaney has said, such as employers and workers arranging things in the factory or at the place of work. What will happen is that under the existing system people will be entitled to advice and help from their trade union or from the employer organisations. The Opposition has proposed that the workers go into the negotiations with their hands behind their backs or, alternatively, without the natural support that they have had during the whole history of the trade union movement they will try to hire guns from some source outside the union that has covered them.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred to a prescription for anarchy because Senator Chaney had to draw on cases where the unions are weak-either in non-union situations or poorly organised workplaces. Such places have always existed and always employers have had the advantage. The Opposition is obsessed with the individual cases where the employer is on top. But for there to be cooperation and for people to get the things that Senator Chaney referred to requires people as adults to negotiate. Invariably the experience has been that where one has the employer's representatives and the trade unions coming together-even at the middle level or the organiser level-the people in the enterprise have the advantage of all the other things that Senator Chaney was talking about. If the Opposition wants to change the system, it will have to give away its ideological commitment to weaken the trade union movement and put the employees in a weakened situation.

The proposed legislation will continue to make available to the workers in an enterprise the assistance of all the things that normally happen-for example, legal advice, economic advice and industry advice. Under this legislation these things will be available to the people so that they will be able intelligently to go into negotiations with an employer. The employer, of course, will have the same types of assistance available. That is why the proposed system is a sensible one. Senator Chaney quoted from an article by Charlie Fitzgibbon. All Charlie Fitzgibbon was indicating in that article was that there is probably a need in many areas for people to get into direct negotiation. The Bill that the Committee is considering does not prevent that: in fact, it encourages it. To that extent it is positive legislation. I do not wish to become involved in a long discussion. There is an ideological difference between the Government and the Opposition. Unfortunately the Opposition does not have a program of objectives that will do anything. All it would do is create a tremendous crisis in industry as the fight took place from one area of Australia to another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would respond in part to what Senator Childs has said by referring him to Hancock's second volume, where he talks about the provisions already available under part X of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It provides that parties may enter into industrial agreements for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes, existing or future, by conciliation and arbitration. Similar provisions have been in the Act since 1904. The Act provides that such an agreement is binding on the parties to it and is enforceable by the monetary penalties provided. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The penalty may be proceeded for and recovered in the same manner as penalties for breach of an order or award.
There are of course some inhibiting provisions that make it very difficult for there to be agreements of that nature at present. Let us remind ourselves of what Hancock said:

The industrial relations benefits are seen to be the greater commitment which arises from agreement whilst the economic benefits are seen to reside in the right of the parties to fix wages and conditions in the light of specific economic capacity.
He went on:

It can be argued that the inclusion of such provisions in the Act as early as 1904 demonstrates a recognition by the parliament that parties should be entitled to make their own arrangements for conciliation and arbitration.
Hancock's recommendation 21, which has been totally ignored and in fact rejected by the Government, states:

That the provisions of Part X of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act be amended to provide that parties who wish to make their own arrangements for the prevention and settlement of disputes by conciliation and arbitration may do so, and that the terms and conditions of employment resulting from those agreed arrangements would be able to operate to the exclusion of federal awards and state prescriptions. The legislation should ensure that parties who choose to follow this approach do so as a basis for the regulation of all industrial matters involved.

The Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 envisaged the capacity and ability and common sense of parties to negotiate between themselves as to arrangements and agreements that suit both. Hancock has made that point and he has reinforced it by tracing the steps in his own recommendation. He highlights the benefits of it. But the Government seems to be obsessed with the view-apparently it is a philosophical view, according to Senator Childs-that employees coming together and meeting employers are incapable or incompetent and are not able to enter an agreement which suits them and the employers, quite separate and quite distinct from an arrangement which might suit the trade union movement as a whole or employees outside the industry or outside that particular work place. The proposition put by Senator Chaney is that, given certain parameters, it can only enhance the industrial relations system in Australia if individual employees are able and allowed to negotiate their own awards and agreements and arrangements. The proposals under clauses 115, 116 and 117 barely go towards that.

Under clause 43 any arrangement or hearing before the Commission can be intruded upon by any other party with the agreement of the Commission. Presumably if that agreement does not suit the trade union movement, for whatever reason, it will intervene and present its point of view, in spite of the wishes of the parties to the agreement. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce could at any time apply to the President for review by the Full Bench of the operation of the agreement. It is subject to a number of conditions, not the least being-I find this the most impertinent-whether the commissioner decides that it is in the interests of the individuals, in the interests of the parties to the agreement. I find it quaint that we have a government that pretends in every other sphere of society to be the defender of the rights of individuals yet the moment these individuals seek to exercise their rights in a very real way that goes to the heart of their daily lives the Government decides, on their behalf, that they are not capable of making judgments which best suit them in terms of their daily lives and endeavours and rewards and arrangements. This Government knows best. The truth is that it is not a matter of what this Government decides but what the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) decides, and that is reflected in this legislation. The first legislation of the former Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, was not satisfactory to the ACTU, so we now have a revised form. That is hardly a reflection of the aspirations of individual employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There were one or two points raised by Senator Chaney that I want to refer to quickly. First, let me make the point that in quoting from the article by Charlie Fitzgibbon he was quoting from what I certainly regard as an eminent source on industrial relations matters and a considerable contributor to the industrial relations debate. That is why he was chosen by the Government to be a member of the Hancock Committee and as a member of that Committee, his views are intruded very much into the Hancock report recommendations. The second point I make is that in talking about enterprise negotiations I said earlier that it was not possible for an enterprise union or single enterprise employer to create an industrial dispute within the meaning of the conciliation and arbitration power. I do not retract from that view at all. Senator Chaney says that the Opposition has the views of eminent Queen's Counsel on this matter. I think the views of Queen's Counsel are more likely to say that, in respect of these matters, the Opposition's amendments would be supported by the corporations power.
—That is additional.

—I do not want to give legal opinions here. We do not get paid very much for them. I am prepared to assert with a fair degree of confidence that the enterprise bargaining referred to by Senator Chaney would not be supported by the conciliation and arbitration power.

SPEECH.PARA: The other points I made and which I want to remind the Committee about relate again to the question of how control is maintained over aggregate wage outcomes without a process of certification of agreements. That is the distinction between the Government's amendments to clauses 115, 116 and 117 and the Opposition's amendments. One cannot, in our view, maintain a sensible situation in respect of aggregate wage outcomes-which I think is regarded by many commentators to be a success at the present period-in the context of the proposals made by the Opposition. There are a number of other reasons, which we touched on in the second reading debate, as to why the Government will not accept these amendments to the objectives. I say again that I understand the spirit behind them. But there are a number of very practical and philosophical reasons why those amendments are not accepted by the Government at this stage. Therefore we will not support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to a couple of comments made by Senator Childs. I also omitted to respond to Senator Button's comments about aggregate wage outcomes. I regret that; it was an oversight on my part. I must say I found Senator Childs's contribution, which included a suggestion that we were ideological, a very ideological contribution. The suggestion that the policy we are pursuing requires workers to go into negotiations with their hands tied behind their backs is simply to ignore totally the content of both the policy that underlies the amendments and the amendments themselves. There is no hint of compulsion, no element of compulsion, in the policy proposals put forward by the Opposition. There is in fact a genuine widening up of freedom of action, which may be objectionable to Senator Childs and some others but is certainly regarded by the Opposition as important in terms of both principle and practical effect. It is possible for people in all parts of this process to behave in a peculiar way.

SPEECH.PARA: The first negotiation that I had with the trade union movement was with the Printing and Kindred Industries Union (PKIU)-a union with which Senator Childs would be familiar, as it is perhaps a sister union to his own. It was a fascinating discussion, because that was a case where the union representatives with whom I was dealing quite overtly were not concerned about the welfare of the unionists. There was a most extraordinary exchange, which I would like briefly to repeat. It was when a new newspaper was being started in Perth; I was the corporate solicitor and for some reason I was told that I should go and deal with the PKIU, when it was causing difficulties in relation to the start of the newspaper.

I went to the meeting with the PKIU feeling very puzzled, because we were paying rates of pay which were well above the award and we were providing working conditions which certainly were a far cry from the hot metal conditions with which I had been familiar as a copy boy at the old West Australian newspaper. This was one of the very early moves to offset very clean work. I met with representatives of the PKIU, together with a couple of journalists, and I said to them that I was puzzled because the conditions of the workers were excellent. However, the lead negotiator for the PKIU leaned on the table and said, `We are not here to talk about the conditions of the workers but we are talking about the power of this union.' That was the blunt way in which he put it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an old story. It must be if you were just a youngster.

—It is an old story, and I might say that I told that story at the Victorian Industrial Relations Society. There was a PKIU representative there and he said, `Yes, we were just like that.' I have referred to that simply to illustrate the sort of silly behaviour that relates to the other side of the coin. It is that sort of behaviour which leads employees to think that there must be a better way to be represented.

SPEECH.PARA: One can say that that is a very old example-and I think Senator Button makes the obvious interjection-but let me say that if Senator Button cares to go to Senator Cook's heartland in the Pilbara at the moment, he might be somewhat discouraged by what he finds at Mount Newman, where there has been a pathetic recurrence of disputes recently. I think there have been well over 100 disputes at Mount Newman. A few weeks ago, for example, there was supposed to be a two-month moratorium on disputes. It is a desperately inefficient operation because of the lack of use of equipment. The amount of downtime that occurs there is just pathetic, and it is because of bad industrial relations practices. Within a matter of weeks of the two-month moratorium having been declared further difficulties arose. There is a sense of desperation about the incapacity of a company to meet its contracts and obligations.

That is not history; it is now. All I am saying is that in circumstances where that unreasonable side exists, it seems to me that one certainly runs the risk that employees will decide that there must be a better way of getting representation. In cases where the known and the tried and true organisations are on the ground and have the resources, it is a pretty poor show if they cannot present themselves as those most able to represent the employees' interests.

All I am saying is that if the Government allowed a little freedom into the system, we would get to a situation where the economic incentive would point in the direction of correct behaviour, whether by the trade union officials, the trade union members or the employers. So, I totally reject Senator Childs's suggestion that this is some sort of doctrinaire thing. This policy is not extreme; it is simply saying that we want to open it up to more freedom. There are safeguards in the policy in respect of the payment of minimum wage levels related to awards, and so on, and people have the ultimate right to stay with what they know if that is the way they wish it to be.

In terms of Senator Button's important issue on aggregate wage outcomes, a matter which was raised by Ms Williams in her article in the Australian Financial Review, the position is that in terms of the practical operation of the system, the policy makes it quite clear that both employers and employees may opt to remain within the system, and those employers-and there are plenty of them-who believe that they would not be capable of handling the wages situation would stay within the system.

The 1986 policy acknowledged the nervousness of employers about this, because it actually restricted the freedom to go outside the system to small firms of 50 or less employees. But, of course, there has been a huge shift in employer understanding of their obligations in the industrial relations field. For example, the shift in the Business Council of Australia from 1986 to 1988 is very considerable and in the right direction. It is a very positive shift in terms of understanding the importance of management undertaking management of the work force as the top priority. There has been a great change, and there is not the widespread nervousness that there was in 1986. There is still nervousness, but it is not nearly as widespread.

The situation is that only those employers who see that they have a capacity to carve out arrangements which will be more productive for them will want to go down that route, and that only employees who see that it would be more productive for them will want to go down that route. There is nothing compulsory in what we are suggesting. We are suggesting that people be given a chance to find their common economic interest and their best arrangements. We see this present system struggling towards a greater capacity to do that. We see the present system used at times to repress the natural economic forces that would lead to higher wages and a better profitability. That is why we are concerned to provide this other avenue through our policy.

In terms of the aggregate outcomes, the situation is that aggregate outcomes will always be satisfactory if the micro outcomes are satisfactory. In other words, if one imagines a genuinely competitive sort of situation, a genuine sort of market situation, with a proper level playing field, where employers and employees come to economically sensible decisions or agreements, then provided the outcomes are rational at the micro level, the aggregate outcomes must also be rational.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not necessarily follow that they will be.

—I will get to that point-I just want to sketch the theoretical base first. The point is that if a firm can get together its work force and boost productivity, it can afford to pay much higher wages, because unit labour costs remain either lower or they flatten.
—That is presuming the premise on which they would grant increases.

—One is trying to achieve productivity improvement which will pay higher wages and produce greater returns on capital. That is the objective we are after, and there should be common ground on that. It is not wage rises which are destructive. What is destructive is wage rises which are out of line with capacity to pay, with the productivity increases, and so on. We are not here to argue for lower wages. Surely, Senator Button is not arguing for lower wages for the sake of lower wages. Presumably, he wants what we want, which is higher wages-but we want sustainable higher wages.
—Real wages.

—Yes. What we want is a system which will promote, as far as possible, higher real wages. I refer back to what Charles Fitzgibbon had to say in 1986. He described so clearly the deficiencies of a system where a man who works badly is paid as well as the man who works well. He sketches in a very clear way the lack of incentive for improvement in our system. We are looking to the capacity of people to look for ways to improve their productivity, with a greater share of the profit and a greater share for the employees.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, in relation to the South East Queensland Electricity Board-with SEQEB now being a buzz word for a negative reaction on the Labor Party's side, no doubt-it is worth examining what the people there were trying to achieve and what they are in fact achieving, namely, higher wages and lower electricity costs. Surely, that is the combination we are after.

So, to get back to the matter of outcomes, what we are saying is that, ideally, provided we have a situation where the individual micro outcomes are right, then the macro outcomes will be all right. How does one ensure that? There are two points here. We are not suggesting that employers and employees be thrown to the wolves; we are saying that they should go into the market-place when it suits them-not otherwise. With respect to the centralised system, under which umbrella many will remain-perhaps they will all remain, but that is their choice and not ours-we sketch out that we would be pursuing the same sort of control of aggregate wage outcomes and so on as would be pursued by the present Government. Senator Button might jump up and say, `Aha, you will not have an accord'. Well, the accord has not always delivered what it said it would deliver. I concede that it has been an expression of the cooperation between the trade union movement and the Government. I accept that that has been a great strength for the Government.

I believe that in the current situation we would have had as amicable an arrangement with the trade union movement-indeed, a more appropriate arrangement with the trade union movement-with respect to the approach that should be adopted in terms of wage rises and tax reductions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can tell tall stories.

—I am simply saying that judgments will differ. But I would have thought, had I been not in opposition but in government over the last six or eight months, that the task I would have had would have certainly focused on the need to restrain aggregate wage outcomes. I would have been looking at the wage tax mix in a quite different way from the way that the present Government has chosen to do. I think the weakness of the accord in the present circumstances is that it has enabled the Government to get away with blue murder on the tax front. The reality is that Senator Childs's ex-colleagues in the trade union movement have been denied a tax cut until next year on a basis which I think is probably economically destructive in the longer term. I think the Government has got itself into a terrible bind about where it might be at the end of this financial year and moving into the next.

SPEECH.PARA: Fundamentally, what I am saying is that those people who move out into the agreements area on the more level playing field that our totality of policy provides, with proper compliance provisions, voluntary unionism and all the rest of it, will not be upsetting the macro outcomes. We will have even stronger barriers between the agreement and the arbitrated sectors of the system. We had some discussions earlier tonight about the barrier this Government is erecting between registered agreements and awards. So we will be using much the same sorts of mechanisms. What we have to offer the work force in terms of gaining its support and cooperation is the prospect of a better future. We were really told off when we said that a lot of workers would like employee-share ownership as part of the sweetening of the system, the encouraging of common enterprise, common purpose and involvement. I am delighted that the Government has picked up that ball now. The majority of major corporations in this country have also picked up that ball and run with it.

One has to look at the whole totality of approach when responding to the point that was made by Senator Button-how to control our aggregate outcomes. We do it by having a continuance of the centralised system with much the same disciplines as we have now-in fact with some additional disciplines. We will have an opting out process which will encourage a move to higher productivity which is the key to improved wages in a way which is not damaging to aggregate wage outcomes.

That is a fairly discursive response to the point which was made by Senator Button. But I think he made an important point which, in a sense, is central to this debate. I am sorry that writers like Ms Williams are, in my view, a bit too mesmerised by what they see as the golden success of the accord. I would see a system which is delivering diminishing living standards and high nominal wage rises as pretty pathetic. In terms of outcomes I do not think the situation is very satisfactory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Chaney that the accord has allowed the Government to get away with blue murder with respect to taxation cuts and that in fact we are moving to a situation next year in which it is possible that low income earners will not receive tax cuts and that the higher income groups will have their tax cut from 49c to 39c in the dollar. I can support what Senator Chaney said by referring the Committee to the fact that many people employed under existing Federal awards are on wages or salaries from which they have to sustain a number of dependants. This Government has ignored the plight of those middle income groups. It applies a taxing system which taxes their incomes without any regard to their dependants. That is one of the very major problems that we have to address in the forthcoming months. Amendment (4) put forward by Senator Chaney seeks to insert the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: `(ba) to encourage adherence to the rule of law in industrial relations;
`(bb) to encourage direct dealing between employers and employees within each enterprise;
`(bc) to minimise interference in relation to enterprises by persons or bodies who have no direct interest in those enterprises; and
`(bd) to facilitate the consolidation of single enterprise bargaining units;'.
In a perfect world there would be very little wrong and very few problems with that type of approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are they not good objectives in an admittedly imperfect world?

—Because they will not work. They ignore the aspects of greed and self-interest. That is the problem. What is going to happen under this proposal in a period of high employment? We are going to get people who will agree in order to get a job.
—Under duress.

—In fact, under duress they will agree to wage rates and conditions which are substandard. On the other hand, this will work against the employer in periods of high employment and very low unemployment. Demands will be made for standards of income and employment which are super for standards of income and employment and, which are super for employees but which will tend to create a two-class society.

SPEECH.PARA: I think one thing of note that has occurred in the industrial scene over the years since 1904 when the Conciliation and Arbitration Act first became law is the recognition of the need to recompense employees for the work that they perform irrespective of where they are employed. I know that some differentials have crept into the system but, by and large, this system has worked reasonably well. It is a system which has worked almost irrespective of the structure of the trade union movement.

People have attempted to suggest that the structure of the trade union movement is the problem. I refer honourable senators to the final report in October 1982 of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation. Page 15 and subsequent pages of that report detail the history of moves from 1884 onwards to restructure the trade union movement in Australia. I do not intend to dwell on that matter, but it will be an interesting exercise for honourable senators to read the Senate Select Committee report. What we must understand is that it is not so much the structure of the trade union movement that is critical to the successful operation of any industrial relations system; it is the desire on the part of the parties to that system to see that it works.

One of the problems that I foresee with Senator Chaney's proposition is that it will tend to undermine or make unworkable what appears to have been the objective of the Commission, the Government and, I believe, the Opposition over the last few years: that is, to provide incentive for restructuring and efficiency in awards of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and of the various State industrial tribunals.

The latest judgment of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission emphasised what it has termed the new structural efficiency principle. Under that new structural efficiency principle, the proposed award increase of 3 per cent and $10 is not available to any organisation that will not give an undertaking to the Commission to abide by the principle. That requires the trade unions to establish skill related career paths which provide an incentive to workers to continue to participate in skill formation; to eliminate impediments to multi-skilling and broadening the range of tasks that a worker may be required to perform; to create appropriate relativities between different categories of workers within the award and at the enterprise level; and to ensure that working patterns and arrangements enhance flexibility and meet the competitive requirements of the industry. There are a number of other requirements.

The point that I am making here is that the Commission says, `You are not going to get a 3 per cent increase or a $10 increase unless you agree to abide by these provisions'. It is really only the registered industrial organisations that are capable, firstly, of giving that undertaking to the Commission in a formal sense and, secondly, of ultimately delivering on it, because it will be able to be delivered by the exercise of the rules of the organisation. If a group of shop stewards in a particular industry says to its union, `We are not going to abide by that rubbish; we are not going to abide by what the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission says', that puts in jeopardy the rest of the members of that organisation.

Under the proposal that Senator Chaney put forward `to minimise interference in relation to enterprises by persons or bodies who have no direct interest in those enterprises', presumably the Federal executive, the Federal management committee or the national council of the relevant organisation may not even be able to exercise authority over the group concerned by the use of the provisions of its rules. Senator Chaney may not mean that; maybe I have misunderstood him. But I am very firm on the need for representative industrial organisations to be responsible and to be able to give the types of guarantees that the Commission has sought in its two most recent national wage judgments.

I remind Senator Chaney that when there was full employment one of Albert Monk's greatest problems was with the shop steward organisations in the early and mid-1960s. I remember it well. I was on the Australian Council of Trade Unions executive. I see Senator Burns half smiling in his place. We were rather concerned about what was happening. It tended to be an anarchy. If we put this structure into place it might work to the disadvantage of the employees at this time, and during a period of high employment and low unemployment it could well work the other way. My view is that there ought to be a structure which enables a degree of flexibility-and I think the Government has gone far enough down that track-but emphasises the need for an egalitarian attitude to the work force so that we do not develop in Australia a situation which exists in some other countries, such as the United States of America, which have very highly paid groups and people doing the same types of work for very low pay.

I come to the final point. What are we talking about when we talk about industry or enterprise? I believe that my comments here are as much a reflection on the Government's approach as they are on the Opposition's approach. Remember, I have stated, and I believe it to be correct, that it is not so much the structure of the trade union movement that results in a better industrial outcome; it is the desire of the parties to the system to see that it works and to see that orderly industrial progress is achieved. So I come to the point as to what people mean when they are talking about industry unions or enterprise unions. I suppose, being a State President of the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association and a member of the national council, it is all right for me to say that for the retail industry, `We will have anything that moves in the retail industry, thank you very much'. But our view in that regard may not be shared by some other people. For example, the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union may not share that viewpoint. In fact the Electrical Trades Union may not share that viewpoint.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enjoyed listening to Senator Harradine. I just say to him that I am glad to have his agreement about the Government getting away with murder on middle income earners. I want to raise with the Committee Senator Harradine's suggestion that we need the system for restructuring. I think some would argue quite the reverse-that it is because of the system that we have such an urgent need for restructuring; that the system has delivered this complexity which is in so many cases counterproductive. I think most of us would welcome the attempts to reduce that complexity and to get a better situation for the employer and the employee that is inherent in the award restructuring arrangements being pursued in the metal trades area.

SPEECH.PARA: One does not require the system to involve restructuring. I refer Senator Harradine to the description of what has been happening with respect to restructuring the South East Queensland Electricity Board (SEQEB) which is set out in the industrial relations and management letter, which is the title of the publication-volume 5, issue No. 7. It points out that there has been major restructuring within SEQEB as part of its moving out of the system. Indeed, it has the flexibility to make changes. I think that the other route is potentially just as valuable. I have absolutely no doubt-or as little doubt as one can have about these things-that the metal trades restructuring will produce substantial gains for employers and employees. I very much fear that what Senator Harradine quoted with approval from the most recent national wage case will prove in many cases, as indeed did some of the second tier negotiations, to be words rather than action.

It is rather sobering to recall that the 3 per cent and the $10 rely not upon the parties acting upon the words read to the Committee by Senator Harradine, but simply involve an agreement to commence a process of discussion about it. That will make the next round terribly important. Indeed, it will make the approach of employers over the next 12 months terribly important to the extent to which they and the unions grasp the nettle of turning that agreement to talk into something which does mean something. I do not believe, I say in response to Senator Harradine, that it is an essential part of obtaining the restructuring we all seek that we remain within the system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it difficult to see anything but hypocrisy in what Senator Chaney has said. I would like to be wrong, but he seems to show concern about workers being able to negotiate higher wages. As Senator Chaney was a member of a government which, in 1982-83, was responsible for a wage freeze which denied workers the opportunity to negotiate any wage increase, that statement seems to indicate a fair deal of hypocrisy. Senator Chaney talked about the difficulty of people negotiating substantial enterprise agreements, or registered agreements, within the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, given the current arbitration legislation and the amendments suggested by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I say unequivocally that, under the present Commission legislation and the amendments offered by the Government, it is perfectly legitimate-and the opportunity is there-for negotiations to take place. What would prevent them from taking place, in terms of the level of wages and the standard of conditions that would be negotiated into those awards, would be the policy decisions of the Commission, in considering its responsibilities, including its community responsibilities, which would restrict wage levels or the national wage decision that it makes from year to year. It is total rubbish to suggest that the proposed Act denies these steps being taken: that is not true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Harradine's time had expired, he asked: What is an industry union and what is an enterprise union? I am not one of those who would say that we should copy willy-nilly what might be good in another country, because we are a special country: we are different from other countries. But we can learn from other places. We are aware of the Australia Reconstructed document and the fact that the Australian Council of Trade Unions pushed very hard for fewer unions-super unions, if honourable senators wish. I warn this chamber about the danger and I will give an example. We are all very much aware, as would be the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who are in the chamber, of the problems in the coal industry. The coal industry would be the closest thing that I know of in this country to an industry based union. Yet it has a record second to none in regard to disputation and continued disputation.
—Forty times the national average.

—I thank Senator Chaney. As a result, our reliability overseas has been tarnished. That reputation flows on to every other industry. I know that Senator Button is doing what he can to improve our exports situation, but that is a classic example of what can happen with an industry based union. I know that Senator Harradine has some strong views-he has spoken in this place after I have spoken on the matter-on closed shops and preference clauses. I will come to that later. The closed shop principle is an absolutely essential part, and has been for many years, of the industry, to the extent-it works both ways-that, if a union perceives a member to be recalcitrant, it can actually threaten him with the withdrawal of his ticket. Senator Burns knows all about that.
—I have heard about it.
—Often.
—Not often.

—Even though we should not copy exactly things that happen in other countries, we should look at those countries that have been successful. By far the most successful country-certainly since the war-has been Japan, followed by the Koreans who followed the Japanese system to a large extent. A former member of the Australian Democrats, Senator Siddons, was very much enamoured of the Japanese system. One cannot help but be enamoured of the Japanese system because it has been successful: that is the test. It is not a matter of saying, as some of the more left wing militant unions would say, that, if a country is successful it is QED; the workers are oppressed. One cannot say that in Japan. The Japanese have tightened their belt. They have worked hard. They are now getting the fruits of that hard work.
—What about the spring offensive?

—I have forgotten whether that was a spring offensive or a summer offensive. It was totally predictable and, if my memory is correct, it occurred only in certain industries. It was predictable, and that is the complaint that is made: one could predict it, forecast it and allow for it, so the machinery did not come to a grinding halt. I have made those remarks about what I perceive as the danger of having a few super unions and comparing those unions with the enterprise unions in Japan. Japan has a multitude of unions. In the main, they are associated with particular companies. They all kick in the same direction and that is what we need to do in this country. There must be a change of attitude. I said at the second reading stage of the Bill that I did not think this was contributing one iota to the attitudinal change that we need in this country. We need employees to work in the same direction as employers. We need a recognition that the productivity of organisations must increase, that we are on the world stage and that we are competing. I do not have to remind people that this is an economic war. Everyone needs to take the view that the success of a particular company depends on the productive efforts of everyone within that organisation. If it becomes productive, if we can get rid of some of the things that are still referred to as hard won gains and can get on to the world stage, everyone will benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently we saw the machinations that occurred in the coal mining industry. There was revulsion about getting rid of hard won gains and so on. Yet, by not getting rid of those restrictive work practices that were put in place over two or three decades, the workers were destroying their own jobs. Mines went out of business because they were unproductive. Yet that could not or would not be seen. That is the attitude that must be changed. Hence, this shows the sense of direction that we in the Liberal Party have taken towards the enterprise based unions so that people-men and women-are working in organisations. Again I refer to ex-Senator Siddons. He put this system into practice and it was very successful. In fact, he introduced a Bill in this place in an effort to encourage other organisations to follow his lead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Metal Workers Union worked for him.

—All I am saying is that it was successful. It was fought against by some unions which wanted to become big and powerful and take the decision making process out of the workplace, out of the coal face, that is a mistake.
—He doesn't have an enterprise union.
—He does have an enterprise union.
—He does not.

—In practice he has an enterprise union. I will give some other examples. I have heard Senator Button in the past refer to the success of Nucleonics, the Paul Trainor run organisation. I know that Senator Button is very proud of that and so he should be, so we all should be.
—Nucleus, it is called.

—Thank you, Senator Button. It employs 400 or 500 people and is one of the greatest export examples that we need in this country. It is totally enterprise based. It supplies about 40 per cent of the world's heart pacemakers. I am saying that honourable senators should look at those successful organisation and learn from them. Another good example in my home State is Palmer Tube Mills Ltd., one of the growth organisations. Ross Palmer was on one of Senator Button's consultative committees. I am somewhat surprised that having seen the success of those particular organisations the Government has not taken notice of them. We need many more Nucleus organisations and many more Palmer Tube Mills. If we could achieve that in this country we would be out of a lot of the trouble that we are in.
—Tubemakers, too.
—I do not know about Tubemakers of Australia Ltd. It used to have a lot of problems but it may have improved in recent times. I was talking about Palmer Tube Mills.
—Members of the FIA; it is not an enterprise union.
—It operates as an enterprise union.
—No, it is not.

—Senator Burns is wrong. He should go and see that organisation. It might not want to see him as he may scare the pants off it and destroy what is a productive organisation. I am saying that we need more of these organisations. That is the thrust of our policy and I think it is the direction in which this country needs to go in if we are going to change the whole attitude of people. I know it is going to be tough because there are a few people like Senator Burns wandering about who would prefer to see--
—I am not against productivity.

—Would Senator Burns be prepared to trade some productivity for dollars? I have heard people from his side say that they will never trade productivity for dollars, because they would give up hard won gains. This is not entirely the problem but attitude is a major part of the problem. East is east and west is west and never the twain shall meet. The Government has a vested interest in doing that. It is not necessarily, and never has been, in the main an employer attitude. I would like to reinforce the remarks of Senator Chaney and state that I think this whole attitude of the structure of unions-the major key element of this Bill-is going in the wrong direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want anybody to get me wrong but I think everybody is going to rue the day we restructure the trade union movement. The proposed restructuring of the trade union movement will bring it down to 10 or 20 major industrial organisations. This will mean that there will be a greater possibility for those organisations, rich and powerful as they will be, to make their own decisions irrespective of what anybody else thinks and they will thumb their noses at central organisations such as the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I think that we will see some problems as a result of that. As we observed in the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation there is considerable doubt amongst the industrial relations community that unions' structures predominantly determine industrial relations outcomes. I think that is correct. Honourable senators should think about which companies are the most prosperous in Australia. They should think of Mr Elliott's company or Mr Bond's company. The brewing industry is probably one of the most profitable organisations in this country. What are the union structures there? Those companies have a multitude of unions.
—There is an insatiable demand for the product.
—That has nothing to do with union structures, I venture to suggest.
—Therefore, one should not be prescriptive.

—Senator Chaney has a point but we also have to have an authoritative group that will negotiate, having regard to the general effect that those negotiations are going to have on other members of the work force and other industries. I know what Senator Chaney is going to say. He is going to build a strong barrier between that sort of certified agreement-maybe it will not be a certified agreement-and consent awards or other awards.
—Clause 95 plus.

—I understand what Senator Chaney is talking about. The reality is that it is not going to work because if those organisations are going to achieve victories along the way it will seep inevitably into the system. I have a lot more to say but I do not propose to say it tonight. I think we have had enough discussion on this matter and I propose to sit down.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 2, clause 3, line 14, before ``to encourage'' insert ``to provide for freedom of association, and''.
Amendment No. (5) circulated in my name is another amendment to the object clause. Object (f) reads:
to encourage the organisation of representative bodies of employers and employees and their registration under this Act;
It is proposed that this should read:
to provide for freedom of association, and to encourage the organisation of representative bodies of employers and employees and their registration under this Act.

The additional point which we seek to insert is a point which I understand in a theoretical sense is much beloved of the Government. I was fortunate to be sent to Geneva by the Government to the International Labour Organisation (ILO) this year and I made the acquaintance of some members of the Department of Industrial Relations. One of the things I enjoyed most was going to the committee where member nations were being taken to task for their failure to live up to the ideals of the ILO-perhaps less the ideals than the conventions. The first experience I had of the ILO was listening to a very severe drubbing being given to the Polish contingent for its failure to honour the principles of freedom of association. I enjoyed it enormously. It actually removed some of my concerns about the ILO because I found the exchange very free, frank and highly critical. I forget the name of the senior employee representative-I am not getting much help from the officials who were also enjoying themselves in Geneva at the time-but the point is it was a forthright and highly critical attack on the Polish delegation about the limitations on freedom of association in Poland.

I might say that the very good impression that was made was somewhat diminished when on the last day I listened to, I think, the Liberian delegation getting a caning about the conditions on Liberian registered ships. The force of this was somewhat broken by the fact that one of the delegates pointed out that this was the twentieth annual drubbing that the Liberians had received on this subject, which made me think that perhaps the severe admonitions that the Poles were receiving were not making as deep an impression as I had hoped. But the point is that the Government is committed to a series of both ILO and human rights conventions which pay respect to the principle of freedom of association. The actual reality in Australia is quite different because, in a number of respects, freedom of association is not respected in this country. There is de facto compulsory unionism. Certainly, I have seen plenty of places around Australia with the sign up, `No ticket, no start'. We are aware of the struggles that some people have had to withstand membership of a trade union. That is one side of the lack of freedom; the freedom not to associate if that is one's choice.
