No matter how much Ministers might say there is no compulsory unionism in this country there is, de facto, through the preference clause and through industrial muscle, the enforcement of the requirement of trade union membership in many circumstances. That is one element.

The other element, of course, is that there is a very highly structured and controlled situation with respect to registered organisations. The Australian laws contain detailed provisions as to what is to happen if people wish to form new organisations and obtain registration for them or to break up or divide up existing organisations. The legislation which is before us now is no exception. It contains very rigid, strict controls on the organisations which can be formed or changed.

In terms of freedom of association there is a very substantial inroad in this country in the sense that one may well find that although one wishes to form an organisation-one might have a group of workers who are perfectly of one mind about wishing to associate together in their common interest-the `conveniently belong' rule I think is one of the things that can be used to prevent one from forming an association in an area in which an existing registered organisation can claim that it can provide coverage.

I think that there is an important question of civil liberties involved here. I put that in a category of its own. The question is whether we should have laws in Australia which prevent people from having the right to join or not join a trade union. I think that that can be looked at as an issue of individual freedom. We are very good at lecturing people around the world and lecturing each other on these subjects but in my view it is very hard to argue that a man or woman should be denied the right to join or not join. Perhaps I have put insufficient stress so far on that point. I think that the freedom of people to form associations and join them should be a matter that one is just as passionate about as their freedom not to join. There tends to be on our side of politics for natural reasons a preponderance of concern about the right not to join when one is an unwilling conscript. But, of course, the theory on which we operate and the practical basis on which we operate is that there ought also to be freedom for people to join trade unions. One of the disappointments of the collapsed human rights debate in the chamber when the Government withdrew the Bill was that we were looking forward to inserting into the human rights legislation a guarantee that people were free to join and not to join trade unions. We thought that that would have been an interesting test of the Government's bona fides in respect of that legislation but, unfortunately, the Government whipped it out from under us.

However, to turn from the question of civil liberties-I do not wish in any sense to appear to make light of the question because I think it is fundamentally important to the economic side of it-it seems to me, to go back over some of the discussion we have had in the course of this evening, that in terms of encouraging productive relationships within Australian workplaces there are huge advantages to be gained in having a greater degree of freedom to form such associations as would contribute to the welfare of the parties involved within an enterprise rather than their being conscripted or forced to join organisations which have interests which are not necessarily the same as the interests of those parties. I should stress that the Opposition is not seeking to be prescriptive. One might look at the Vehicle Builders Union as a fascinating example of an industry union which has within its structure adopted an approach which gives it a lot of the advantages of an enterprise union. The approach seems to be one in which one gets the overriding servicing capacity of a large industry union and yet, in terms of the plan manufacturers, as I understand it, there is an award within each plan manufacturer. I suppose that is something that is not the same as but which reflects some of the pattern in the United States where a large industry union or, indeed, a large craft union will have local branches which in many respects are self-sufficient, except for major issues, and which might receive servicing from the overriding union structure.

We are not saying that we would wish to interfere in any way with a structure such as the Vehicle Builders Union. Indeed, we would not seek under our proposals to adopt a prescriptive view at all. We are genuinely providing opportunities for people to form organisations in the pattern that they themselves want. We believe that the whole of the modern economic process will tend to mould those organisations into organisations which are more suitable rather than less suitable to the economic interests of both sides of the equation. We do not leave it completely at large. We are not totally pure in our approach in the amendments we have put forward. We do not give complete unsullied support to the principle of freedom of association because we do, in so far as there are registered associations, retain a supervisory role in respect of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission just to advance the interests of producing single enterprise bargaining units as far as possible. That is the sole basis of public interference that we provide to the principle of freedom of association in respect of registered organisations.

With respect to the balance of the system-the system which operates outside the Conciliation and Arbitration Act-we are proposing genuine and complete freedom of association. In other words, there would be no public control over the associations which were formed within organisations that were choosing to regulate their industrial relations by agreement. We think that the economic pressure would be towards single bargaining units. That would vary a lot. For example, in a public hospital one might well find a situation in which people chose to associate in the various sorts of professional categories that exist within a hospital with a wide range of professions. In other words, again we are not prescriptive about that. I suppose that one of the fascinating representations that came to me in the course of considering this legislation was that made to me by, I think, the Ambulance Union. It may have been called the Ambulance Drivers Union; I do not remember the precise title. That was an example of a small group that had actually been part of a larger organisation. What that group said to me was: `We were just being used as an industrial battering ram. We were all the time having industrial disputes. We are now a separate small union but, in fact, we have an amiable and, in our view, productive and constructive relationship with our employers. We feel that it is a much more satisfactory situation'. That is the sort of anecdotal situation, if one likes, of the virtue of giving people the freedom to form organisations that will suit them and their economic requirements.

Therefore, we think that this is an important principle on two separate but related efforts. We have glasnost and perestroika in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics because the truth is that economic progress probably is only possible for the Soviet Union if there is greater freedom. That might be a very extreme comparison to draw but I think that in those countries that cause Senator Button's brow to furrow when he looks at the problem of our becoming internationally competitive it would probably be genuinely true to say that there is more freedom rather than less when we compare their industrial relations arrangements with our own. That is not universally so but I think that would probably be a fair generalisation. Therefore, we see that there is a civil liberties argument which is important and there is a basic issue of freedom, the rights of the men and women of Australia that we wish to assert and protect better than the existing law and this Bill would provide. We see that as being very much in the economic interests of Australia as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want tonight to say a few words about the Victorian election campaign. It is a campaign that has been highlighted by a series of dirty tricks, on the part of the Cain Labor Government, that is unprecedented in Victoria's history. One can only imagine what is going to eventuate between now and the election on Saturday. I want to mention particularly one dirty trick that arose today. It is part of a pattern that has emerged over the last week. The first dirty trick occurred a week or so ago when an advertisement was shown on television in which the Premier pledged that the typical Victorian family will not pay $1 more over the next four years for electricity, gas and public transport charges, sewerage and water rates.

SPEECH.PARA: That is simply not true if one can believe the content of the prospectus that was put out by the Victorian Treasurer, Mr Jolly, when he launched the Victorian Equity Trust several months ago. From that prospectus it is clear that the typical Victorian family will pay an extra $496 over the next four years from September of this year in electricity and gas charges and Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works rates. The Government is claiming that from those increases should be deducted the promised increase in the Victorian education allowance. But I quote from the relevant Budget Papers, which show that that allowance has always been intended to assist the family to meet, at the beginning of the school year, various expenses associated with school attendance. I take that quotation from page 9 of Budget Paper No. 2 in the 1987-88 Budget. But even if one did take into account the education allowances that have been promised, the typical family would still pay more per year than is now the case. Therefore the pledge by Premier Cain is blatantly incorrect. That was the first of the dirty tricks that appeared in the last week.

Another one occurred shortly after, with the Premier's letter to voters in several marginal electorates in Victoria. That letter claimed, among other things, that the Government has `halved motor registration fees and that motor registration fees will be abolished from 1 July 1989'. That also is a statement that is blatantly not true. The Government's undertaking to reduce and abolish registration fees relates only to renewal fees for motor vehicles and then only to private A class registered cars and cars owned by pensioners. All people have still to pay the registration fees on the purchase of a new vehicle, and except for those categories that I just mentioned they will still have to pay renewal fees as well.

The Premier's letter also claimed that the Government `has got rid of stamp duty for low income earners'. That again is blatantly not true. I point out that it was a commitment made in the 1988-89 Budget which has not yet been passed, and even before it has been passed in the Parliament it has been trampled on by the Government as completely out of date. In the Budget statement it is said that stamp duty will be abolished where three conditions are met. The first is where the property purchased is valued at $100,000 or less. The second is where the purchaser or purchasers meet the income test under the Commonwealth's first home owners scheme. The third is where the purchasers have dependants. None of those three conditions was mentioned in the letter that the Premier sent to voters in marginal electorates. I believe that that is a disgraceful example of yet another dirty trick by this Government in a dirty tricks campaign which is, as I said, unprecedented in Victoria's history and which now builds on a very long history of this type of activity by the Australian Labor Party in electioneering.

The classic example that one recalls in recent history was the Nunawading how-to-vote scandal at the last State election-a scandal which has scarred and tarred the Labor Party for years to come. The third dirty trick that I want to mention occurred today. On public buses in Melbourne today `Support Public Transport. Return the Labor Government' signs appeared on vehicles running around, owned by the Government and operated by the Metropolitan Transit Authority. Those slogans were apparently put on the buses by the transport unions. If the Metropolitan Transit Authority gave the unions permission to do this, obviously the Authority stands condemned for a blatantly political act.

Signs on public transport are always regarded as advertising and must therefore be paid for, unless they are specifically a community service advertisement. This slogan by the transport unions is obviously not a community service advertisement, so I want to know whether the unions paid for these signs. If so, were the unions charged normal commercial rates? If not, on what basis was permission given to have these blatantly political signs placed on public transport vehicles in the city of Melbourne? If the Metropolitan Transit Authority did not give permission for this advertising, it must immediately have all the signs removed. If this is not done, there could be no clearer indication that the Metropolitan Transit Authority in Victoria is improperly exercising a blatant pro-Labor political bias.

To me this is a matter of extreme importance. It is a disgrace that a public utility can be used in this way in the week running up to a vital State election to so blatantly propagandise the political fortunes of a party which has been in power for 6 1/2 years and has brought the State of Victoria virtually to financial bankruptcy by indulging in huge expenditure on matters such as public transport, despite the fact that it is running at a horrendous loss each year. When all those things are considered, the idea that this type of activity can be allowed to pass without the greatest condemnation and action being taken to correct it is a further example of the extent to which the Cain Labor Government in Victoria has allowed all standards of integrity and morality in politics to slip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Senate to the affairs of the Morwell Migrant Resource Centre. This centre has been operating for quite some time but in recent months there have been a number of matters of serious concern not only to members of the migrant community in the Latrobe Valley but also to the citizenry at large. Of paramount concern at present is what can be described only as either woeful and wilful ignorance on the part of the local Federal member, the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), and the outgoing State member, Ms Callister, or indeed a cover-up of the financial affairs of the centre.

SPEECH.PARA: I will recite the sorry litany of events that have occurred in recent weeks. The first matter that came to the attention of the public was expression of concern by the centre's treasurer that all was not well. Subsequently, the Liberal candidate, Mr Norman Olsen, was invited to look for himself and ascertain whether there were matters of genuine concern. Having looked into the matter, I say that Mr Olsen acted with responsibility and sensitivity. He offered to meet with the chairman of the centre, Mr Don Ferguson, and to sit down with the board of management and act as a liaison person between management and the migrant community. He ultimately called for an inquiry into the running of the centre but was met merely by howls of denunciation and allegations on the part of Mr Cunningham that this was simply a politically motivated attack. By that I presume he meant that there was no substance to the allegations and that Mr Olsen was simply attempting to make use of the community concern for political purposes. The facts are quite contrary to that and I regard Mr Cunningham's behaviour as quite outrageous in the circumstances.

What has now come to light is that not only have these concerns been expressed over a period of months but also they were brought to the attention of both local members, who did absolutely nothing about them for a period of some weeks. It was only then that Mr Olsen was called in. What has not been revealed to date and what I think is of very great concern is that, despite the suggestions that somehow there was nothing other than an attempt at a political beat-up, that really there was nothing that need trouble the scorers, that really there was only a personality conflict, in fact a Commonwealth auditor was brought in to investigate the financial affairs of the centre. He came down from Canberra on the 19th of this month and examined the books. He found a number of very serious irregularities. In particular, he made a clear finding that the centre had been receiving more funds than it needed and made a deliberate decision that funds should be cut back, that payments should be made only on a monthly basis, and that all moneys needed to be banked in Canberra and not locally.

It is a matter of particular concern that the auditor for the centre happens to be a local accountant and also a member of the board. I would have thought that was a classic example of a conflict of interest. One expects the auditor of any organisation, let alone one that is funded by government, to have some degree of arm's length impartiality and to make judgments not affected by his own position in the matter. But the auditor was very intimately involved in the affairs of the association and clearly not wanting to have the matter become publicly known.

Indeed, the Commonwealth auditor found that there were a number of other matters of serious concern, in particular that the centre had very high travelling expenses paid quite indiscriminately to members of the board. There was no proper documentation. Any person wishing to travel to Melbourne was simply given $100 cash and there was no requirement for any accountability. Income received was not always recorded in the books, quite contrary to any normal accounting practices. There was no mention in the books of the centre of a bank account containing in excess of $2,000-in fact $2,168. The auditing procedures left a lot to be desired. There were a number of pay slips which were not signed; employees were paid in cash. Cleaning had been done by two employees who had also been paid in cash but payments had been recorded in fictitious names and no signatures had been obtained.

It is quite clear that the affairs of the centre are an absolute disgrace, that there is a great deal of financial and other skulduggery going on. It has been the deliberate design of the local members of parliament and, indeed, those associated with the conduct of the centre to try to keep the lid on its affairs, at least until after the State election. One can think of no other motivation because quite clearly there is a very urgent need for the affairs of the centre to be properly and impartially investigated. Belatedly, the board of management is now suggesting that somehow it had requested that the books be inspected by an independent Commonwealth auditor, Mr Ka-Lee. The reality is that Mr Ka-Lee was brought in quite independently because of a number of matters that have now been shown to be valid.

The Victorian community in particular needs to be made aware of the cynical manipulation of this issue not by the Liberal candidate, Mr Olsen, but indeed by those who ought to have been in a position to know better, people who have made allegations of political motivation when in fact that can be the only explanation for their desperate desire not to have these matters aired in public. In conclusion, I believe that there is an urgent need for the report of the auditor to be made public. There also needs to be a full public inquiry into the affairs of the centre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief at this hour with the matters I wish to raise concerning the provision of legal aid and funding for it. I refer particularly to a press release of the Law Council of Australia headed `Legal Aid' which was issued on 15 September 1988. To save going through the press release in the detail that I otherwise might, I shall seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
LEGAL AID
The President of the Law Council of Australia, Mr Denis Byrne, said today that if urgent action was not taken soon, legal aid would cease to be available to many deserving applicants.

The need for such action had arisen because of the inadequate provision made for legal aid in the recent Budget. Funding had been maintained at present monetary levels only, which meant a substantial reduction in real terms.

Mr Byrne said the Commonwealth appeared also to be endeavouring to pass some of its responsibility for funding legal aid to the State Governments. There was a real danger that persons in need of assistance would be `the meat in the sandwich'.
Mr Byrne said the matter was of increasing concern to the legal profession, which remained prepared to make its fair contribution to society in this area.
``The profession is already undertaking extensive legal aid work on the basis that less than normal charges will apply,'' he said.
``However, the situation has now been reached where the profession is being expected to do this work at rates that are unrealistically low.
``One consequence is that many practitioners simply cannot afford to undertake legal aid work. There are, however, other undesirable consequences for the integrity of the administration of justice.

``In the area of prosecutions, for example, an unacceptable position exists in that counsel engaged by a legal aid body are being paid so much less than the scale being paid to counsel for the prosecution that questions arise in regard to inequality of representation. Legally-aided persons should not be placed in a worse position than other litigants.

``The Commonwealth must face up to the need to make adequate provision for legal aid, and it should be accepted that the funding of legal aid is a proper charge on consolidated revenue. However, there is in addition a need to make the legal aid dollar go further and all ways of achieving this must be explored.

``In particular, there is a need for some drastic cost cutting to be undertaken by the Legal Aid Commissions. The Law Council is concerned that the Commissions are using valuable funds in supporting costly administrative procedures. There should be more concern to ensure that the funds are used to assist deserving applicants for aid. Bureaucratic arrangements for providing legal aid tend to be inefficient.

``The Law Council is also concerned that aid is being provided to support some proceedings that have no merit. This is a wastage that cannot be condoned. There should be a more rigorous examination of the merits of applications and the assistance of private practitioners for this purpose should be availed of. The profession stands ready to provide this assistance.
``Another way to make the legal aid dollar go further is to insist on recipients of legal aid contributing more to the cost of their proceedings.

``Court procedures must also be examined to eliminate the need for unnecessary action. The Law Council will be giving close consideration to this aspect of the matter. A committee will also be examining the scope for alternative methods of dispute resolution. However, the courts themselves and the Governments must take their own initiatives.''
15 September 1988
Further information: Trevor Bennett (062) 47 3788

TALK.START.PARA: —Legal aid is an important part of the judicial system. The funding for it must be adequate to ensure that those needs are met and that those who need aid to get before the courts are able to get it on a proper basis. The press release I have incorporated refers to the need for there to be a fair return for solicitors and lawyers who provide service. These days, in many instances, there are solicitors who no longer will work in the area because the return is so low as to make it quite impractical. For many years, and certainly during the time that I was more familiar with it, legal aid work was done at a considerable discount but reasonably happily by those who participated. In many instances, that is no longer the case. We find instances in which a person defending someone is being paid effectively with Commonwealth money at a much lower rate than the person who is prosecuting. There are anomalies of that kind in the system. The imbalance in that area needs to be looked at closely to ensure that there is some real balance and fairness in the representation that is made available.

SPEECH.PARA: This press release refers to administrative waste. I refer briefly to a matter I have raised previously in the Senate of aid being granted for cases which really are of academic interest only. The case I am thinking of related to a man who was in gaol, having been convicted of murder. He was subsequently convicted of a couple of other murders and wished to appeal in relation to them, the very pedantic issue being whether the offences had occurred on this or that side of the Australian Capital Territory-New South Wales border. Had it been found to be one or the other-whichever was relevant-it made not the slightest difference to whether or not he stayed in gaol. Allowing the matter to proceed to the High Court seemed to me to be a luxury; the legal aid money really ought to have been saved for some other purpose. I suspect that there are other anomalies of a similar kind. The Law Council refers to its commitment to looking for alternative methods. It calls upon the Government to do so as well. I add my voice to that and hope that there will be a review of legal aid to see that it is administered and provided in the best possible way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three speakers from the Opposition have spoken in the adjournment debate tonight, and I think that exhausts the list of prospective speakers. On behalf of the Government, perhaps I can say to Senator Reid that I have taken an interest in the things that she has said. I am aware that there are always complaints in relation to the administration of legal aid. One never hears of the approval or the appreciation that is expressed, because that is often done privately. However, I will ensure that the matters that Senator Reid has raised are referred to the appropriate Minister, and if he wishes to further comment on those matters, he will no doubt do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that the adjournment debate tonight has been used by Senators Short and Alston as an opportunity to try to beat up some interest in the Victorian State election campaign-and here we are with this occurring on the Tuesday before the poll on Saturday. Rather than hearing this rather nebulous, sorry and transparent litany of complaints from those two senators, I would have expected to see perhaps Senator Grant Chapman rise to his feet and make an explanation as to why he sought registration as a business agent for business migration programs, or I would have expected to see senators opposite standing, and distancing themselves from the actions of Senator Alston, to make it clear that they do not want there to be any confusion in the mind of the public in Australia or overseas about the role of senators and about the role of business migration.

However, we did not hear any of that, and I guess that in itself that is a reflection on senators opposite. We heard from Senator Short a beat-up of the worst sort about the Victorian election campaign, where he accused Premier John Cain of misleading Victorians. Senator Short cited what he said was a series of statistics to prove that. I think it needs to be said that Premier Cain enjoys the highest reputation for political integrity in office. It is not something that any of his political foes would ever seek to take issue with. Indeed, when Mr Sinclair on a public occasion said of Premier Cain: `Is this the sort of man you would trust your daughter with?', there was such a public outcry in defence of Premier Cain's integrity there was no argument but that the conservatives who adhered to the Sinclair view lost considerable credibility in the eyes of the electorate.

As to the sorts of examples that Senator Short has given, I am not at this moment and in these circumstances able to rebut them exhaustively, but I do say, however, that the Government does not accept them. We are aware that, under the present State Labor Administration, Victoria has enjoyed the highest level of economic growth of any of the States in the Commonwealth, that it has a very high level of employment, a growing level of employment, and that it is marked as a State exuding a great deal of political stability and economic growth-which rewards all of its citizens in as fair a way as one can expect in a Westminster parliamentary democracy of the sort that we have in Australia.

This must be contrasted with the situation in New South Wales, where, indeed, the Greiner Government did what Senator Short is now accusing Premier Cain of doing. Shortly after the Greiner Government came to power, it broke, in a completely arrogant way, the promises that it had made about not increasing State Government taxes and charges. It broke those promises bare facedly and in direct repudiation of its previous electoral undertakings. That has not happened in Victoria under Labor, but it has happened in New South Wales under the Liberals. It stands as a great disgrace in terms of the political situation in New South Wales. The situations in the two States are not directly comparable. While we have heard no mention by Senator Short of the Greiner reversal, we now have a fairly transparent cobbling together of a series of baseless statistics aimed at trying to prove a case that does not stand up, in an attempt to besmirch the Cain Government. It is a fairly sorry effort and one that must be put down as such.

Senator Alston went one step further. Based on a concern that he expressed about the Morwell Migrant Resource Centre, he has tried to besmirch the reputation of a very fine member of the House of Representatives, the honourable member for McMillan, Barry Cunningham. I do not know whether Senator Alston gave the honourable member for McMillan notice that he was going to do this, but before attacking a member in this way such a courtesy ought to be extended. However, I think the honourable member for McMillan will find an appropriate way to respond to those remarks. The Government does not accept any of the allegations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
